As such the special qualities and attributes  of this historic  rural landscape would be harmed contrary to the aims of Policies 1, 2, 7, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs  8, 79, 124, 127, 170, 192 and 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 In the absence of a suitable structural survey report the Local Planning Authority is unable to ascertain  as to whether the existing  buildings are capable of re-use in accordance  with the aims of Policy  7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 79 of the National  Planning Policy Framework  2019.

Address: Land Adj Treglow Penmenner Road The Lizard Cornwall TR12 7NR
Description: Outline application for exceptions housing scheme with detailed access (scale, layout, appearance and landscaping reserved) (up to 8 dwellings)
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the settlement  of Lizard and is located  within the countryside. The proposal has been submitted as a rural exception site but the proposed introduction of new dwellings  onto this land would result  in adverse harm  to the intrinsic character and beauty of the surrounding area which is designated  an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty  and would be prominent  from a number of public viewpoints.  It is considered that this proposal  would  not be appropriate in this location given the resulting harm to the character  of the area such that it would not  conserve or enhance  the area. The proposal  would  conflict with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030; as well as paragraphs 8, 127, 170 and 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019 and policies CC2, MD5 and MD9 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021. 2 The proposal has not demonstrated  that a suitably safe means  of access  and associated visibility splay can be achieved on site without  the need to remove large sections of hedging. The submitted  visibility splay plan is inadequate and does not accord with Section  7 of The Manual  for Streets.  The result  is that it has not been adequately demonstrated that a safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved, and the removal of large sections of hedging  would lead to an adverse impact on the character of the area which is within  an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty such that the proposal conflicts with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030; as well as paragraphs  8, 108, 109, 127, 170 and 172 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019 and policies CC2, MD5 and MD9 of the Cornwall  Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021 and guidance within  Section 7 of the Manual  For Streets. 3 Notwithstanding the scheme being in outline form,  the scheme is not considered to be affordable housing led as the submitted indicative plan shows less than 50% of the site area given over to affordable units; and there has been no mechanism to secure the delivery  of affordable  housing.  The proposal is therefore contrary  to policy  9 of the Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic  Policies  2010-2030 and the aims and intentions  of Government advice contained within paragraph 77 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: ADP Diamex Dunmere Road Bodmin Cornwall PL31 2QN
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved except access for the construction of 10 dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal fails to demonstrate how safe, suitable and desirable pedestrian and cycle movements to and from the site can be provided.  This  conflicts with the objectives  of enhancing active  travel patterns, improving  access to public transport, and encouraging a modal  shift away from private motor vehicles, in the interests of reducing resource consumption, air quality improvement and maintaining highway safety conditions.   It is considered therefore that the development is not sustainable and contrary  to Policies 2, 12, 16 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030, Connecting Cornwall 2030 and the aims and intentions of paragraphs  8, 91, 102, 103, 108, 110, 127, 148, 150, 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework. 2 In the absence of robust survey  data, the proposal has failed to demonstrate the level of ecological impact resulting from the development nor the ability to mitigate or compensate impacts to a level that accords  with Policy 23 1., 3., 3.d) of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030,  and the proposal  fails the derogation tests in respect  to dormice and bats causing conflict  with The Conservation of Habitats  and Species Regulations 2017.  It is not considered that the proposal in respect to its environmental dimension  constitutes sustainable development. 3 The application has not been accompanied with evidence that active marketing has taken place prior to the submission of the application and so fails to demonstrate there is no market demand  for this business contrary  to Policy  5 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030.  Without  evidence of the lack of demand  for this business space,  it cannot be concluded  that the loss would be outweighed  by the economic  benefits of the development through employment during the construction phase  and local spend of the future occupiers of the housing.  It is considered therefore  that the proposal  does not in its economic dimension contribute to sustainable development and is conflicts with Policies 5 (2.) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030.

Address: 2 Greenbury Greenbury Lane Rosudgeon Cornwall
Description: Outline planning permission (some matters reserved) for construction of two dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, near to a small cluster of houses which is not considered to be a settlement.  The proposal  will introduce  new dwellings with poor accessibility  to necessary  daily services and facilities and the proposed  introduction of new homes onto this land would  result  in harm to the intrinsic character  and beauty  of the surrounding area.  Given the lack of any special justification, the application  is not sustainable development and is contrary to Policies  1, 3, 7, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs  8,  79, 127 and 170 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: 22 Union Street Camborne TR14 8HG
Description: Conversion and extension of garage to form a self-contained annexe for a family member
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would  create a cramped and contrived form of residential accommodation that by virtue of its 2-storey design  would look at odds with the surroundings, which predominantly  consist of single  storey outbuildings to the rear of traditional terrace dwellings.  The annexe  would  introduce  a new bulky form of development that if repeated would  proliferate the erosion of the character of the designated Conservation Area and Outstanding  Universal Value of the World Heritage Site in which it is located. While the proposal  would result in less than substantial harm  to the significance  of the designated assets the public benefits would not outweigh  the harm created.The proposal would  therefore fail to accord  with paragraphs 8, 127, 130, 192, 193 and 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) 2018 and policies 1, 2, 12, 13 and 24 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 2 The site is situated in Camborne Town Centre (Extension 1) Conservation Area and Camborne and Redruth Mining District  World Heritage. The application is not accompanied by a sufficiently robust heritage impact  assessment and therefore  the impact on these heritage  assets cannot be assessed and is contrary to policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs 189, 190 and 192 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 3 The proposed development does not accord with policy  12 part 2.b of the Cornwall Local Plan and paragraph  127 (f) of the National  Planning Policy Framework because  of unacceptable  overshadowing and overbearing of the private rear garden  of the adjacent  property known as No.24  Union Street.

Address: Storage Building Adjacent West Towan Towan Lane Lobbs Shop St Austell Cornwall PL26 6BE
Description: Conversion of domestic storage building to unit of holiday accommodation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed conversion would create an unpleasant living  environment  for its future occupiers due to adverse noise and odour impacts from a nearby farmyard to the detrimental of their living conditions.    The  application,  therefore,  fails to protect and alleviate risk from a polluted  environment and is contrary to Policies 1, 12, 13 and 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 180 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Bygones 1 Bella Vista Gardens Truro Hill Penryn Cornwall TR10 8AN
Description: Lawful Development Certificate for the commencement of works under planning reference PA16/03474 - Erection of a bungalow
RefusalReasons: 1 The works evidenced and described in this certificate application are not considered to be a 'material operation' under Section 56 of the Town & Country Planning Act 1990 and therefore this certificate application must fail.

Address: The Old Coach House Churchtown Illogan TR16 4SW
Description: Conversion of store to dwelling (revised scheme)
RefusalReasons: 1 The confined nature of the site is such that the development would  appear cramped, poorly integrated with existing patterns of development and would have an adverse effect  on the setting and amenity  of the area. It would  also provide a poor standard of amenity  for future residents of the building.  By reason of its two storey  scale and design and use of materials the proposed development would cause  material  harm  to the designated  and undesignated  historic asset.  The development would  be an incongruous  and contrived  addition  to the street scene in this location and would  clearly  not add to the overall quality of the area and would not sufficiently integrate with the historic environment of this part of Illogan Churchtown.  It is considered that whilst less than substantial harm, the setting of surrounding heritage  assets,  including  the Listed buildings will be harmed by a proposal  of such poor design and scale in this prominent location.  On balance there is not considered sufficient public benefit to justify this harm. The proposal  would  therefore not accord with paragraphs 8, 127, 130, 192, 193 and 196 of the National  Planning Policy Framework (NPPF)  2018 and policies  1, 2, 12, 13 and 24 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 2 In the absence of an assessment of the existing trees that adjoin and overhang  the site in order to establish whether any tress that are present on and adjoining  the site that may be adversely  affected  by the proposal  it is considered to be contrary to paragraph  127 and 170 of the National  Planning Policy  Framework  2018 and policies  12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Kooyong Landlake Road Launceston Cornwall PL15 9HP
Description: Proposed erection of dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The design of the proposal,  in particular due to its positioning, height,  and close proximity to the parent dwelling would have a cramped  and contrived appearance that would harm the character of the area and be overbearing  on the parent property.  The confined relationship between the parent and proposed dwellings and positioning of the external amenity  space would also result  in unreasonable disturbance  to the occupants of the properties.  The scheme is therefore in conflict with policies  2 and 12 of the Cornwall  Local Plan and section 12 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019.

Address: Caravan Tregarne Manaccan TR12 6EW
Description: Removal of historical caravan, demolition of outbuilding, construction of replacement traditional retirement single storey dwelling, site clearance, landscaping and parking area
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal is considered to create additional  housing  development in the countryside which is not normally  permitted  unless there is an essential need for a rural worker to live at the location and no evidence of a need for the dwelling has been put forward. Future occupants  of the proposed dwelling would be reliant upon the private vehicle to access services,  goods, facilities and employment given the distance to the nearest  settlements. The proposed development would create  additional  built form leading  to the incremental growth of buildings and domestic paraphernalia  into the open countryside to the detriment of the character of the area. This is especially the case at this site which is located within an Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty and is in conflict with MD5 and MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021.  Paragraph 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework  2018 (NPPF  2018)  requires that great weight should be given  to conserving and enhancing  landscape and scenic beauty  in these areas and that planning  decisions should contribute to and enhance the natural and local environment. For these reasons this proposal  does not recognise  nor enhance the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside and consequently would fail the criteria set out in paragraphs  79, 170 and 172 of the NPPF 2018 and policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030.

Address: 8 St Gluvias Street Penryn Cornwall TR10 8BL
Description: To replace present windows with appropriately styled uPVC double-glazed sash windows.
RefusalReasons: 1 The replacement  windows by reason of their design, materials  and detailing  are considered visually inappropriate and detrimental to the appearance of the host property, street scene  and neighbouring listed buildings, thereby failing to preserve or enhance  the character  of the Conservation  Area contrary to Policy 24 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and Paragraphs 193 and 194 of the National Planning Policy Framework.  The proposed works would  cause less than substantial harm to the designated heritage assets  of the nearby listed buildings and Conservation Area but the public benefits of the proposal would not outweigh the harm to the significance of the heritage  assets.  Therefore the proposal would  fail to comply  with Paragraph 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework.  In addition, the proposal also fails to accord with the duties imposed by sections 66 and 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Area) Act 1990.

Address: Buscaverran Farm House Buscaverran Crowan Praze An Beeble TR14 9NQ
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for proposed removal of animal shelter and siting of twin mobile unit on existing concrete base
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation provided in support of the application and having regard to other information available the Council does not consider that the applicant has discharged their onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the twin unit caravan proposed, meets all the necessary criteria for the purposes of the 1968 Caravan Sites Act or as defined under Section 29(1) of the Caravan Sites and Control of Development Act 1960 (as amended). It is therefore considered that the proposal would amount to operational development for the purposes of Section 55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990. Furthermore, the proposed twin unit caravan would be sited outside of the curtilage area of the dwellinghouse known as Buscaverran Farm House, Buscaverran, Crowan thereby constituting the construction of a new unit of residential accommodation without the necessary planning permission. Consequently, a Lawful Development Certificate for the proposed development cannot be issued.

Address: Land South East Of Rookery Nook Fraddon Hill Fraddon Cornwall TR9 6NG
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters reserved: Two storey detached dwelling house.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling would result  in a negative and harmful impact  on the character and appearance  of the area by way of eroding  the open space and wooded area, which is covered by a Tree Preservation Order, and physically  extending the built form of the settlement into the open countryside. The impact on the distinctive character and appearance of the area and loss of woodland and scrub is considered to outweigh any benefits of this proposal  and therefore the proposal does not comply with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12,  21, and 23 of the Cornwall  Local Plan, and paragraph's  8,  170 and 174 of the NPPF 2019  .

Address: Dolphin House 27 St Gluvias Street Penryn Cornwall TR10 8BL
Description: Certificate of Lawfulness for a proposed Conservatory required to enhance building and gain more room.
RefusalReasons: The proposed erection of a conservatory to the rear of 'Dolphin House', 27 St Gluvias Street, Penryn would not be considered as permitted development under Class A to Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town & Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended, by virtue of its size and therefore planning permission would be required.

Address: Copthorne Methodist Church Copthorne Road North Petherwin Launceston PL15 8NB
Description: Listed Building Consent for change of use from former Methodist Church to bungalow. No external changes.
RefusalReasons: 1 Insufficient information has been provided regarding the proposed window alterations and interior alterations that would have a detrimental impact  on the building resulting in less than substantial harm to the Grade  II listed building. No justification as to the substantial public benefit of the proposal  or that all reasonable efforts have been made  to mitigate  the extent  of the harm to the significance of the asset has been submitted  that would outweigh the less than substantial harm to the listed building. The proposal  is therefore  contrary to policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030  and paragraphs 184, 19, 193, 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 The application is not accompanied by a phase  1 ecology  survey and therefore the local planning authority cannot be satisfied  that the proposal would not result in harm  to protected species. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 170 and 175 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Copthorne Methodist Church Copthorne Road North Petherwin Launceston PL15 8NB
Description: Change of use from former Methodist Church to bungalow. No external changes.
RefusalReasons: 1 Insufficient information has been provided regarding the proposed window alterations and interior alterations that would have a detrimental impact  on the building resulting in less than substantial harm to the Grade  II listed building. No justification as to the substantial public benefit of the proposal  or that all reasonable efforts have been made  to mitigate  the extent  of the harm to the significance of the asset has been submitted  that would outweigh the less than substantial harm to the listed building. The proposal  is therefore  contrary to policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030  and paragraphs 184, 19, 193, 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 The proposal fails to provide sufficient private amenity  space to serve  the functional and recreational  needs of future occupiers, including  for the provision of drainage and parking, and emphasises the cramped nature of the development. This would result in the occupants  having a poor standard  of amenity in accordance with policy 2, 12, and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs  127 and 130 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2019. 3 The proposal fails to provide an appropriate  level of off-street parking and a safe and suitable access  given that the site is accessed via single track lanes, is not accessible by public  transport and is not in proximity to facilities and services. The proposal is therefore  contrary to policies 13 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 103 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 4 The application is not accompanied by a phase  1 ecology  survey and therefore the local planning authority cannot be satisfied  that the proposal would not result in harm  to protected species. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 170 and 175 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Tregenna Steps Studio Tregenna Terrace St Ives Cornwall TR26 2DL
Description: First floor extension and associated works with Juliet balconies to the east elevation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its scale, massing and design,  in relation to its location, would result in a loss of a protected view of the harbour from the terraces within the town, as such,  the proposal  is contrary to policy OS9 of the St. Ives Neighbourhood Plan.  2 The development  would result in a loss of privacy due to the overlooking opportunities from the proposed  first floor Juliet balconies, which have an unacceptable adverse impact on the residential  amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties to the north and east, particularly the neighbours at No. 15, 16, and 17 Tregenna  Terrace.  The development is contrary to policy  GD1 of the St. Ives Neighbourhood Plan, Policy 12 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 127 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Desiderata Golberdon Road Pensilva Cornwall
Description: Retention of residential caravan
RefusalReasons: 1 The retention of this adapted caravan (which has now evolved  into an unsightlypermanent structure, accompanied by associated domestic paraphernalia)  hasresulted in the creation of a new dwelling in the open countryside withoutspecial justification, in what is an isolated,  car-dependent location. As such theproposal would be harmful to the interests of sustainability, it would  harm thecharacter and appearance of the open countryside of the Lynher Valley  sectionof the Area of Great  Landscape Value, and the location  of the developmentwould  be in conflict with the strategy for the delivery of dwellings as set out inthe development  plan. In consequence the proposal  conflicts with thedevelopment plan when considered as a whole, and, in particular, with CornwallLocal Plan (2016) Policies  1,2,3,5,7,23 and CL9, together  with paragraph 79 ofthe National Planning Policy  Framework 2019.

Address: Land Off Pill Creek Pill Lane Feock Cornwall
Description: Detached dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 Contrary to the aims and intensions  of Policies BIO 2, LS2 and D1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development  Plan 2017-2030,  and Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030,  and paragraph  172 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2018 the proposed dwelling falls outside  the settlement boundary for Feock in the Neighbourhood Development  Plan, is not infill or rounding off and would harm the natural  qualities of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty by reason of the loss of and pressure to fell or prune trees within an area of woodland protected by the Pill Creek Feock No 3 Tree Preservation Order 2018. 2 The proposed development does not accord with policy  12 part 2.a of the Cornwall Local Plan and paragarph  127 (f) of the National  Planning Policy Framework because  of  unacceptable  overlooking into the private  rear garden of the adjacent  property known as Waterside. 3 Contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan the proposals would result in the unacceptable intensification of a substandard access  detrimental to the safety of all road users owing to the poor emerging visibility  and acute angle of the priority T-junction between  the C101 road and the single vehicle width U6069  road.

Address: Rosehill Nurseries Landulph Saltash Cornwall PL12 6NF
Description: Construction of 40 dwellings (20 Affordable dwellings and 20 Open Market dwellings), Village Shop (A1), formation of new vehicular/pedestrian access and other associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is not located within a main town identified in Policy  3 as a suitable settlement to accommodate  the county's strategic housing  growth.  The site's location and scale of development does not constitute infill development or rounding off nor utilise previously  developed land.  The settlement is considered suitable for housing on a rural exceptions basis where housing development is responsive to local circumstances  in reflecting local housing  needs and be affordable housing led, however  the scheme is not considered to be a suitable Rural Exception Site as the scale of the development in relation to the settlement  and very low housing need is beyond what is considered appropriate.   Although the proposal offers  social and economic benefits through  housing  delivery  including affordable  units in this village location  (which are positive material  considerations supported  within  the NPPF)  these do not outweigh or justify  a departure from the spatial strategy pursued  by the Development Plan. The proposal is therefore not considered to constitute sustainable development  as defined by the Development  Plan as it conflicts specifically  with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7 and 9  of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016; and guidance within paragraphs  8, 11 and 15 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 In the absence of a mechanism  to secure it, the proposal fails to provide; affordable housing; off-site public open space contributions;  managing the increased recreational impacts on the Plymouth  Sound and Estuaries SAC Natura 2000 site; and off-site financial contributions to deliver improvements  to mitigate pressures on education.  The proposal is therefore  considered to be contrary to policies 9, 12, 13, 16 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and guidance  contained  within paragraphs 61, 62, 77, 94 and 96 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 3 The proposal, by reason of its scale,  density, massing  and location,  fails to conserve or enhance the landscape and scenic beauty of an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty  (AONB).   It is a major development  within an AONB and evidence has not been submitted to demonstrate exceptional circumstances in the public interest in order to justify its adverse visual impact  upon the character  and appearance of this designated landscape.  The proposal is not therefore  sustainable development  and is contrary to paragraph 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019 and Policies 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted  November 2016. 4 A safe and suitable vehicular and pedestrian access has not been demonstrated as the main vehicular  access  does not present appropriate  sight lines for all users  . The scheme is contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic  Policies  2010-2030, adopted  November  2016. 5 The application fails to provide  internal space  to meet nationally described space standards within all of the proposed affordable  homes; fails to demonstrate sufficient accessible homes will be delivered; its market  housing  represents more than 50% of the land take; and the proposal fails to provide sufficient external private amenity space for every dwelling  which creates a cramped  and poor housing layout that does not function  well or add to the overall quality of the area; contrary  to Policies 9, 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016 and paragraph 127 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Land At Carnon Downs Carnon Downs Cornwall
Description: Construction of 14 dwellings (use class C3) with associated infrastructure and landscaping.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is situated outside of the settlement  boundary of Carnon Downs, as defined in Appendix 2 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017 - 2030, and the proposal  could not therefore  be considered to round-off the settlement in accordance with Policy H1 of said Plan. Furthermore, there is neither an overriding need for affordable  housing in the Parish at present, nor any other  material planning considerations which would justify  conflict with the Development Plan. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict  with the aims and intentions of Policy H1 of the Feock  Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017 - 2030, policies 1 and 2 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 2 and 12 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 In the absence of a suitable mechanism to secure mitigation for the harmful  effects of the development,  specifically education  contributions for Devoran  and Kea schools  and improvements  to the play area at Parc an Gwarry  in Carnon  Downs, the proposal would  conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030. 3 In the absence of a suitable mechanism to secure mitigation for the additional recreational pressures  which the development would  inflict upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation,  the proposal  would  conflict  with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Land At Carnon Downs Carnon Downs Cornwall
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters reserved: Residential development (use class C3) of up to 45 units
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is situated outside of the settlement  boundary of Carnon Downs, as defined in Appendix 2 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017 - 2030, and the proposal  could not therefore  be considered to round-off the settlement in accordance with Policy H1 of said Plan. Furthermore, there is neither an overriding need for affordable  housing in the Parish at present, nor any other  material planning considerations which would justify  conflict with the Development Plan. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict  with the aims and intentions of Policy H1 of the Feock  Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017 - 2030; policies  1, 2 and 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 2 and 12 of the National  Planning Policy  Framework  2019. 2 In the absence of a suitable mechanism to secure mitigation for the harmful  effects of the development,  specifically education  contributions for Devoran  and Kea schools  and improvements  to the play area at Parc an Gwarry  in Carnon  Downs, the proposal would  conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030. 3 In the absence of a suitable mechanism to secure mitigation for the additional recreational pressures  which the development would  inflict upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation,  the proposal  would  conflict  with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Crenver Cottage Crenver Grove Praze An Beeble Cornwall TR14 0NS
Description: Conversion of domestic garage to beauty salon
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would, due to its location result in patrons  being  dependant upon the private  vehicle  to visit the proposed business and hence fail to accord with the aims of Policy 5 of the Cornwall  Local Plan which requires that new business  and tourism  proposals should  be well integrated with our city, towns and villages and well served by public transport. In the absence of any robust evidence to demonstrate that there is an identified site specific need for the business  proposal in this location the economic benefits of the proposal to the private individual would not outweigh the inherently unsuitable location of the site to local services, facilities  and transport  alternatives  and is therefore considered as unsustainable. As a result, the proposal  would  be contrary  to the aims of Policies  1, 2, 5 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 83, 87 and 108 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018. 2 The proposal, which would require  alterations to the existing domestic  garage in particular to the front elevation which overlooks  the main road, introducing  a change in character to the building through the introduction of patio doors, the associated parking by customers  and pressure  to provide advertisements and signage, which will not protect nor enhance  the character  and appearance  of the area which is viewed as part of the open countryside. The development is contrary to the aims of Policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs  8, 127 and 170 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land Adjacent To 1 Camel Valley Cottages Dunmere Road Bodmin PL31 2RD
Description: Full planning for a three bedroom dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is located outside the main town of Bodmin and is not within  any defined settlement.  The proposal,  if permitted, would  create  an additional  dwelling  which would fail to accord  with the housing growth  strategy identified  in Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and whose occupiers would be heavily reliant on accessing services and facilities by private car particularly having regard to the unsafe  pedestrian route along the A389 where there is no pavement.   This conflicts  with the objectives of enhancing  active  travel patterns, improving access to public transport, and encouraging  a modal shift away from private motor  vehicles, in the interests of reducing resource consumption, air quality improvement and maintaining  highway safety conditions. In the absence of any special circumstances  to justify  residential development  in this countryside  location, the proposal is not sustainable development and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 16 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030,  Connecting Cornwall  2030 and the aims and intentions  of paragraphs 8, 91, 102, 103, 108, 110, 127, 148, 150, 181 of the National  Planning Policy  Framework. 2 The proposed access arrangement  fails to demonstrate a safe and suitable access for the proposed  dwelling and, if permitted, would  be detrimental  to highway safety as a result of the introduction of vehicular movements onto the A389, substandard visibility, observed traffic speeds and volume of traffic using  this main road.  It is considered therefore that the development is not sustainable and contrary  to Policies 2, 12 and 27 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic  Policies  2010-2030 and the aims and intentions  of paragraphs 8, 91, 102, 103, 108 and,127 of the National Planning Policy Framework. 3 The design of the dwelling is constrained by the triangular  shape  of the plot which narrows at the front boundary which results  in a contrived design form which would form a prominent addition to the streetscene and fail to respond positively to the local character of development.   The proposal is considered to constitute an unacceptable  form of development  which would fail to take the opportunity for improving the character  and quality  of the surrounding area and is therefore  considered to conflict with the aims and intentions  of policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010 - 2030;  paragraphs 124, 127 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: The Homestead Crelly Trenear TR13 0EU
Description: Certificate of Lawful use for Existing use of garden in association with ancillary buildings in connection with private dwelling house
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation provided in support of the application and having regard to other information available to the authority, the Council does not consider that the documentation provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the onus of proof for the Applicant to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the use of garden in association with ancillary buildings in connection with private dwelling house at The Homestead, Crelly, Trenear, TR13 0EU (as shown outlined in red on the Site Location Plan received 17 January 2019) has been continuous for a period in excess of 10 years prior to the date of this application being received. As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing Use is refused.

Address: Seaview Holiday Village Polperro Road West Looe PL13 2JE
Description: Extension and improvements to Seaview Holiday Village caravan park, comprising use of land for the siting of additional lodges/caravans (static caravans) for holiday use; access and parking, landscape planting and associated infrastructure (Revised Application to PA17/09558 dated 09/02/18).
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, by reason of its loss to development of approx. 3.25ha of grassed fields and the introduction of a further 47 chalets  and static caravan pitches onto prominent sloping land which is visible from a number  of public viewpoints would fail to conserve and enhance the landscape  character and natural beauty of the South Coast  Eastern section of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty.   As such it would conflict with Policies  3(4) and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016; Policies 1 and 9 of the The Polperro & Lansallos  Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030; and paragraph 172 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018.
Dev_Type: All other small scale major developments

Address: Land At Reawla Lane Reawla Lane Reawla Cornwall TR27 5HQ
Description: Demolition of existing barn and construction of new detached dwelling and associated amenity space and parking provision
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its two-storey scale and proliferation  of timber  fencing,  coupled with its siting on a narrow parcel of land along an otherwise  undeveloped frontage onto Reawla Lane, the proposed  development is considered to have an unacceptably urbanising effect on the character and setting  of both the settlement of Reawla, as well as the surrounding  countryside to the north-west which the site has a greater visual affinity. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict  with the aims and intentions of GGP Policy 3 of the Gwinear-Gwithian  Neighbourhood Plan 2016-2030; policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 8, 11, 127 and 179 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Sea View West Pentire Crantock Newquay Cornwall TR8 5SE
Description: Outline application for demolition of existing house and garage and erection of two detached houses with integral garages
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside outside of the settlement of Crantock, as identified  by the Crantock Neighbourhood  Development Plan, and is therefore divorced from any recognised settlement.  The proposed additional built development would result in harm  to the intrinsic  character  of the surrounding rural setting  within the Perranporth  & Holywell  Area of Great  Landscape Value  and with an additional new home with poor accessibility to necessary daily services  and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle  and unsustainable traffic movements.  Given the lack of any special justification, the application  is not sustainable development and would  be contrary to Policies  1, 2, 7, and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies H1 and PV1  of the Crantock Neighbourhood Development  Plan, and paragraphs  7 - 14, 30, 79, 102 - 103 and 170 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land North Of Wheal Friendly Wheal Friendly Lane St Agnes Cornwall
Description: Application for Listed Building Consent for Re-surfacing twentieth century Cornish tin mine features in need of attention due to weather erosion on mundic - requiring specialised waterproof plaster although the finish shall have the same appearance as the original portland cement plaster used
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed scheme is considered to promote ongoing deterioration and hide archaeological remains thereby  undermining the integrity, authenticity and setting of the listed building.  The proposals would  therefore  fail to preserve the fabric, character and special interest of the listed building, leading to harm which  would not be outweighed by any public benefit. The proposed would therefore  be contrary to the Council's duty as local planning authority  under section 16 (2) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and Government policy in paragraphs 127, 130, 184, 189, 192, 193, 194 and 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: 36 New Road Port Isaac PL29 3SD
Description: Demolition of bungalow and construction of new dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 Further survey work is required to ascertain if any bats are still using  the building and therefore the impact on this European  protected species  cannot be assessed  or appropriate mitigation secured and the application  is therefore  contrary to policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030  and paragraphs 175 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Land North Of Wheal Friendly Wheal Friendly Lane St Agnes Cornwall
Description: Re-surfacing twentieth century Cornish tin mine features in need of attention due to weather erosion on mundic - requiring specialised waterproof plaster although the finish shall have the same appearance as the original portland cement plaster used
RefusalReasons: 1 The scheme to render the structure would harm the historic  authenticity of the structure thereby  undermining  the integrity,  authenticity and setting of the listed building contrary to S66(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990. It is considered that the public benefits of the scheme does not outweigh the substantial harm caused  which is contrary  to policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030;  and paragraphs 127, 130, 192, 193, 194 and 196 of the National  Planning Policy Framework  2019. By the same actions  the proposal would harm  the Outstanding Universal  Value of the World Heritage Site contrary  to Policy  24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Lower Trewedna Farm Trewedna Lane Perranwell Station Truro Cornwall TR3 7PQ
Description: Demolition of barn and construction of dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, clearly divorced from any settlement.  The proposed  new dwelling would, therefore,  result  in harm to the intrinsic character of the surrounding  rural setting  and with a new home with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which  would perpetuate over reliance  on the private  vehicle and unsustainable traffic  movements.  Given the lack of any special justification, the application is not sustainable development  and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 7, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 9, 78 and 79 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2018.

Address: Mayfield Chymbloth Way Coverack Cornwall TR12 6TB
Description: Demolition of sub-standard dwelling and domestic garage and construction of two dwellings and two domestic garages
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its design which  would fail to respond  positively to the local character and distinctiveness in this prominent  location, the proposal is considered to constitute  a poor quality form of development which would fail to take the opportunity for improving the character  and quality  of the surrounding  area and the way it functions which  is designated an Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty and a Conservation  Area. On balance there is not considered sufficient public benefit to justify  this harm.  The proposal fails to demonstrate  a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding  of its location; the proposal  would therefore not conserve or enhance the area and it is considered to conflict  with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 124, 127, 130, 170, 172, 192 and 193 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019; policy  MD9 of the Cornwall  Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021 and guidance provided in section 7 of the Cornwall  Design  Guide and Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Area)  Act 1990.

Address: Mizzen Top Darloe Lane West Looe Looe Cornwall PL13 2BG
Description: Installation of doors from bedroom onto a new outside deck
RefusalReasons: 1 The raised decked balcony would have a harmful  and detrimental impact  upon the privacy of the occupiers of Tredarloe as a result of excessive overlooking.   The application  is, therefore, contrary  to Policy  12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (adopted  November 2016), paragraphs 124, 127 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019;  and Section 4 para 4.11 and Section 7 para 7.8 of the Cornwall  Design Guide 2013  2 The siting and design of the balcony and the proposal  to leave part of the timber framework of the balcony deck exposed would introduce an unsympathetic and discordant feature that would be harmful to the character and appearance of the area, failing to preserve the character and appearance of Looe Conservation Area.  The development would result in less than substantial harm  to the Conservation Area, which is not outweighed by the public benefits of the development.  The application  is therefore contrary to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 (November 2016) and Paragraph 196 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019.

Address: Chy An Garth Tregowris St Keverne TR12 6PT
Description: Outline Application to build a dormer bungalow with all matters reserved
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal is considered to create additional  housing  development in the countryside which is not normally  permitted  unless there is an essential need for a rural worker to live at the location and no evidence of a need for the dwelling has been put forward. Future occupants  of the proposed dwelling would be reliant upon the private vehicle to access services,  goods, facilities and employment given the distance to the nearest  settlements. The proposed development would create  additional  built form leading  to the incremental growth of buildings and domestic paraphernalia  into the open countryside to the detriment of the character of the area. This is especially the case at this site which is located within an Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty and is in conflict with MD5 and MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021.  Paragraph 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework  2018 (NPPF  2018)  requires that great weight should be given  to conserving and enhancing  landscape and scenic beauty  in these areas and that planning  decisions should contribute to and enhance the natural and local environment. For these reasons this proposal  does not recognise  nor enhance the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside and consequently would fail the criteria set out  in paragraphs 79, 170 and 172 of the NPPF 2018 and Policy 7 and 23 of the CLP. The proposal  is therefore  contrary  to the aims of policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs 79, 170 and 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land NW Of Alexandra Mews Alexandra Road Penzance Cornwall
Description: Erection of 3 bedroom single family dwelling with ancillary works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its design, would fail to respect  the character and prevailing built form found along Alexandra Road. The proposal  would therefore be in conflict with policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph  127 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land North Of 1 Horwell Villas Dutson Road Launceston Cornwall PL15 8DJ
Description: Listed Building Consent: Construction of 2 no. new dwellings within the rear curtilage of a former school (Grade 2 Listed); including modification of existing detached former toilet block and associated landscape works.
RefusalReasons: 1 Through the unsympathetic extension to the curtilage listed outbuildings so as to accommodate 2, stylistically incongruent dwellings  (i.e. featuring white render, horizontal wood cladding, pronounced oriel windows and flat roofs) the historic presence, significance and special architectural and historic  interest  of the host listed building  (a former school) and its setting  would be harmfully degraded in a manner contrary to Policies 2 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016. It is not considered that these  harms to the listed building and its setting would be outweighed by the benefits of the scheme.

Address: Land North Of 1 Horwell Villas Dutson Road Launceston Cornwall PL15 8DJ
Description: Construction of 2 no. new dwellings within the rear curtilage of a former school (Grade 2 Listed); including modification of existing detached former toilet block and associated landscape works.
RefusalReasons: 1 Through the unsympathetic introduction of 2 stylistically incongruent dwellings  (i.e. featuring  white render, horizontal wood  cladding, pronounced oriel windows  and flat roofs) into its rear garden/courtyard  setting, the historic presence,  significance and special interest of the host listed building  (a former school) would be harmfully degraded in a manner contrary to Policies 2 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.  By the same actions  the proposal  would  fail to preserve and enhance the character and appearance of the Launceston Conservation Area. It is not considered  that these harms  to the designated  heritage assets would be outweighed by the benefits of the scheme.

Address: Land Adjoining 21 Coombe Road St Stephens Cornwall PL12 4ES
Description: Outline application for erection of new four bedroom detached dwelling with all matters reserved except access
RefusalReasons: 1 The site comprises a green, undeveloped vegetated garden, including mature TPO-protected trees and forms a very prominent part of the wider area.  The proposed new dwelling by reason of its siting would materially  harm  the character and appearance of the area, significantly impairing its effectiveness in forming a green, undeveloped foreground, and providing a green  finger  which penetrates the built-up area and helps to maintain a close relationship between town and country which contributes significantly  to the character and appearance of this part of the residential  area of Saltash.  As such, the proposal is contrary to Policies 12, 23 and 25 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030, adopted November 2016, together  with the provisions  of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018, with particular  reference  to Paragraphs 127 and 170.

Address: Land East Of Higher Hawks Tor Cardinham Bodmin Cornwall PL30 4BE
Description: Change of use of land for the siting of three gypsy/traveller mobile homes
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is considered unsuitable for the development  proposed  through  its lack of accessibility (through distance and lack of safe or suitable alternatives to private motor  vehicle access) to services  and facilities which puts the proposal in conflict with Policies  6, 7 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 2 The proposal would  introduce three static caravans within  an engineered  bowl into the udeveloped open countryside and in so doing diminish  the opportunity for this site to contribute to and would erode  the habitat value,  visual amenity and lanscape character of the woodland which is a designated Area of Great Landscape Value  and Cornwall Wildlife Site.  Accordingly  the proposal conflicts with Policies 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Prospect House St Anns Chapel Gunnislake Cornwall PL18 9HD
Description: Construction of 18 dwellings (6 affordable), site access, service roads and infrastructure. (Resubmission of application PA17/10378 withdrawn on 16/03/2018.)
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is located within Flood  Zone 1 (low risk of flooding) on the Environment Agency Mapping and not within a critical drainage area, however evidence has been submitted by the occupants  of neighbouring residential  properties to the south of the site demonstrating that flooding  to their properties from surface water from land to the north of the site including the application site. Due to the topography of the area, surface water  run off originating from higher  land is directed towards  the proposed site and existing dwellings.   The Local Authority also has knowledge of drainage patterns in the area. Based on this, the LLFA questions the EA surface water mapping predictions as it would  appear that flooding occurs during lesser events than the 1 in 1000 year prediction.  The Flood Risk Assessment provided to support this application has investigated the flooding issues  and mitigation  measures have been suggested. These measures could aid in the management  of existing surface  water run off flows and so provide some betterment on the current  situation.  However,  betterment is proposed by mitigation  works on third party land and the owners  of this land have objected to the proposed  development  and submitted representations that they would  not allow drainage works on their properties.   The sequential  test has been undertaken and the proposal  would  fail this as there are sites in the parish that could  accommodate this scale of housing  that would  not result in the flooding issues which have been evidenced. The proposal would  thereby fail to provide  a deliverable solution  to the flooding from surface water  to existing residential properties and the highway.  The proposal would  thereby be contrary to Policies 2 and 26 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (adopted 2016)  and Part 14 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019 and Planning Practice Guidance. 2 A Section  106 legal agreement  has not been entered  into to secure the necessary affordable housing, public  open space and Special Area of Conservation contributions.   The proposal  would thereby be contrary to Policies 3, 8, 13, 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 (adopted 2016)  and the advice within the National  Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Steamer Quay Lower Kelly Calstock Cornwall PL18 9RU
Description: Demolition of boat store/holiday let building and erection of a detached dwellinghouse
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, by reason of its scale,  incongruent  contemporary  design and uncharacteristic extensive glazing would fail to assimilate  sympathetically into its historic and landscape context.  As such it would  materially harm: the Outstanding Universal Value of the Tamar Valley  Mining District  of the Cornwall  and West Devon Mining  Landscape World Heritage Site; the character  and appearance of the Calstock  Conservation Area;  the settings of the adjacent listed buildings - in particular  the adjacent viaduct  and the former chapel;  and the natural beauty  of the landscape of the Tamar  Valley Area of Outstanding  Natural Beauty. This harm is considered to outweigh the benefits of the scheme.As such the proposal  fails to accord with Policies 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016;  the advice at Section 2.6 of the Cornwall  Design Guide 2013;  paragraphs 127(c), 130,172,184  and 192(c)  of the National Planning Policy Framework February 2019; and Objective  3.4.1 & Policies  3.5.6, 4.5.1 and 10.5.8 of the Tamar Valley Area of Outstanding  Natural Beauty  Management Plan 2019 - 2024.

Address: Land South West Of Four Oaks St Nicholas Park Lostwithiel Cornwall PL22 0BA
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved: Erection of 1 New Dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 A new dwelling on the application site, due to its location outside of the development boundary as set out in the emerging  Lostwithiel Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015-2030, would introduce  a form of development which would harm the distinctiveness  and natural  setting of the town.  The proposal  is, therefore, not sustainble  development and is contrary to Policy HH2 of the Lostwithiel Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015-2030.

Address: Land South East Of Westholme Access To Trethevy Trethevy Tintagel PL34 0BG
Description: Construction of two dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 Due to the site's position  in the countryside beyond the established  settlement  limits of Trethevy,  it is not well related  to its physical form and its development for housing would  not constitute suitable 'infill' or 'rounding  off' of the settlement in this location.  The development of this prominent  greenfield  site for two dwellings would domesticate the existing largely rural character,  resulting in significant built form and harmful urban encroachment  where there presently is none.  It is contended this would be harmful  to the rural character and appearance of the locality and would not conserve  or enhance the landscape character and natural  beauty of the Area of Outstanding  Natural  Beauty (AONB) in this location.  The development is thereby  contrary to policies 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 in the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010 - 2030, saved policy ENV1 in the North Cornwall Local Plan Part 1 and Part 2 (adopted 1999), policies MD9 and PPW2.04  in the Cornwall Area of Outstanding  Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016 - 2021 and paragraphs  127, 170 and 172 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land North Of Old Chimneys Wesley Road Cubert TR8 5EU
Description: Conversion of barns to form two dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, clearly divorced from any settlement.  The proposed  new homes, including  associated domestic  curtilage, would result  in harm to the distinctive character and beauty of the surrounding  area including  the setting to the nearby Area of Great  Landscape Value.   Given the lack of any special  justification, including the buildings to be converted, by reason of their rudimentary design and poor state of repair  in this rural location, combined with the need for significant extension,  are not appropriate  to retain and would not lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting, the application is not sustainable development  and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs 127 and 170 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019.

Address: Land At Trevispen Farm Trispen Cornwall
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters reserved: Residential development up to 75 units including vehicular access, estate roads, car parking, landscaping, open space, drainage, infrastructure and all associated development. Demolition of all existing structures.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would extend development into the countryside beyond the current built-form of Trispen, which is not a main town identified in Policy 3 as a suitable settlement to accommodate Cornwall's strategic housing growth. The site's location and scale of development does not constitute infill development or rounding off nor utilise previously developed land and the site is not allocated in the emerging Neighbourhood Plan for St Erme Parish. Although the proposal offers social and economic benefits through housing delivery these do not outweigh or justify a departure from the spatial strategy pursued by the Development Plan. The proposal is therefore not considered to constitute sustainable development as defined by the Development Plan as it conflicts with Policies 1, 2, and 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan. 2 The proposed development does not relate positively to the existing landscape and would by reason of its scale and prominent position on sloping land outside the settlement of Trispen, result in unacceptable adverse visual impact to the detriment of the countryside setting of the settlement contrary to policies, 2, 12, and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan. 3 In the absence of a signed legal undertaking, the proposal fails to provide: affordable housing for which there is an identified need; the future maintenance of on-site public open space; improvements to existing public rights of way off_x0002_site; financial contributions to deliver improvements to mitigate pressures on public open space provision; and off-site financial contributions to deliver necessary attendant improvements to education facilities at the Trispen Academy. The proposal is therefore considered to be contrary to policies 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 16 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan. 4 In the absence of a mechanism to secure associated provisions for mitigation of any potential adverse impacts on the Penhale Dunes and the Fal and Helford Special Areas of Conservation it is not possible to establish whether the proposals would have a harmful impact on these Natura 2000 European Protected sites contrary to policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan.

Address: Land At Wheal Owles Lane Truthwall St Just Cornwall TR19 7QN
Description: Construction of a single affordable dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 Whilst the development is considered to be affordable housing-led on balance,  it is considered  to be poorly related  to the physical form of Truthwall and to be inappropriate in scale and character,  given that it does not directly  adjoin the built form of the settlement and would contribute towards  a coalescence of the sporadic collection of buildings  to the west with the settlement. The proposal  is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions  of policies 2, 9 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010 - 2030, and paragraph 127 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019. 2 By reason of occupying an exposed and prominent site in the local landscape which would consolidate the sporadic built form extending westward from Truthwall, the proposal is considered to neither conserve the landscape and scenic beauty  of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural  Beauty, nor take into account the sensitivity and capacity  of the landscape asset. The proposal  is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions  of policies 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010 - 2030, paragraphs 127, 170 and 172 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019, and Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management  Plan 2016 - 2021. 3 By reason of occupying a site which forms part of a large, undeveloped gap between the remnants  of the Wheal Owles mine to the west and the mining settlement of Truthwall  to the east, the proposal is considered to contribute towards a coalescence  of these two, distinct groupings of historic buildings, in turn harming  their setting and significance,  as well as the setting of the Botallack and Truthwall Conservation  Area and St Just Mining  District World  Heritage Site. The proposal is therefore  considered to conflict  with the aims and intentions of S72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings  and Conservation Areas) Act 1990; policies 2 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 184, 192, 193 and 196 of the National  Planning Policy  Framework  2019; and policies  P3 and C7 of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape  World Heritage Site Management  Plan 2013 - 2018.

Address: Beachside Holiday Park 12 Lethlean Lane Phillack Cornwall TR27 5AW
Description: Construction of unfettered owner's accommodation (to be the existing approved unit 4 from planning approval ref PA12/09392 in perpetuity ref PA14/08824) in lieu of existing unfettered owner's accommodation (planning approval ref 15180/W) due to the demolishing of this existing unfettered owners accommodation for shop expansion to the park (planning approval PA18/01305)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed residential dwelling by reason of the location  of the site in the open countryside would represent  new unfettered residential  development for which no special  justification has been adequately demonstrated.  The proposal therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic  form of development. The development is therefore  contrary  to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs  7, 8 and 79 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Trethias Farm St Merryn Padstow Cornwall
Description: Proposed siting of agricultural worker's caravan
RefusalReasons: 1   The application fails to demonstrate  a functional requirement for a new residential unit in connection  with the agricultural  enterprise in this location. In the absence  of any identified need the development if approved would  constitute a new dwelling  in the countryside contrary to the principles  of sustainability embodied in policies 1, 2 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and the guidance contained within the National Planning Policy Framework  - 2018 with particular regard  to Section 15. 2 The development  site is located within the designated  Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty  and due to the visibility of the development combined with the associated permanent works that are required  would have a harmful  impact  on the character and visual amenities  of the area. The application has failed  to demonstrate any overriding need to outweigh this landscape harm and as such would be contrary to Cornwall Local Plan Policy 23 and the guidance contained within the National Planning Policy  Framework - 2018 with particular regard to para 79 and the supplementary planning advice  within the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021 policies  MD2 and MD9.

Address: 1 Beach Road Newquay TR7 1ES
Description: Conversion of bar and night club to 5 no. residential flats and 2 no. retail units including vertical extension to create a second floor level
RefusalReasons: 1 The increased  height  of the proposed  building,  such that it protrudes above the adjacent buildings and the inclusion of significant  areas of balconies  and fenestration, particularly on the Gover  Lane elevation, is considered to amount  to overdevelopment of the site which  is out of scale with the streetscene and in an appearance which jars with the predominant  character  of the surrounding built form, resulting in harm to both the character  and appearance of the locality.  As such, the proposal is considered to be contrary  to the aims and intentions of policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030 - adopted November 2016. 2 The proposed residential units have been designed  with large windows and balconies opening onto two of the busiest night-time economy streets in Newquay. It is considered that the residential  amenities of the occupiers of such units could  suffer, particularly from excessive noise disturbance. The information contained within the noise impact assessment supplied  with the application  is considered to be insufficient to adequately demonstrate that a significant adverse effect upon the amenity of future  occupiers of the proposed residential  units would be unlikely to occur.  As such, the proposal  is considered contrary to the aims and intentions of policies  12 and 13 of the Cornwall  Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030 - adopted November 2016 and section 12 and, in particular,  paragraph 127 of the National Planning  Policy Framework  - July 2018.

Address: The Shed Bosworgy Road Townshend TR27 6ES
Description: Certificate of Lawfulness for existing use of building as a self-contained, independent dwelling house
RefusalReasons: 1 On the basis of the submitted documentation provided and having regard to other information available to the Local Planning Authority it is considered on the balance of probability, that the 'building' which the applicant has applied for was not, either in part or wholly, substantially completed as a dwellinghouse in excess of four years prior to the date of this application. Notwithstanding the above reason for refusal, the Council also considers that the applicant has failed to discharge their onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the use of building as a self-contained, independent dwelling house known as 'The Shed Bosworgy Road Townshend TR27 6ES' has been ongoing for a period in excess of 4 years. The documentation provided in support of the application is not sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the applicants` onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the use of the building as a self-contained dwelling is lawful or immune from enforcement action in accordance with Section 171B (2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). Therefore, the Council refuses to grant this Certificate of Lawful Use (existing use) being applied for.

Address: Sunny Croft Ava Mevagissey PL26 6RY
Description: Removal of self contained annexe and erection of a new dwellinghouse with associated parking.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling,  by reason of its location, siting and design would  introduce an intrusive  built form onto the plot to the detriment of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and the general character of the area.   The application is, therefore, contrary  to the aims of Policies 1, 2, 3, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010-2030 and paragraphs 130 and 170 of the National Planning Policy  Framework 2018 and Mevagissey Neighbourhood  plans Policies D5, EG1, EG3 and EG5.

Address: The Vicarage Cox Hill Cocks TR6 0AT
Description: Erection of a single residential dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal introduces a vulnerable use (a dwelling)  on land which is known  to be at significant risk of flooding from surface water sources identified by the Local Lead Flood Authority. In addition the applicant fails to demonstrate  there are no other  available sites at a lower risk of flooding than the proposed site within Cocks or in nearby  settlements for residential  development. The proposal is therefore  contrary  to the aims and intentions  of Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the aims and intentions contained within the National Planning Policy  Framework 2019 with particular regard to paragraphs 155-158.

Address: The Queens Arms Inn Pellor Road Breage TR13 9PD
Description: Proposed erection of 5 no. new dwellings, reconfiguration of Public House car park and beer garden, and amended access to allotments
RefusalReasons: 1 The siting of five dwellings on this parcel  of land would  be excessively  prominent in the immediate and wider setting of the Conservation  Area and World Heritage Site and would lead to the adverse impact on an element of the Conservation  Area which makes a significant  positive contribution to the Breage  Conservation Area; through  being an open area at the centre of the village which also forms part of the setting of the nearby Grade I Listed  Church, the conservation of which should be afforded great weight.  The proposal would have substantial harm upon the designated heritage assets and this harm is not outweighed  by the limited benefits of 5 new dwellings.The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions  of Sections 66 (1) and 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990; policies  1, 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 8, 127, 184, 190,192, 193, 194, 195, 196, 200 and 201 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018;  and guidance contained in section 6 of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape  World  Heritage Site Management  Plan 2013-2018,  the Breage Conservation Area Appraisal & Management  Strategy - 2010 and section 66 and 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 and Historic Environment  Good Practice Advice in Planning Note 3, The Setting of Heritage  Assets (2nd Edition).

Address: Land East Of Connerton Farm Greenbank Connor Downs Cornwall TR27 5DA
Description: Outline planning permission for affordable-led housing of up to 70 houses
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is not located within a main town identified in Policy  3 as a suitable settlement to accommodate  the county's strategic housing  growth.  The site's location and scale of development does not constitute infill development or rounding off nor utilise previously  developed land and the site is not allocated in the Gwinear-Gwithian Parish Neighbourhood Plan.  The settlement is considered suitable for housing on a rural exceptions basis where housing development is responsive to local circumstances  in reflecting local housing  needs and be affordable housing led. However the scheme  is not considered to be a Rural Exception Site as the scale of the development in relation to the settlement  is beyond what is considered a small scale rural exception  site (70 dwellings represents approximately an 13% increase to the number  of dwellings in Connor Downs as at 2011).  Although the proposal  offers social  and economic  benefits through housing delivery  including affordable units in this village location  (which are positive  material  considerations supported within the National Planning Policy  Framework) these  do not outweigh or justify a departure from the spatial  strategy pursued  by the Development Plan. The proposal  is therefore  not considered to constitute  sustainable development as defined by the Development  Plan as it conflicts with GGP Policy  2 - Connor Downs - Rural Exception Housing Sites of the Gwinear-Gwithian Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2016-2030,  Policies 1, 2, 3, 9 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan and guidance within paragraphs 8, 11 and 15 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2018. 2 In the absence of a mechanism  to secure it, the proposal fails to provide; affordable housing for which there is an identified need; the future  maintenance of on-site public open space; and off-site  financial contributions to deliver improvements to mitigate pressures  on education and local sports infrastructure provision, children's play area or equipped facilities.  The proposal  is therefore  considered to be contrary to GGP Policy 1 - Connor  Downs - Settlement  Boundary and GGP Policy 2 - Connor Downs  - Rural Exception  Housing  Sites of the Gwinear-Gwithian Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2016-2030,  policies 9, 12, 13, 16 and 28 of the Cornwall  Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and guidance  contained within paragraphs 61, 62, 77, 94 and 96 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: 1 Willow Close Mylor Bridge Cornwall
Description: Proposal for the erection of a single storey 'L'shaped bungalow
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed application site is of limited size, resulting in the proposed dwelling appearing as an overly  cramped  form of development with limited private amenity space  available. Besides offering  a poor standard of amenity for future occupants, such a development  is out of character with the form, layout and density of surroundings,  and by extent negatively impacts upon the character of the area. The development is therefore contrary  to Policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies  2010 - 2030 and paragraph 127 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: The Cottage Buckshead Constantine Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5QR
Description: Conversion of a redundant farm building into a dwelling, together with stables/store
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed conversion and extension of this former agricultural/horsicultural building would be tantamount  to the construction  of a new dwelling  in the countryside and combined with the associated domestic paraphernalia would give rise to a detrimental  change in character  thereby harming  the character  and intrinsic beauty  of the immediate surrounding countryside  contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs  8, 78, 79 and 170 of the National  Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Ivy Dene Porthtowan Cornwall TR4 8UB
Description: Construction of a replacement dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed replacement home,  by reason of its siting, design and increase in massing, will have a harmful effect on the distinctive character  and appearance of the surrounding  area.   The  application, therefore, is not sustainable development and is contrary  to Policies 2(1), 12, 21(c) and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 122, 127 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2018.

Address: Land And Railway Carriage East Of Treza Vean Tolponds Road Porthleven Cornwall TR13 9LZ
Description: Removal of dilapidated railway carriage and erection of detached timber framed holiday cottage.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would  introduce new development into the countryside  and when viewed from the adjacent  public highway the development would  cause adverse harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposed  development therefore does not accord  with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic  Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 127 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Ball Meadow Bodieve Wadebridge Cornwall
Description: Outline Planning Consent for residential development comprising up to 225 dwellings, a new link road between Ball Roundabout and B3314, new highway access, provision of a new pedestrian/cycle bridge over A39, new primary school, new local centre, employment area, family pub, public open space, landscaping and associated infrastructure with associated access
RefusalReasons: 1 Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan states that the delivery  of housing,  retail and employment growth in main towns will be managed through site allocations  in order to ensure that growth  is genuinely plan-led. The application site is not an allocated site for development,  does not constitute  windfall under Policy 3 nor the exceptions for residential development in the countryside under Policy  7, has not demonstrably passed the sequential test pursuant to Policy 4, nor the provisions of Policy  5 1. a) - d) and 4. in respect to employment land.
