The proposal is, therefore, contrary to policies 1, 2, 5 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, policy LUD7 of the Ludgvan Parish Neighbourhood Plan, section 7 of the Ludgvan Parish Council Parish Design Statement and paragraphs 8, 124, 126 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The application is refused in accordance with paragraph 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: East Yolland Farm Upton Cross Liskeard Cornwall PL14 5AJ
Description: Detached annexe for use ancillary to adjacent principal dwellinghouse and change of use of land to extend proposed curtilage of the dwelling house
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed annexe, by reason of its scale, two storey form, the level of accommodation that it would provide and its position and siting within the site; some distance from the host dwelling, would effectively create, and present as, a new dwelling in an inappropriate rural location and, as such, it would represent unsustainable development in a manner that would  conflict with Policies 2, 3 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Streategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016).

Address: Baba Restaurant Promenade Penzance TR18 4NP
Description: Outline Application with all matters reserved for demolition of existing restaurant and construction of coffee shop, cafe and bar on ground floor with holiday lets and owner's accommodation above.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would provide relatively modest, albeit valuable economic and social benefits, notably through local job creation (including during the construction phase) and increased tourism spending. However, when weighed against the loss of the non-designated heritage asset of relatively substantial significance and the lack of compelling evidence that the building is beyond viable repair, it is considered that these benefits would not be overriding in this case. The proposal is not therefore considered to provide substantial public benefits to outweigh the loss of the host non-designated heritage asset, in conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 Whilst the proposed development could be made safe for its lifetime without increasing flood risk elsewhere, it has not been adequately demonstrated that there aren't any other reasonably available sites for the proposed development in an area with a lower risk of flooding, thereby failing to pass the Sequential Test. The proposal is therefore considered to constitute inappropriate development in an area at risk of flooding, and to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 159, 161 and 162 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021; and guidance contained in the section of Planning Practice Guidance titled, 'Flood risk and coastal change'.

Address: Oldthorns Road From Chapel Hill To Prentice House Little Polgooth St Austell PL26 7DD
Description: Conversion of a building within use class E to a single dwellinghouse
RefusalReasons: 1 The development proposed will significantly alter the utilitarian and functional appearance of this barn with its timber cladding and lack of fenestration that clearly relates to this rural landscape. The building is not considered to be a suitably constructed rural building that would be considered appropriate to retain and its conversion to residential use would clearly not lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting on a site that is widely visible from the public highway.  The extensive glazing and raised balcony proposed in the conversion will fundamentally alter the perception of the building such that it will be recognised as an incongruous residential form that will harm the strong rural characteristics of this landscape. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character in this location.  As such, it conflicts with policies 2, 7, 12, and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 8, 79 and 130 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land And Buildings Adj To Cober House Trenear Wendron Helston Cornwall TR13 0ER
Description: Application for outline planning permission with all matters reserved for proposed 4 bedroom new build
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal is located outside of any defined settlement, such that it is located within the open countryside where new residential units are only permitted in special circumstances; and it is considered that the proposal does not comply with any of the special circumstances of policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030 and would harm the rural character of the area; due to the proposed residential use and associated domestic paraphernalia and is therefore contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 80 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 15 New Street Penryn TR10 8EB
Description: Listed Building consent for retention of replacement rear wooden windows with double glazed PVC
RefusalReasons: 1 The introduction of the replacement UPVC windows and UPVC door would fail to enhance or restore/preserve the features and fabric and appearance and historic character of this Grade II listed house, its historic setting or the wider Conservation Area, and the harm caused by the proposed development would not be outweighed by any public benefits. As such the proposal conflict with Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) and paragraph 202 of the 2021 National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Llanfield Stables Prickly Post Lane Fowey Cornwall PL23 1EZ
Description: Temporary residential use of caravan/mobile home which has been on site since 2015 as a store.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is outside of a recognised settlement, in open countryside and no robust justification has been given for allowing a departure from adopted local plan policies and the provisions of the NPPF. The site is considered to be in an unsustainable location for new residential development and would increase reliance on the private car to access services and shops. As such it is contrary to policies 2, 3 and 7 of the adopted Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030, policies 3 and 4 of the Fowey Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan, and paragraph 80 of the NPPF 2021.

Address: Land West Of Grove Cottage Red Lane Rosudgeon Cornwall
Description: Resubmission of PA20/03479 (Two dwellings and alterations to existing access.)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would neither round-off the settlements of Rosudgeon or Perran Downs, nor infill a small gap in their built form and would therefore constitute development in the open countryside. The larger green gaps along Red Lane are considered to add significantly to its character and to allow residential development of the site and the need to alter and cut back a significant section of the existing Cornish hedge boundary to form the suitable access and associated visibility splay requirements and access track would represent further, incremental urbanisation of a pleasant, semi-rural lane, thereby unacceptably harming the character and setting of Rosudgeon and Perran Downs and the surrounding countryside in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The land was in use by a person/persons with mining connections and that as such would be regarded as a mineworker's smallholding, of which this area has many. As such, the field would be regarded as an attribute that expresses the Outstanding Universal Value (OUV) of the World Heritage Site. It is acknowledged that the southern field boundary has been lost, but the site and wider environs still retain an open and undeveloped rural character. The proposed development, that would be readily visible from the road to the north east and north west, is considered to erode some of that character which would neither conserve nor enhance the remaining legibility of this historic land-use contrary to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 189 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Rodda Meadow Road From B3257 To Junction East Of Cox Park Farm Coxpark PL18 9AZ
Description: Single storey extension
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its design, scale, materials and finishes, would result in an overly large and discordant addition to the existing converted barn that overwhelms its existing simple linear form and fails to preserve or enhance the appearance and character of this modest historic barn or that of its immediate setting within the Tamar Valley AONB. As such, it conflicts with the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 23, 3, 12 and 1 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies LA1 and HP6 of the Calstock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030, and Parts 15, 12, 4 and 2 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Bridge View Nurseries Church Lane Calstock Cornwall PL18 9QJ
Description: Proposed development of 33 dwellings with variation of 2 (approved plans) of decision PA17/09575 dated 20/12/18
RefusalReasons: 1 It has not been possible to conclude that the alterations to the extant permission as here sought would not harm the affordability and deliverability of some of the affordable dwellings to be provided on site (Units 6-10) and in turn impede efforts to meet the housing needs of all sections of the local community. In the absence of such certainty, and in accordance with the precautionary principle, the development would conflict with Policy 6 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Policy HP5 of the emergent Calstock Neighbourhood Development Plan, and paragraphs 8b and 63 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land And Building At Enys Cottages Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7ED
Description: Conversion of Existing Building To Form One Dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building is not considered appropriate to retain and the conversion of the building would not lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting in conflict with Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. The domestication of the building together with the proposed garden area which extends the development into the adjacent field would harm the rugged character of the existing coastal landscape. The proposed conversion would also detract from the character of Enys Cottages and the Old Watchtower which are non-designated heritage assets. The proposed development would result in a building with a greater visual presence within this sensitive and prominent location which is designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Heritage Coast and World Heritage Site. The modest benefits of the proposal through the contribution to the housing stock and economic benefits through the construction of the development are not considered benefits which outweigh the identified harm with particular regard to paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB and Heritage Coast and fails to protect and conserve the significance of the designated and non-designated assets in conflict with Policies AD3, AD4 and AD5 of the emerging St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021-2030, Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 37 Penmere Drive Newquay TR7 1QQ
Description: Proposed extension
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposals result in significant adverse impacts to the residential amenity of 39 Penmere Drive through overshadowing of their living room and the proposals would also have an overbearing/ dominant effect on this neighbour impacting on the occupants' enjoyment of their property. The proposals would also result in an unacceptable loss of privacy to the garden and conservatory of 27 Curlew Close through overlooking.  In so doing the scheme conflicts with Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and H1 of the Newquay Neighbourhood Plan 2019-2030 which seek, amongst other matters, to ensure new development does not adversely affect the amenity of neighbouring properties. 2 The proposed scheme by reason of its height, design and massing is out of keeping with the surrounding properties. It does not respect the tiering of properties down the slope within the cul-de-sac and will create a visually dominant and discordant form of development which is at odds with and detrimental to the street scene and character of the cul-de-sac and is contrary to Policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Newquay Neighbourhood Plan 2019-2030 Policies G2(c) and H1.

Address: Land To East Of Falmouth Golf Club Swanpool Road Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5BQ
Description: Change of use of land for the siting of six units of holiday accommodation together with operational development, including the provision of access roads, parking and levelling of land.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would result in the development of a site which forms part of a larger area of open space identified in the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan (NDP) as having a High Value, in conflict with the provisions of the Falmouth NDP which seeks to protect such areas from development. The proposal would result in the loss of an area of Grade 3a Best and Most Versatile agricultural land. The development is situated in a highly prominent and elevated coastal location overlooking Falmouth Bay and within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONB) and would be visible in close views from parts of the public footpath and public highway to the north and from parts of the South West Coast Path to the east, and in middle and longer distance views from the north and north east, including from parts of the South West Coast Path between Swanpool and Gyllyngvase beaches, the Boscawen Fields public open space, and Falmouth Bay. The proposed development would introduce built form and associated roads, paths, car parking and paraphernalia onto previously undeveloped agricultural land that contributes positively to the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB. It is considered that the proposed development would not be sympathetic to the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB in this highly sensitive and prominent location. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB. The development is therefore considered to be contrary to Policies 2, 3, 5, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies BE 3 and FOS 1 of the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030 Post examination version, the advice contained within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021, and the advice in paragraphs 8, 120, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure a financial contribution towards mitigating recreational impacts upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies 22, 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; the Cornwall Council European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document - July 2021; the Cornwall Planning for Biodiversity Guide - October 2018; and paragraphs 8, 55, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North Of Howard Farm Howard Lane Stratton Bude Cornwall EX23 9TF
Description: Proposed change of use and extensions to existing agricultural building to dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed works go well beyond a conversion and the scheme is tantamount to a new dwelling in the open countryside where no special circumstances are applicable, contrary to Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (CLP). In addition, the scale and bulk of the extensions would dominate and consume most of the original west elevation; and would create an unacceptable impact on the original building, contrary to Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Kenora Wheal An Wens Marazion TR17 0DF
Description: Demolition of Existing and Construction of New Dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and overall appearance, fails to promote local distinctiveness and would appear at odds with the established character and would give rise to a prominent and discordant feature within the context of the surrounding settlement.  In addition the proposed development is considered an intrusive and overbearing form of development due to is scale and proximity to the adjoining neighbouring dwellinghouses. The application is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Wellington Place Wellington Place Old Carnon Hill Carnon Downs Cornwall TR3 6LF
Description: Outline planning permission for the erection of up to five dwellings, to include the approval of the site access (all other matters reserved).
RefusalReasons: The  proposed development does not represent an acceptable form of rounding off or infill as defined in Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 because it would extend development into the countryside beyond the current built-form of Carnon Downs and by reason of its urbanising impact and extension of built development into the countryside would be detrimental to the rural character and appearance of the area. Therefore the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policies xx of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030. The submitted scheme does not demonstrate safe access/egress for the proposed development with the use of the existing byway (reference) which is considered unsuitable to cater for the inevitable vehicle movements generated by the development by reason of the surface condition and width, and would in the opinion of the Local Planning Authority give rise to conflict with other users of the public right of way.  The proposed location of this development would encourage vehicle movements in conflict with pedestrians giving rise to increased danger for all users and creating an unacceptable highway safety impact. As such the development is assessed to conflict with Policies 16 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of The Coach House Week St Mary Holsworthy Cornwall EX22 6UP
Description: New custom build house
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would, by virtue of its scale, form, appearance, layout and the size of the plot, appear cramped within the context of the site and discordant with the character and appearance of the surrounding built form whilst failing to reflect local distinctiveness. The cramped nature of the site results in an inadequate level of private amenity space for both the proposed dwelling and the existing dwelling.  The proposal would therefore conflict with Policies 1, 2, 12, 13 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South West Of St Buryan Farm Shop St Buryan Cornwall TR19 6EL
Description: Proposed new rural workers dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would introduce new housing development into the open countryside for which there are no special circumstances for its justification given that there is insufficient agricultural or land based worker function need to support the application at present. The proposed dwelling and associated domestic paraphernalia due to its significant distance from the existing farm shop, together with the existing undeveloped nature of the site and the contribution that it makes to the wider countryside, would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the open countryside and natural environment which is designated as an Area of Great Landscape Value and Heritage Coast. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, saved Policy CC5 of the Penwith Local Plan 2004 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 178 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Jedcott Dobwalls Liskeard Cornwall PL14 6JD
Description: Single storey extension and internal works to existing house and erection of 2no. dwellings with associated landscape works.
RefusalReasons: The proposal by reason of its mass would harm to the setting of the listed former St Peters Church; by reason of the close proximity of the 2 new dwellings would harm the setting of the host dwelling as a heritage asset; through the massing of Unit 1 and the array of large, south-facing windows would degrade of the levels of amenity currently enjoyed by near neighbours with regard to overshadowing and overlooking; and the increased massing onsite would harmfully impact upon the character of the locality. As such the development conflicts with Policies 2, 12, 21 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016; the guidance within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021 at pp32 and 73; and the guidance within paragraphs 199 and 124 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. It is not considered that these harms as identified would be outweighed by the benefits of the proposal.

Address: 12 Trewint Crescent East Looe Looe Cornwall PL13 1ET
Description: Two-storey rear extension to be completed same structure as existing property.
RefusalReasons: 1 The siting, the extent of projection and height of the proposed development, and its resulting massing would lead to an oppressive sense of enclosure to the rear amenity space of the neighbouring dwelling No.11 Trewint Crescent, whilst also having an overbearing impact and causing loss of light to the internal accomodation. The proposed development would significantly harm the living conditions curently enjoyed by the occupiers of No.11 Trewint Crescent. The proposal is therefore contrary to the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 1 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, with particular reference to paragraphs 8 and 130.

Address: Land East Of Bosavern Farm Bosavern St Just Cornwall TR19 7RD
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters (appearance) reserved for the erection of 5 two-storey dwellings with associated parking, amenity and site access (three 4-bedroom dwellings and two 3-bedroom dwellings)
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of the proposed development resulting in a clear extension of the built form of Bosavern into the surrounding countryside, on a parcel of land which is considered to be substantially undeveloped, the proposal is not considered to round off the small settlement or to constitute the development of previously developed land adjoining its built form. Furthermore, none of the exceptions for new residential development in the countryside would be met. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy AH6(3) of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021 - 2030, and policies 3(3) and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. 2 Whilst the application site is bordered by established and mature trees along its boundaries, it is considered that they would unlikely provide substantial screening of the proposed development from the surrounding area at all times of the year. Furthermore, it is considered that an improved scheme of planting along the boundaries would unlikely overcome any harm - indeed, the substantial shading caused by the existing trees upon the proposed dwellings and their outside areas, coupled with the likely desire to achieve countryside views from the dwellings, is likely to increase the pressure for their felling following occupation (despite any tree protection conditions), thereby making the development even more conspicuous, including in the setting of Bosavern House. The proposal is therefore considered to fail to at least conserve the landscape and scenic beauty of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies AD1 and BD8 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021 - 2030; policies 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021; and policies CC7, CC13, MD9 and WP7.05 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021. 3 Owing to the distinctly domestic appearance and tight and weaving nature of the proposed access through Bosavern House to the application site, it is considered that the proposal would not function well through its poor-quality layout which would fail to provide a clear and legible route to the proposed dwellings from the public highway, and would likely give rise to conflict between existing and future users of land and buildings. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 The application site appears on historic mapping as curtilage land serving the locally significant and apparently well-preserved Bosavern House and its outbuildings, and the proposal would result in the substantial covering of this land with buildings which would erode the spatial relationship between the site and the non-designated heritage assets, which are considered to be of relatively substantial significance. Furthermore, the harm caused is not considered to be outweighed by the relatively limited public benefits of 5 open market dwellings. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy AD3 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021 - 2030;  policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 194, 197, 199 and 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North East Of St Levans Church Porthpean St Austell Cornwall
Description: Construction of a 3/4 bedroom house on domestic recreation land.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site sits outside of the defined settlement boundary for Higher Porthpean and would not represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The proposal would physically extend the built envelope of the nearby settlement into the adjoining countryside to the detriment of the landscape character.  In the absence of any functional need and evidence that the dwelling is justified to be on the land, or any other special circumstances to justify the development as a whole in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and would be contrary to the guidance contained in Paragraphs 8, 11, 79 and Sections 5, 12 and 15 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 3 (3), 7 (4 and 5), 21(a,b,c,) and 23(2,) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and guidance contained within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021 and Policies H1, D2, and L1 of the St Austell Bay NDP.

Address: Minerva Guest House 2-3 The Crescent Newquay TR7 1DT
Description: Remove existing third floor area and form a new larger third floor extension of 5 bedrooms and two balconies (Resubmission Application PA20/10152)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, through its form, architectural language, height massing and bulk, will harm the character and appearance of the host property as well as the roofscape of this terrace through interrupting the stepping down of bulk and heights along the street scene. The proposal is considered to constitute poor design that fails to appropriately respond to its townscape setting and is in conflict with Policy G2 (c), D1 (a. 1 and 2) and E5 (b) of the Newquay Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019, Policy 12 (1a. and b.) of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land West Of Church Farm Church Farm Church Road Penponds Camborne Cornwall TR14 0QE
Description: Proposed self-build family dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its location outside of the definable limits of the settlement, represents an unsustainable, undesirable and sporadic form of development which would contribute to the erosion of the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside and the identity of the settlement. Unjustified by any special circumstances, the proposal would be contrary to Development Plan policy concerning the location of residential development and result in environmental harm, in conflict with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 119, 124, 126, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development would result in the intensification in the use of the substandard access between No. 21 and No. 33 Church Road, which has significantly constrained emerging visibility. The on-street parking of vehicles along Church Road adjacent to the access further restricts the forward visibility of the emerging vehicles. The access lane is single width with limited passing places such that a vehicle may be required to reverse unsighted on the highway. The proposal would not have a safe and suitable access, nor would it minimise the scope for conflicts between pedestrians, cyclists and vehicles, and therefore conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 1 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Kerris Vale Kerriers Road Inches Bodmin PL30 5LR
Description: Removal of Condition 5 (agricultural occupancy) of Application No. E1/87/0720/OOP dated 6th July 1987 (Erection of agricultural dwelling at Trevidgeorge Farm, Withiel)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, in seeking to remove condition 5 of the previous permission, would alter the nature and description of the previous development permitted under E1/87/0720/OOP. Given that the local planning authority shall consider only the question of the conditions subject to which planning permission should be granted, the proposed change in plans is considered to fall outside of the remit of Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and to conflict with the contents of Paragraph: 031 Reference ID: 21a-031-20180615 of the National Planning Practice Guidance (Revision date: 15 06 2018). 2 Condition 5 of the original permission, despite the certificate that has been granted, still holds a planning purpose. As such, the proposal to remove condition 5 and subsequently the agricultural tie, would be against the aims and intentions of Policy 7 of the CLP and 80 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Former St Johns Ambulance Station Rawlings Lane Fowey Cornwall PL23 1DT
Description: Addition of a one bed apartment above garage to include raising of ridge height and addition of balcony and access staircase to the east elevation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed works would, with the addition of the first floor and balcony area add additional raised massing, increasing the scale of the building, and add an alien feature to the street scene in the form of the spiral staircase, constituting a design that would be materially harmful to the character and appearance of the area. The works would be contrary to Policy 2 and 12 point a of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 Strategic Policies, NDP Policies 2 point 1 and 2, Policy 6 and Policy 8 point 2 and section 12 paragraph 130 point a and b of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The raised balcony area with associated screening and the increase elevated massing of the proposal would have an adverse overbearing and overlooking impact on the neighbouring property Drakenhuis, Rawlings Lane, Fowey. The works would be contrary to Policy 2 and policy 12 point 2 a of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 Strategic Policies, NDP Policies point 7.7 and paragraph 130 point f of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Shalimar Road From Barkla Shop To Higher Mithian Farm Mithian Downs St Agnes TR5 0PY
Description: Change of use of land to provide 23 pitch seasonal camping pitches with associated erection of toilet/shower building and administrative/service building
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development of the site for 23 camping pitches with associated erection of toilet/shower building and administrative/service building, by reason of its scale and location in the open countryside, divorced from nearby services, facilities and amenities, would represent unsustainable new tourism development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable, undesirable and sporadic form of development that would be harmful to the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside. The development is therefore contrary to Policies 1, 2, 5, 12, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policies 1, 6, 10, 13, and 19 of the St Agnes Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030, and paragraph 174(b) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Factory Unit Rear Of 75 Treverbyn Road St Austell Cornwall PL25 4EW
Description: Proposed extension to existing B1/B8 industrial/warehouse building and formation of vehicle turning/parking area and boundary landscaping
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would provide a harsh and conspicuous built edge with an industrial-like appearance which would be out of scale with the immediate built surroundings. This would undermine the appearance of this fringe just beyond the built form and thereby causing harm the character and appearance of the area and, consequently, conflict with Policies 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 2010-2030 which seek, in this respect and amongst other things, that development should respect and enhance the quality of place. 2 The increase in the level of traffic and activity particularly from HVG's entering, turning and leaving the site would cause harm to the adjoining residential properties through noise and disturbance not currently experienced. The proposal conflicts with Policy 12(2) and Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies which seek, in this respect and amongst other things, that development should protect individuals and properties from harmful impacts and health risks associated with air and noise pollution.

Address: Higher Charaton Farmhouse Road From Penharget Cottage To Golberdon Road Pensilva Liskeard Cornwall PL14 5RW
Description: Lift Condition 3 (Holiday use only) of Permission PA11/03319 (for the construction of six units of disabled holiday accommodation lodges with ancillary supervision unit and hydrotherapy pool with associated changing rooms and toilets. Formation of new vehicular/pedestrian access to highway.
RefusalReasons: 1 The lifting of this condition as sought would alter the nature of the development in a manner that would differ materially from the approved permission. As a result this proposal goes beyond the scope of Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 and is contrary to guidance within the National Planning Practice Guidance, specifically paragraphs 001 Reference ID: 17a-001-20140306 (Revision date: 06 03 2014) and 031 Reference ID: 21a-031-20180615 (Revision date: 15 06 2018). 2 By reason of the site being solely accessible from the nearest settlement by a long, narrow, unlit road with no footways and a sharp bend and the increase in movements associated with full dwellings when compared to holiday units the proposal would fail to provide safe and suitable access to the site other than by private car and it would materially degrade levels of highway safety. As such the site would not be appropriate for unencumbered dwellings.  Accordingly the proposal conflicts with Cornwall Local Plan Policies 12 and 27 and paragraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure its delivery, the proposal fails to provide an off-site financial contribution towards the delivery of affordable housing for which there is an identified need. The proposal is therefore contrary to Policies 8 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.

Address: Higher Charaton Farmhouse Road From Penharget Cottage To Golberdon Road Pensilva PL14 5RW
Description: Lift Condition 3 (Holiday use only) of Permission PA19/08006 (Proposal for three accessible lodges and associated landscaping)
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of the site being solely accessible from the nearest settlement by a long, narrow, unlit road with no footways and a sharp bend it is considered to be poorly related to that settlement. Mindful of the increase in movements associated with full dwellings when compared to holiday units the proposal would fail to provide dwellings in a location that accords with the spatial strategy of the development plan, and which moreover would fail to provide a safe and suitable access to the site other than by private car, and it would materially degrade levels of highway safety. Accordingly the proposal conflicts with Cornwall Local Plan Policies 3,9,12 and 27 and paragraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North East Of Glebe Cottage St Ewe St Austell Cornwall PL26 6EY
Description: Outline application with some matters reserved for rural exception site for up to nine dwellings and associated landscaping works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by virtue of its scale and location, would have a detrimental impact on the character of the village and surrounding landscape. The proposal would project development into open countryside and have a suburbanising impact in an oth erwise undeveloped pastoral and rural location. The settlement of St Ewe lacks a range of services and has no public transport connections to the wider area. It is not considered to be in compliance with policies 2, 3, 9 and 23 of the adopted Cornwall Loca l Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the provisions of the NPPF 2021.  2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan.  3 Insufficient information has been provided to assess the impact on designated heritage assets and archaeology at the site and the proposal is not considered to be in conformity with policy 24 of the adopted Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Polices, and paragraphs 194 and 195 of the NPPF 2021.  4 The application fails to comply with the habitat directives in that there is no overri ding public interest for the proposal and there would be a disturbance to foraging and commuting bats. The application is therefore contrary to policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 -2030 adopted 2016, paragraphs 180 and 181 of the N PPF 2021, the Conservation of Habitat and Species Regulations and Circular 06/2005.  5 A Section 106 legal agreement has not been entered into to secure the necessary affordable housing.  The proposal would therefore be contrary to Policies 3 and 9 of t he Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 -2030 (adopted 2016) and the advice within the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Pentangle 4 Nanpusker Road Angarrack TR27 5JX
Description: Construction of home office and associated storage for family business
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development is for a home office. However, the scale of the proposal is such that the development in effect constitutes the sub-division of the domestic curtilage of the existing residential property to facilitate a business use thus creating a mixed use of the site for both residential and business purposes. New build development in the countryside is strictly controlled though there is some limited policy support for new sustainable business proposals. Specifically, policy 5 of the Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030) supports employment land and uses in the countryside where the scale of development is appropriate to its location or demonstrates an overriding locational and business need to be in that location or an extension to an existing business where re-location would be impractical or not viable. Policy EX1 of the Hayle Neighbourhood Plan (2014-2030) supports proposals where the development demands a countryside location and paragraph 84 of the NPPF (2021) advises that planning decisions should enable the sustainable growth and expansion of all types of business in rural areas both through the conversion of existing buildings and well-designed new buildings. The applicant has not provided any information to demonstrate a business need for the proposed building to be sited at this rural location, nor any justification for the scale or internal layout of the development. Further to the above, the design of the proposed building is not locally distinctive, is not well related spatially to the existing development on-site and would constitute a prominent, discordant feature in the street scene that would not conserve or enhance the character of the wider open countryside. The development thereby fails to accord with the aims and intentions of the above-mentioned policies and conflicts with policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030), with policy NE3 of the Hayle Neighbourhood Plan (2014-2030) and with paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the NPPF (2021). 2 Insufficient evidence has been provided in regards to surface water disposal to demonstrate that drainage of the development site can be adequately achieved without increasing flood risk elsewhere. In the absence of this information, the proposal is considered contrary to the aims of policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030) and paragraph 167 of the NPPF (2021).

Address: Land South Of Lynwood House Mousehole Lane Mousehole Cornwall TR19 6TR
Description: Construction of residential dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The site and the surrounding area has experienced a number of historic flood events due to problems associated with the restricted capacity of the culverted sections of the Paul Stream and its tributaries. These are liable to blockage and have not been considered in the submitted Flood Risk Assessment. The submitted Flood Risk Assessment has failed to consider the safe access and egress to site during a flood event or to determine the hazard rating. This is required to make a decision on whether the level of risk during a flood event is acceptable in terms of emergency access and egress for the occupants. The Flood Risk Assessment is inadequate and fails to demonstrate that safe access and egress to the site during a flood event can be achieved in conflict with Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed dwelling is not reflective of the surrounding development and would appear at odds with the established character of the Mousehole Conservation Area. The proposed development would result in the gradual erosion of the sense of place which is created through locally distinctive buildings in conflict with Policy 2 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 which sets out that development should be high quality and demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location. The proposed development fails to preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Mousehole Conservation Area or enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty in conflict with Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021. 3 The existing access onto Mousehole Lane which is proposed to serve the new dwelling has constrained emerging visibility in both directions. An emerging car would be unable to observe approaching road users due to the boundary walls both side of the access, therefore leaving road users vulnerable to collision. The proposed development is therefore not considered to be served by a safe and suitable access in conflict with Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Grahams Garden Machinery A3058 Between Brighton Cross Roundabout And Myrtle Villa Brighton Cross Grampound Road TR2 4HD
Description: Construct a Managers dwelling within the grounds of the business known as Grahams Garden Machinery Ltd
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is in an unsustainable rural location away from any settlement and the proposed dwelling would be visible within the rural context and would detract from the open countryside character through the introduction of additional built development. The evidence provided has not demonstrated that there is a functional need for a worker to live on site in connection with the adjoining garden machinery business. The proposal thus fails to accord with Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan and without there being an essential need to live at the site the harm to the countryside character is not outweighed thus the proposal also fails to accord with Cornwall Local Plan Policies 2, 12 and 23 or paragraphs 8, 80, 130 and 174(b) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land At Wheal Honey Menheniot Liskeard Cornwall PL14 3RG
Description: Use of commercial yard for parking of buses, erection of sound barriers and access.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed site for the parking of 13 buses overnight (and used every day for public transport purposes) is located in an unsuitable location. It would involve the use of a network of largely single-track country roads with limited passing places and sections which are devoid of sufficient forward visibility for vehicles to utilise the passing places. The scale of the vehicles associated with the proposal and the significant intensification of such vehicles using the route would exacerbate conflict between road users over a considerable distance on the local highway network. The proposal does not demonstrate safe and suitable access to the site and would cause adverse impacts upon the local road network. This proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (adopted 22nd November 2016).

Address: Land North Of Beaver Lodge Trevelgue Road Newquay Cornwall TR8 4AT
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters reserved (Access): Up to 4 number dwellings, former quarry site.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal makes a small contribution to housing delivery in the community network area, supporting in a minor way services and facilities in nearby settlements, and jobs in the construction process. Against this the proposal is outside the settlement boundary for the settlement of Whipsiderry and does not accord with the spatial strategy for the delivery of housing pursued in the local plan or Neighbourhood Plan and would erode the intrinsic verdant character of the site following its re-greening since the cessation of its use as a quarry. The limited economic and social benefits of the proposal do not outweigh the harms identified within the report and the proposal conflicts with the spatial policies of the development plan and does not constitute sustainable development. The proposal conflicts with aims and intentions of Policies G1 of and LE1 the Newquay Neighbourhood Plan 2019-2030 and Policies 1, 2 3, 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and is considered unacceptable in principle. 2 In the absence of appropriate evidence, the proposal fails to adequately demonstrate how the development would impact upon any species protected by law both during and post implementation of the proposed scheme. In the absence of such information the Local Planning Authority is unable to assess whether adverse harm would be generated with respect to any protected species and hence the development is contrary to the aims of paragraph 179 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, guidance within the section titled 'Natural environment' of Planning Practice Guidance, together with Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030

Address: Mevagissey Bay Hotel Polkirt Hill Mevagissey PL26 6UX
Description: Demolition of hotel and redevelopment of site with five apartments.
RefusalReasons: 1 The building proposed by this application, by reasons of its siting, elevated massing and design, which includes extensive glazing and balconies on its front elevation, would appear discordant and jarring in the surrounding street scene and Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The resulting harm to the character of the area is contrary to policies 2, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan; policies EG1 and D1 of the Mevagissey Neighbourhood Development Plan; and paragraphs 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Land North West Of Bowood Park Lanteglos Camelford Cornwall PL32 9RF
Description: Outline application for development of residential units with all matters reserved, except access
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwellings represent an extension into undeveloped, open countryside beyond the built form of any settlements including Camelford. The site is not allocated for residential development in the emerging Neighbourhood Plan and does not represent infill or rounding off development or development of previously developed land adjoining a settlement. Neither is the proposal for an affordable housing led development. The proposal would be substantially reliant on private vehicles for transport and would be unsustainable in transport terms. The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of residential development in the countryside which erodes the character and appearance of the area and, in the absence of any special circumstances or overriding business need to justify it in this location or other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 2 (1d) 3, 5, 7, 9, 21, 23 (1) and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016), paragraph 80 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policy 1A (Camelford Development Boundary), 1B (Rural Exception sites) , 1D (Housing Development and Design) and 3D (Accessibility and Connectivity) of the Neighbourhood Development Plan for Camelford Parish October 2020 and paragraphs 92, 110(a) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of affordable housing, public open space, healthcare provision and educational financial contributions to mitigate impacts, the proposal is considered to be contrary to guidance contained within Policies 8, 13, 25 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016), paragraph, 55 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Cornwall Council Housing Supplementary Planning document (February 2020), A guide to planning contributions and health care provision in relation to primary care services (June 2020) And Guidance on S106 Planning Obligations for Education Provision (2018) 3 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that this proposal would not result in an increase in phosphate levels which would further adversely affect the current unfavourable status of the River Camel Special Area of Conservation. In adopting a precautionary approach, the Local Planning Authority is not satisfied that the proposal will not adversely affect the integrity of this Special Area of Conservation and the application is contrary to Regulation 63 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017; Policies 1, 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 8, 11, 174,and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 4 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that flood risk will not be increased elsewhere as a result of the development or that the site can be adequately drained and there will not be a risk of pollution of surface water. The site is over 1 hectare in size and no Flood Risk Assessment has been submitted. No foul and surface water drainage strategy, percolation test results or supporting calculations have been provided. No details relating to the management and maintenance of the drainage systems have been provided. As such the proposal has not demonstrated there will not be an increased risk of flooding and risk of pollution of surface water in accordance with the aims and intentions of Policies 16 and 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraph 159, 167 and footnote 55 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 5 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposal will leave the natural environment on the site in a measurably better state or result in at least 10% Biodiversity Net Gain, the proposal is therefore considered contrary to Policy 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Tregoddick Barn Madron Penzance Cornwall TR20 8SS
Description: Change of Use of family annexed accommodation to allow for holiday use
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would generate an increase in vehicle trips resulting in the intensification in use of an access which is significantly constrained in emerging visibility in both directions. The proposed development would not be served by a safe and suitable access in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Reflections Brenton Road Downderry Cornwall PL11 3JA
Description: Proposed detached dwellinghouse with garage and parking spaces (resubmission following refusal)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its scale and design, would dominate the surrounding built forms and landscape, representing an overdevelopment of the site, and would appear unduly conspicuous within its elevated setting above the neighbouring properties of Brenton Road. As such the proposal would fail to take account of the coastal and built contexts, or the character and appearance of the Area of Great Landscape Value. The development is therefore contrary to policies 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and saved policy CL9 of the Caradon Local Plan 2007.

Address: Land Development Off Swanpool Road Swanpool Road Falmouth Cornwall
Description: Construction of 2 detached dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The development is viewed in context with the large green swathe of wooded land along the eastern side of Swanpool. The proposal seeks to introduce 2 dwellings (and their associated residential paraphernalia, access and parking, and associated engineering works) onto this steeply sloping site to the detriment of the natural qualities of this tranquil setting which will be harmful to the wider landscape including the nearby Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The application, therefore, fails to meet the aims and intensions of Policy 2(1), 12 (1), 21, and Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 126, 130, 131, 174, 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2012 and Policy FOS1, DG1 and DG4 of the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030. 2 There is a lack of supporting information that clearly and convincingly demonstrates specific measures that will be implemented to prevent pollution and run-off reaching the closely related and highly sensitive Swanpool SSSI, contrary to Policy 13 (5), 16 (1) and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and paragraphs 179,180, 183 to 185 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 There is a lack of supporting information that clearly and convincingly demonstrates that the scheme can be undertaken without significant and unacceptable impacts upon trees (within the site and adjacent to the site, some of which are protected within the Swanpool Road Quarry Tree Preservation Order 2013) or local landscape character, contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraphs 131 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 In the absence of appropriate evidence, the proposal fails to adequately demonstrate how the development would impact upon any species protected by law both during and post implementation of the proposed scheme. In the absence of such information the Local Planning Authority is unable to assess whether adverse harm would be generated with respect to any protected species and hence the development is contrary to the aims of paragraph 179 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 5 The proposed development has been determined to lie within a historic mining area with naturally elevated levels of heavy metals and the potential for contamination. The applicant has not provided sufficient information to address the land contamination on site, in the form of a Phase 2 report, and therefore the proposal fails to satisfy the requirements of paragraphs 183 and 184 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy 16 (1) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 6 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of contributions towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Falmouth and Helford SAC for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan, the European Site Mitigation SPD (July 2021), and guidance contained within paragraphs 181 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South West Of Jacks Mews Atlantic Road Tintagel Cornwall PL34 0DP
Description: Proposed cottage on site of former two storey garage / store building
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its scale, the size of the application site and diminished distance to common boundaries to the East results in an overly cramped form of development which introduces issues of overbearing and loss of outlook which would be harmful to the residential amenity of The Haven to the immediate east. The proposed development does not provide a good standard of living accommodation and has an inadequate amount of private amenity space due to issues of overlooking. As such, it conflicts with Policy 2, 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Kallacliff 12 Lusty Glaze Road Newquay TR7 3AD
Description: Demolition of Existing Building, construction of 2 detached dwellings.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal shall, through its form, massing and appearance, lead to an incongruous addition to the street scene which will be to the detriment of the character of the area. The proposal shall therefore fail to accord with Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030, D1 of the Newquay Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019-2030 and Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal will lead to a significant impact to neighbouring amenity through its scale, height and siting and shall reduce neighbouring outlook from 2 Manewas Way to an unacceptable degree, as well as incur significant levels of over-shadowing and over-bearing to the same property. The proposal therefore fails to comply with the aims and intentions of Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030, D1 of the Newquay Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019-2030, Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and The Cornwall Design Guide 2021.

Address: Land North Of Nanturras Way Nanturras Way Goldsithney Cornwall TR20 9DG
Description: Change of use of land to campsite and erection of one ablutions block
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development will introduce a building, parking area and 30 tent pitches into a currently unspoilt meadow which is considered to positively contribute to the visual amenities of the area. The proposed development and associated paraphernalia will erode the rural character of the site, particularly in the winter months, thereby harming the character and appearance of the area in conflict with Policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Penthouse Nailzee Point Marine Drive West Looe Looe Cornwall PL13 2DF
Description: To extend living area in the roof space
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed extension of the top floor flat, by reason of the discordant design, appearance and architectural form fails to take account of the character and appearance of the host building, the historic context of the application site and would fail to preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Looe Conservation Area. The development is therefore contrary to policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 130, 194, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policy TC 3 of the emerging Looe Neighbourhood Development Plan and Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990. 2 The proposal through the extended external staircase would harmfully degrade outlook, levels of sunlight and daylight receivable and create an overbearing impact to the main living room window/patio door and balcony area serving flat No.12 immediately below. The proposal therefore is contrary to Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan, Paragraphs 130 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy DS 5 of the emerging Looe Neighbourhood Development Plan.

Address: Treglossick Farm Treglossick St Keverne Helston Cornwall TR12 6PS
Description: Change of use of land and erection of two glamping pitches and two compost loos and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed change of use of the site for two holiday letting units and associated works, by reason of the location of the site in the open countryside, divorced from nearby services, facilities and amenities would represent an unsustainable form of new residential, tourism development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. The proposal therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic form of development which would promote a reliance on a private vehicle and would be harmful to the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside, neither conserving nor enhancing the scenic beauty of the area which is designated an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The development is therefore contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 84, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North West Of Angarrack Lane Angarrack Lane Connor Downs Hayle Cornwall TR27 5JF
Description: Outline Application with some matters reserved for up to forty units with associated open space
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of the application site only adjoining the built-up area of Connor Downs along its north-eastern side, with the intervisibility of the neighbouring dwellings along this boundary being partially obscured by established and mature trees and hedging, the site is not considered to be well related to the physical form of the settlement; rather, it is considered to result in the unsympathetic extension of the built form into the open countryside. Furthermore, the benefits of providing affordable housing to meet local need are not considered to outweigh this harm. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of GGP Policy 2 of the Gwinear-Gwithian Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2016 - 2030; policies 1, 2, 9 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed access along Angarrack Lane and the junction at Horsepool together with the pedestrian connectivity to services does not provide a safe access for vehicles, walkers and cyclists contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Cabin 5 Trekye Cove Sandy Road Porthtowan Cornwall TR4 8UL
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for existing use as a single dwelling house
RefusalReasons: 1 The Council does not consider that the documentation provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the applicants onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the building in question has been used as an independent, single dwelling for a continuous period in excess of four years. As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing Use is refused.

Address: 12A Fore Street Tregony Truro Cornwall TR2 5RN
Description: Resubmission of previously withdrawn application PA20/11374 for conversion and extension of redundant studio to form a single bedroom cottage
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. 2 The creation of this residential unit to the rear would alter the historic grain and pattern of development. The proposal would intensify the density of development and harm the aesthetic quality of the setting of the heritage asset to the rear, historic, narrow service area. Residential paraphernalia would exacerbate this impact. The proposal would therefore alter the historic grain and pattern of development and would harm the historic spatial development of the Tregony Conservation Area. The harm identified is not considered to be outweighed by associated public benefits and would fall contrary to Section 72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, policies 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 130 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land West Of Mens Institute Shute Hill Breage TR13 9PU
Description: Construction of a Mixture of Open Market and Affordable Housing Development, Landscaping and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is outside of the physical boundaries of the existing settlement of Breage and is therefore open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. The site has a distinctly rural character and forms part of a larger field. It also lies within the setting of the Conservation Area. The scheme is considered a poor design and the introduction of built development and day to day activity into this sensitive area would extend the built up area into the open countryside and would be harmful to the character and appearance of the countryside and the setting of the Conservation Area. The proposal is contrary to policies 2, 3, 7, 9, 12, 21, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 126, 130, 174, 197 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The scheme has not provided the necessary reports to show that reptiles would not be adversely affected and would fail to deliver the necessary 10% Biodiversity Net Gain in both linear and habitat features. It would also harm the Fal and Helford SAC due to the recreational disturbance.  The proposal is contrary to policies 2, 22 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and the European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document July 2021 and Cornwall Planning for Biodiversity and Net Gain Supplementary Planning Document October 2018. 3 The layout of the scheme due to the proposed gradients within the site, potential conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians past the existing social club and concerns over the visibility at the junction of Shute Hill and the A394 would produce a layout that could give to a substandard layout and fail to provide a safe and suitable access to the site for all users can be achieved. It would therefore be contrary to policies 12 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 A legal agreement has not been completed and therefore the proposal would not provide the proposed affordable housing in perpetuity and the necessary mitigation in the form of contributions towards education, open space and management of the Fal and Helford SAC. It would therefore be contrary to policies 2, 8, 9, 13, 22 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 57 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Silver Valley Cottage New Mills Ladock Truro Cornwall TR2 4QG
Description: Erection of 2no wooden glamping pods for use as holiday lets. Erection of composting toilet.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is in a countryside location away from the nearest settlement of Ladock which offers a range of services and facilities. It is without a safe and convenient pedestrian access or nearby bus stops thus is considered to be in an unsustainable location that will rely heavily on the private car for access to services. The above neutral aspects in terms of design and the beneficial aspects to the tourist economy do not outweigh the identified harm due to the unsustainable location in terms of accessibility and environmental harm due to the increase use of the domestic vehicle, and as such the proposal is considered contrary to Policies 1,3, 5, 7 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Pan and paragraphs 84 and 85 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.  2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Lakenheath Carwin Lane Angarrack Hayle Cornwall TR27 5JB
Description: Construction of extension to building with the inclusion of a balcony on the south west elevation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed part single and mostly two storey rear extension, a boundary development, would create an overbearing sense of enclosure to the detriment of the occupants of the neighbouring property also creating additional over shadowing and loss of light. The use of the front balcony would raise concerns relating to the impact upon the occupiers of neighbouring property through overlooking that are not balanced by other factors acting in the public interest. The proposal therefore is contrary to Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan and Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The design of the resulting proposed development by reason of its front balcony and flat roof rear extension would result in a prominent building at odds with its immediate surrounding of traditional bungalows and houses, located within the village of Angarrack. The modern balcony and flat roof rear extension would fail to respect the aesthetic understanding of its location. The design would neither conserve nor enhance the area. The proposal, therefore, is contrary to policies 2, and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 126, 130 and 133, of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of Kitts Farm Stratton Bude Cornwall EX23 9NR
Description: Proposed eco lodge
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling, by reason of its location outside of any defined settlement extends the built form into the countryside eroding the character and appearance of landscape designated as an Area of Great Landscape Value. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of residential development in the countryside, and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 7, 11, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016), saved Policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local Plan and the guidance contained within Planning Policy for Traveller Sites (2015).

Address: Carn Meor Coppice The Carn Black Rock Camborne Cornwall TR14 9NG
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for existing dwellinghouse completed prior to December 2013
RefusalReasons: 1 The local planning authority considers that the applicant has failed to discharge their onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the use of building, known as 'Carn Meor Coppice' as shown on submitted site location plan 1:1250 (Plan no. PA21/01489-01) received 12 February 2021, has been used as a self-contained, independent dwelling house for a period of 10 years or more, and therefore immunity from planning enforcement has not been achieved in accordance with Section 171B (3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

Address: Land West Of Wheal Alfred Road Wheal Alfred Road Hayle Cornwall TR27 5JT
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved: Residential development of up to 64 dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site excludes a strip of land along its south-west boundary, outlined in blue on submitted drawing no 2020/396/JB/01 Rev A, part of which is shown indicatively in the Hayle Growth Area - Concept Plan to provide part of the new main street serving the immediate and wider Growth Area. However, it is considered that the land is not wide enough to accommodate the main street and its necessary infrastructure, and there are serious doubts as to whether the street could be accommodated within the site area and connect successfully with any new highway infrastructure to the north, the location of which would highly likely be informed by the adjacent development to the north (ref: PA20/11368). The proposal is therefore considered to fail to ensure the delivery of a high quality, comprehensive new neighbourhood, in conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy H-UE1 of the Cornwall Site Allocations Development Plan Document and the Hayle Growth Area - Concept Plan. 2 In the absence of a geophysical survey which is required owing to the existence of a number of known heritage assets nearby, the proposal is considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 189 and 194 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a suitable mechanism to secure mitigation for the effects of the development - related specifically to affordable housing, transportation, green infrastructure, open space, employment land, education and healthcare - the proposal is considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 8, 13 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; Policy H-UE1 of the Cornwall Site Allocations Development Plan Document; and the Hayle Growth Area - Concept Plan.

Address: Land South Of Lower Lanherne Farm St Mawgan Cornwall
Description: Certificate of Lawfulness for the continued use of land and caravan for holiday use
RefusalReasons: 1 From the evidence submitted with this application, which has not been considered sufficiently precise and unambiguous to show that, on the balance of probability, the land has not been used as a holiday use, and therefore for residential purposes, for a continuous period in excess of 10 years prior to the date of this application being received. The certificate has therefore not been granted.

Address: 27 Trethiggey Crescent Quintrell Downs Cornwall TR8 4LF
Description: Outline permission with Landscaping and some matters reserved (Appearance, Access, Layout and Scale) for a 2 bed bungalow to the rear of 27 Trethiggey Cres, new crossover to A3085
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal shall introduce a new access onto the A3058, directly opposite Figgy Road junction and dedicated right turn lane. Due to the proximity of the access to this junction and the Right Turn Lane, the length of frontage to the scheme and no suitable alternative, safe and suitable access arrangements cannot be acheived. The proposal shall therefore be against the aims and intentions of Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and section 9 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development, due to the size of the site, would result in an unwelcome increase in housing densities that would fail to respond positively to local housing densities and the character of the wider area. As such, the proposal is contrary to the aims and intention of Policy 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Notter Bridge Park Notter Saltash Cornwall PL12 4RW
Description: Proposed development of twenty lodges
