The conservatory has also not been in place for four or more years.As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing development of the conservatory at Hope House is refused.

Address: The Garden House The Parade Mousehole Cornwall TR19 6PP
Description: Enlargement of existing opening to allow off road vehicle parking
RefusalReasons: 1 In proposing the loss of, and alteration to part of a strong, distinctive and a highly conspicuous feature of the street scene that is of considerable historic and local interest, the proposed works result in a harmful reduction in the characteristic enclosure in this vicinity; a material reduction in the existing visual quality of the streetscape; and failure to preserve the character and appearance of the Mousehole Conservation AreaThe proposed removal and alteration to a section of a highly significant wall and the construction of a vehicular access and associated parking is inappropriate, out of keeping and at odds with the setting. The proposal has a significant detrimental impact upon a strong and distinctive feature of the streetscape that would result in harm to the character and appearance of the Mousehole Conservation Area. The works are considered to raise design concerns that cause harm and that are not balanced by other factors acting in the public interest or benefit.The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 1, 2 (paragraphs 1a to 1d), 12 (paragraphs 1a and 1b) and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); Sections 2 (paragraph 2.1.1), 3 (paragraphs 3.1.2, 3.2.2 and 3.3.5) and 5 (paragraph 5.8.1) of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021; and paragraphs 126, 130 (paragraphs a to d), 134, 189, 197(c), 199, 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development does not accord with the local planning authority's statutory duty under section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 because it would not preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Conservation Area. 2 Due to the limited width of the unclassified road that serves the proposed vehicular access; the raised concerns relating to turning, manoeuvring and potentially reversing of vehicles up the narrow lane that exits onto the adjacent classified highway where visibility is constrained; and the vulnerability of these vehicles to collision, the proposal is considered to be detrimental to highway safety and this is not balanced by other factors acting in the public interest. The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of paragraphs 110 and 112 (a) and (c) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, and Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) 3 The proposed works would result in level changes inside the boundary wall that would cause significant damage to the roots of an adjacent Acacia tree that is one of a small number of trees within the site that remain visible from outside the garden. The proposed works would result in a detrimental impact to the provision of public amenity provided by the Acacia tree within the Mousehole Conservation Area.The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of paragraph 131 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, and Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016)

Address: Builders Store Land Rear Of Nos. 2 To 6 Southgate Street Redruth Cornwall TR15 2LU
Description: Proposed demolition of existing storage building and replacement with single dwelling and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The historic significance of the site is recognised through its inclusion within the Camborne and Redruth Mining World Heritage Site (WHS), and mining settlements and social infrastructure are recognised as one of the seven attribute types which express the Outstanding Universal Value (OUV) of the WHS mining landscape. The site in its current state, despite the alterations that have reduced its authenticity and legibility, does not significantly disrupt the character and understanding of the function of the historic miner's settlement whereby a hierarchy is established between the primary dwellings and their rear service land. The dwelling, of the design, scale, proportions and finish proposed, would fail to respond positively to the historic local character and distinctiveness in this location, appearing as a discordant feature, out of context within its immediate context; it would attract much greater attention than the existing store, thereby further reducing the primacy of the former host and adjacent dwellings and harmfully contributing to the disruption and erosion of the established hierarchy, which forms an integral part of the morphology of the historic settlement. Unjustified by any overriding public benefits, the proposed development would adversely impact upon the character and appearance of the streetscene and result in less than substantial harm to the OUV of the WHS, in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 189, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, policies P3, C2 and C9 of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020 - 2025 and the guidance within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021. 2 The proposed development, by reason of its scale, design and mass, together with its proximity to and relationship with the gardens serving neighbouring dwellings adjoining the site, would have an overbearing impact upon the said gardens, leading to an adverse sense of enclosure that would result in harm to residential amenity, in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of sufficient technical information to support the application, it has not been demonstrated that the proposed scheme for the disposal of surface water drainage is achievable so as to successfully minimise, reduce or where possible eliminate flood risk on site and in the area and avoid an increased risk of flooding elsewhere. The proposal is therefore in conflict with the aims and intentions of policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Adjacent Sunnyside Trethewell St Just In Roseland Truro Cornwall TR2 5JE
Description: Proposed open market dwelling within garden Area
RefusalReasons: 1 In the absence of any affordable housing provision or any other special circumstances to justify the dwelling in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and is contrary to the guidance contained in Policies H04 and GP3 of the Roseland Neighbourhood Development Plan May 2015 -2030, policies 1, 2, 7 and 9 of the Cornwall Local Plan and paragraphs 8 and 80 of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Pendragon Newmill Penzance Cornwall TR20 8UU
Description: Conversion of existing ancillary building to form a holiday unit
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would represent a form of unsustainable tourism development having particular regard to the accessibility of the site and its location within the open countryside. Regardless of a condition restricting the occupancy, the proposed development would introduce a new dwelling into the open countryside for which there are no special circumstances for justification. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 3, 5 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 84 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Burthallan Barns Burthallan Lane St Ives Cornwall TR26 3AB
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for proposed works to reinstate corrugated metal roof of main barn using new corrugated galvanised metal sheeting; replace roof trusses and upgrade to stronger C24 timbers with an internal substructure, or repoint and cap standing gable end with waterproof sheeting; simple maintenance consisting of removing ivy from the gable ends and then repointing the walls on the inside and the outside with traditional lime mortar where appropriate; reinstate roofs of one room cottage and tractor shed
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed external works would result in a material change to the appearance of the buildings contrary to paragraph 55 (2) (a) (ii) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.  The derelict buildings are not considered to benefit from any particular permitted development rights for this particular work. Therefore the proposed works are not lawful, and planning permission is required.

Address: Beech Cottage Common Moor Cornwall PL14 6EP
Description: Proposed two-storey extension to existing dwellinghouse.
RefusalReasons: 1 This application for the construction of an extension to the dwelling known as Beech Cottage by reason of its excessive size and incongruous form fails to take into account the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the surrounding area, being of poor design thus causing harm to the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The proposed development is therefore contrary to policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 130 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, policy 8 of the St Cleer Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020 to 2030, policies PD-P3 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2022 - 2027, Part 1 of the National Design Guide 2021 and paragraphs 4.2.2 and 4.2.5 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021.

Address: Cornwall Council Public Conveniences Callington Road Saltash Cornwall PL12 6LW
Description: Erection of one detached dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its height, design, discordant architectural form and isolated position, the proposed development would result in an incongruous and dominating form of development out of keeping with the existing character of the area causing unacceptable harm to the appearance of the wider street scene. Furthermore, due to the limited size and somewhat cramped nature of the site and scale of the proposed 4 bedroom dwelling, the scheme would represent the overdevelopment of the site. The development fails to represent good design and conflicts with policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016), paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Section 4.2.5 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021. 2 Internally, the western side of the lower ground floor level serving a bedroom would lack natural light and outlook as a result of the rising ground levels and position of windows resulting in poor quality living accommodation contrary to Policies 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and section 9.3 of the Cornwall Council Design Guide 2021.

Address: Comprigney Comprigney Hill Kenwyn Cornwall TR1 3EF
Description: Proposed conversion and extension of former stable block to form dwelling with annexe
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed loss of historic fabric, chosen design, orientation, proportions and siting of the extended parts of the proposal would harm the architectural and historic integrity of these listed structures associated with the listed property known as 'Comprigney' that would cause less than substantial harm that is not outweighed by substantial public benefit in conflict with accordance with the aims and intensions of Paragraphs 8, 130, 80, 200 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 7, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies E1 and E4 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015. 2 The proposal has not been supported by sufficient ecological surveys to demonstrate that the proposal could maintain the favourable conservation status on European protected species in conflict with accordance with the aims and intensions of Paragraphs 8, 174(d) and 180(a) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policy 23 point 3(d) of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policy E1 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015.

Address: Comprigney Comprigney Hill Kenwyn Cornwall TR1 3EF
Description: Listed Building Consent for Proposed conversion and extension of former stable block to form dwelling with annexe
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed loss of historic fabric, chosen design, orientation, proportions and siting of the extended parts of the proposal would harm the architectural and historic integrity of these listed structures associated with the listed property known as 'Comprigney' that would cause less than substantial harm that is not outweighed by substantial public benefit in conflict with accordance with the aims and intensions of Paragraphs 8, 130, 200 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 7, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies E1 and E4 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015.

Address: The Cottage Trevenen Bal Helston Cornwall TR13 0PP
Description: Application for a lawful development certificate for existing use of land as residential garden incidental to the associated dwelling house
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation provided in support of the application and having regard to other information available to the authority, the Council does not consider that the documentation provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the onus of proof for the Applicant to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability that the area of land has been continuously used for a period in excess of 10 years prior to the date of this application being received as residential garden. As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing Use is refused.

Address: Helstone House Road From Ivy Cottage To Moor Plantation Helston Water Bissoe Cornwall TR4 8TB
Description: Outline application with all matters reserved for demolition of existing building and construction of new dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, outside of any defined settlement. The proposed dwelling therefore represents unjustified and sporadic development within the open countryside with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and unsustainable traffic movements.  The proposed new dwelling, in combination with the inevitable introduction of additional domestic paraphernalia associated with an additional dwelling, in this context of the rural setting, would result in harm to the distinctive landscape character of the area and would appear incongruous within the countryside. The public benefits of the scheme are limited in providing one new dwelling to the local housing stock but this does not outweigh the identified harm. The application is not sustainable development and is considered to be contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 80, 112, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Penhellick Water Mill Access To Penhellick Water Mill St Columb Cornwall TR9 6DZ
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an existing use of a building as a domestic garden room/outbuilding.
RefusalReasons: 1 Based upon the lack of sufficiently precise and unambiguous evidence submitted in support of the application, it is not considered that the applicant has successfully discharged their onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the domestic use of the outbuilding is lawful, by virtue of the passage time, in accordance with Section 171B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). Therefore, the Certificate of Lawfulness for Existing Use cannot be granted.

Address: 24 New Street Penzance Cornwall TR18 2NE
Description: Construction of Two Storey Extension and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 By virtue of the scale and design, the proposed extension is an inappropriate, discordant and overly-dominant addition to a traditional cottage that currently remains relatively unaltered and unobtrusive in the context of the surrounding historic built environment. The proposed works materially reduce the visual quality of an iconic streetscape, and fail to preserve the character and appearance of the Penzance Conservation Area; the contribution of the host building that is afforded Group Value; and the setting of the adjacent Grade II listed building(s). The National Planning Policy Framework requires harm to be weighed against the public benefit of the proposals. In this case the harm of the proposed two storey extension has been set out above.  Although the private benefits and minor economic benefits of the extension are appreciated, the proposed works would result in less than substantial harm in relation to the Conservation Area and its setting that are not balanced by these factors or other factors acting in the public interest.The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 1, 2 (paragraphs 1a to 1d), 12 (paragraphs 1a and 1b) and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); Sections 2 (paragraph 2.1.1), 3 (paragraphs 3.1.2, 3.2.2 and 3.3.5) and 5 (paragraph 5.8.1) of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021; and paragraphs 126, 130 (paragraphs a to d), 132, 134, 189, 197(c), 199, 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development does not accord with the local planning authority's statutory duty under section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 because it would not preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Conservation Area. 2 The proposed extension, due to its design, scale and location, results in a harmful increase in overbearing, loss of light and loss of outlook in relation to the first floor terrace and living room window of the immediately adjacent neighbouring property to the northwest (23 New St / Abbey Cottage)The proposed two storey rear extension would result in a loss of outlook and loss of light in relation to the living room window, and would further result in harmful overbearing, loss of outlook and loss of sunlight/ambient light to the existing terrace. The proposed works have a detrimental impact upon the main living area and associated terrace of 23 New St / Abbey Cottage, that are currently enjoyed by users of these properties.The proposed extension would raise concerns relating to the impact upon users of the neighbouring property that are not balanced by other factors acting in the public interest.The proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 12 (paragraph 2b) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); Section 9 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021; and paragraphs 126, 130 and 132 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Rayle Farm Bridge Hill Bridge Cornwall TR16 4QP
Description: Formation of new field access onto Public Highway, removal of section of hedgebank, provision of new native hedge mix dry-stone wall.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would create a new entranceway within an established hedgerow and would create a discordant feature which would detract from the rural character of the area through the provision of a domestic looking access for which there is insufficient justification to outweigh this harm; such that the development would conflict with policies 1, 2 ,12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal has failed to demonstrate that the proposed access and visibility splay will provide suitable visibility for emerging vehicles and would not lead to adverse highway safety concerns such that the proposal will conflict with paragraphs 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North West Of Dartana Forder Cornwall PL12 4QR
Description: Outline application for the demolition of existing buildings and erection of a dwelling with all matters reserved, except means of access
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed site is located outside of the development boundary as defined by Policy RUR 2 of the Saltash Neighbourhood Development Plan. It would represent housing development in the open countryside which would not relate well to an existing settlement, would be in an unsustainable location and would harm the character of the open countryside. The proposal would not represent infill or rounding off, or a rural exceptions development, does not fall within the special circumstances listed within policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan, and would increase building density which would be out of character with the surrounding area and divorced from services and facilities. The proposal would therefore be contrary to policy RUR 2 of the Saltash Neighbourhood Development Plan and Policies 1,2, 3, 7, 9 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Polices 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016). 2 The site lies within Flood Zone 1 however insufficient information has been submitted with regard to surface water drainage for the site which lies within a Critical Drainage Area. A suitable Flood Risk Assessment that takes into account the requirements of the Critical Drainage Area has not been submitted, nor has a drainage strategy which should include; Percolation test results, Layout and Maintenance. Furthermore, by reason of the fact the access to the proposed dwelling is located within Flood Zone 3, the proposed development fails the sequential test as the provision of one new dwelling could be achieved elsewhere within the Cornwall Gateway Community Network Area at locations at lower risk from flooding. The proposed development is therefore contrary to Policy GRN4 of the Saltash Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030, Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016) and Paragraph 162 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 24A Church Lane Padstow Cornwall PL28 8AY
Description: Certificate of Lawful Development for an Existing Use for proof that 24a Church Lane (Lobcray Cottage) has been used as a residential dwelling for more than 10 years
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation and information provided in support of the application and having regard to other information available to the authority, the Local Planning Authority does not consider that the property known as Lobcray Cottage (24A Church Lane) can be considered as a separate dwelling for the purposes of section 55(3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 due to the continued existence of the doorway that provides an interconnectedness between it and 24 Church Lane. As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing Use of Lobcray Cottage (24A Church Lane) as a separate dwelling is refused.

Address: Land South East Of Wringdown Yeolmbridge Launceston Cornwall
Description: Outline application with some matters reserved (appearance and scale) for erection of 1 dwelling together with access and boundary works
RefusalReasons: 1 This proposal, by causing the loss of a tall section of stone-clad earth bank (i.e. a 'Cornish Hedge') adjacent to an historic sunken lane, and its replacement with a suburban-style stone wall with hedgerow above, would harmfully degrade local landscape character and distinctiveness.  As such the proposal conflicts with Policies 2, 12, 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2016 and Policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local Plan 1999.

Address: The Beach House Canton Street Gorran Haven Cornwall PL26 6JG
Description: Addition of external cladding.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal by means of the introduction of timber cladding which is a non-vernacular material, would fail to suitably respond to the setting of the Conservation Area. The works would fail to maintain the special character and appearance of Conservation Area and are found to conflict with the aims of policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, section 16 paragraphs 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, and the local planning authority's statutory duty under section 72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 which requires that special attention be paid to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of the conservation area. The development would result in harm to the significance of the designated heritage asset and whilst this harm may be less than substantial, there are no known public benefits associated with the scheme that would outweigh this harm.

Address: Coombe End Kingsand Torpoint Cornwall PL10 1NS
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for proposed construction of concrete base for the installation of a sealed granite above ground mausoleum in the garden of Coombe End
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal fails to meet the criteria of Part 1, Class E of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) due to the location of the site outside of the residential curtilage serving the existing dwelling and due to fact that the use of the proposed building as a mausoleum cannot be reasonably considered to be required for purposes incidental to the enjoyment of the dwelling. Therefore, planning permission is required for the proposed development.

Address: Seaward Barn Access Track To Cruder Meadow Lower Boscaswell Pendeen Cornwall TR19 7ER
Description: Construction of extensions and alterations
RefusalReasons: 1 The characterful form and proportion of the existing former agricultural chall barn which is considered a non-designated heritage asset would be lost through the addition of a two storey extension subsequently altering its relationship with its setting. The non-designated heritage asset is prominently located within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Conservation Area, Heritage Coast and World Heritage Site and the character and appearance of the existing building and the surrounding area should therefore be protected. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies AD2, AD4 and AD8 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021-2030, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies PD-P1, PD-P2 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027 and Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990. 2 In the absence of an ecological survey to identify the presence and impact on protected species, the Local Planning Authority are unable to assess whether the development would adversely impact on biodiversity and the ecological value of the site, with specific regard to protected species. The proposed development therefore fails to comply with the aims and intentions set out within Policy AD10 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021-2030, Policies 1 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended).

Address: Blue Waters Wodehouse Terrace Falmouth Cornwall TR11 3EW
Description: Addition of an extra storey to an existing bungalow
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development is considered to result in harm to the streetscene and the character of the area, including the character and appearance of the Falmouth Conservation Area, and harm to the setting of nearby listed buildings (No. 34 Wodehouse Terrace and No.s 9 and 10 Gyllyng Street), by reason of its increased height and mass compared to the existing built development on the site, and its design, including its architectural style and roof form. The harm to designated heritage assets that has been identified is not considered to be outweighed by the limited public benefits of the development. The proposed development is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Sections 16 (2) and 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies DG 2, DG 3, DG 6 and DG 7 of the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030, advice contained within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021, and paragraphs 8, 130, 189, 197, 199, 200, 202, 203 and 206 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 50 Carn Bosavern Carn Bosavern St Just Cornwall TR19 7QX
Description: Demolition and replacement of existing front and rear extensions.
RefusalReasons: 1 The extensions by reason of their design, finish, scale and bulk would significantly detract from the architectural merits of the original dwelling, rendering the architectural merits of the original building largely undetectable. The extensions would dominate the building thereby resulting in the loss of the original character and form of the dwelling which as present contributes to the character and appearance of the area. In addition, with regard to the narrow plot character of the existing terrace, the scale of the extensions represent development which appears cramped and contrived failing to demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the existing dwelling and surrounding area and the small economic gain through the construction of the extensions is not considered a benefit that outweighs the identified harm with particular regard to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB, maintain the character and distinctive landscape qualities of the Heritage Coast, preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the St Just Conservation Area and protect and conserve the significance of the St Just Mining District World Heritage Site in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies AD2 and AD4 of the St Just-in-Penwith Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030, Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies PD-P1, PD-P2 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027.  2 The extension on the east elevation protrudes from the rear to an extent which results in overbearing impacts on the neighbouring properties known as 49 and 51 Carn Bosavern. In addition, due to the pattern of the sun, the extension is considered to result in overshadowing impacts on the neighbouring property known as 49 Carn Bosavern. The extension is considered to cause significant and demonstrable harm to the living conditions of the occupiers of the neighbouring dwellings known as 49 and 51 Carn Bosavern with particular regard to overbearing and overshadowing in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of an ecological survey to identify the presence and impact on protected species, the Local Planning Authority are unable to assess whether the development would adversely impact on biodiversity and the ecological value of the site, with specific regard to protected species. The proposed development therefore fails to comply with the aims and intentions set out within Policy AD10 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021-2030, Policies 1 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended).

Address: Land West Of Cherry Tree Cottage Wheal Damsel Road Carharrack TR16 5RS Cornwall
Description: Construction of a single detached self-build dwelling with domestic garage and home office and associated to include alterations to existing vehicle access and new connection into existing foul sewer within bridleway.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is considered to be located in the countryside and not considered to represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The scheme represents an undesirable encroachment and intrusion of the built form into the open, historic countryside setting to the detriment of the character and appearance of the countryside and setting of the World Heritage Site. The proposal would therefore fail to preserve the character and special interest of the World Heritage Site, leading to harm which would not be outweighed by significant public benefit. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal represents unjustified development and would be contrary to policies 2, 3, 7, 12, 21, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, section 7.1 of the The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020-2025 and paragraphs 120, 130, 134, 194, 195, 197 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 2 In the absence of adequate ecological survey, the application fails to demonstrate that the proposal would conserve and enhance habitat and biodiversity. As such, this proposal is contrary to Policy 23(4) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) and the aims and intentions of Paragraphs 120 (b) and 174 (a) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan and Paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Head Home 7 Murtons Terrace Lanner Redruth Cornwall TR16 6HW
Description: Application for Permission in Principle for the erection of dwellings, minimum 1no. and maximum 3no.
RefusalReasons: The proposed development, by reason of its location outside of the definable limits of the settlement of Lanner, represents an undesirable form of unsustainable development within the open countryside, contrary to the Development Plan policies concerning the location of new residential development. Unjustified by any special circumstances, the proposed development would give rise to the gradual erosion and urbanisation of the open countryside, in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 6 and 7 of the Lanner Neighbourhood Plan 2016 - 2030, policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 119, 124, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development would result in the intensification of the use of an unclassified road which is constrained in width and is accessed via the A393. The proposed intensification in the use of this road would increase the likelihood of vehicles having to reverse into the A393, and the increase in vehicular trips from the site is likely to give rise to increased congestion and reversing movements within the cul-de-sac at the top of the unclassified road. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would fail to benefit from a safe and suitable access, and the development would not minimise the scope for conflicts between pedestrians, cyclists and vehicles. The proposed development therefore conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 1 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. This reason for refusal is in accordance with paragraph 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The application site falls within the zone of influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC), and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to sufficiently mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Goonzoyle Lodge Bell Lake Camborne Cornwall TR14 0JG
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for the retention of land as domestic land in association with Goonzoyle Lodge, Bell Lake, Camborne
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation and evidence provided in support of the application, and having regard to the contradictory evidence against the application and other information available to the Authority, it is considered that the applicant has not discharged their onus of proof, to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the land shown outlined in red on the submitted 1:1250 site location plan (received 10.06.2022) has been used solely and continuously for purposes incidental to the residential occupancy of the property known as Goonzoyle Lodge for a period in excess of ten years. As such, the material change of use of land is not considered to be lawful by virtue of immunity from enforcement action in accordance with Sections 171B (3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). For this reasons, the Certificate of Lawfulness application is refused.

Address: Land Adj To Polgear Villa Well Lane Perran Downs Goldsithney Penzance Cornwall TR20 9HH
Description: Erection of a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would appear cramped and contrived at odds with the established character of the area thereby representing development which fails to provide continuity with the existing built form. The surrounding area is spacious and open in character and the application site is unable to provide a plot/building ratio which is in keeping with the prevailing character of the surrounding development thereby failing to demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 12 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Lavender Cottage B3285 From Hillside To Trevellas Trevellas St Agnes Cornwall TR5 0YA
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing use of Lavender Cottage as a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The Council does not consider that the evidence provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to discharge the applicant's onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the derelict structure known as Lavender Cottage has been used as a residential dwelling for a period in excess of 10 years prior to the date of this application. The residential use of the former cottage is considered to have been abandoned and, as such, the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an existing use is refused.

Address: Potters Farm Halvasso Penryn Cornwall TR10 9BX
Description: Construction of replacement dwelling in place of previously consented conversion of former Piggery/Agricultural storage building to dwelling (PA20/00506) following catastrophic collapse of existing building during winter storms.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed new dwelling would be located within the open countryside, clearly divorced from any defined settlement with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and so be deemed unsustainable development. The proposal would also harm the distinctive character and natural beauty of the immediate area. In the absence of any affordable housing provision or any other special circumstances to justify the dwelling in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and is contrary to the guidance contained in paragraphs  8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 1, 2, 7 , 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Potters Farm Halvasso Penryn Cornwall TR10 9BX
Description: Construction of replacement dwelling in place of previously consented conversion of former Piggery/Agricultural storage building to dwelling (PA20/00506) following catastrophic collapse of existing building during winter storms.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed new dwelling would be located within the open countryside, clearly divorced from any defined settlement with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and so be deemed unsustainable development. The proposal would also harm the distinctive character and natural beauty of the immediate area. In the absence of any affordable housing provision or any other special circumstances to justify the dwelling in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and is contrary to the guidance contained in paragraphs  8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 1, 2, 7 , 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Land Northwest Of Trevarrick Cottage, Gorran, PL26 6LS
Description: Outline Planning Consent with the matter of access only for consideration, in respect of the erection of a single dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its location outside of the clearly defined settlement does not represent infill, rounding-off or fall within the definition of previously developed land and would visually extend the built form into the open countryside, eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 3, 7, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan.

Address: Kelsey West Pentire Road Crantock Cornwall TR8 5SD
Description: The Construction of a Single Replacement Dwellinghouse
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling by virtue of its scale, mass, architectural form and design results in a development that is visually prominent and dominant in the streetscene, to the detriment of the character of West Pentire and Holywell and Perranporth AGLV. It fails to demonstrate enough understanding or response to surroundings or promote local distinctiveness and conflicts with policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, PV1 of the Crantock Neighbourhood Development Plan and paragraphs 11, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal, by virtue of its proximity to the boundary and additional height of development will have an overbearing impact upon the neighbouring property Seascape and due to the scale, form and massing, would be unduly harmful to the residential amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring residence. As such, the proposal is considered to be contrary to the aims and intentions of Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030 - adopted November 2016 and Section 12, particularly paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Trevenna Skinners Bottom Redruth Cornwall TR16 5DY
Description: Continued use of land for the siting of a lodge/mobile home to be used ancillary to the host property 'Trevenna',
RefusalReasons: 1 The isolated dwelling sited within the countryside on topographically high and exposed land, fails to conserve or enhance the intrinsic landscape character and scenic beauty of the rural landscape and represents an unsustainably located dwelling without special justification whos unauthorised and future occupiers would have a high reliance on the private motor vehicle as the site is located in an area where the road network is not conducive for pedestrians and not well related to public transport links, everyday shops, services and facilities in conflict with the aspiration for sustainable development and the aims and intensions of paragraphs 8, 80, 110, 112, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 2, 3, 7, 12, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and Policies 1, 10 and 13 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019. 2 The proposal has not demonstrated through the provision of adequate site investigation information that the site is suitable for its proposed use taking account of ground conditions and any risks arising from contamination for the safety of future occupiers and is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8, 174 and 183 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Redundant Workshop At Atlantic View 56 Pentire Avenue Newquay Cornwall TR7 1PE
Description: Conversion of existing redundant workshop to form annexe accommodation with parking
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its lack of functional integration with the host, lack of amenity space, and substandard quality of internal accommodation, the proposal would provide a poor standard of residential accommodation to occupiers of the unit. The development fails to represent good design, conflicts with policies 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policy H1 of the Newquay Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019-2030 and paragraphs 130 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, and does not amount to sustainable development.

Address: Land Adjacent Awen Wheal Rose Scorrier Redruth Cornwall TR16 5DA
Description: Application for Permission in Principle for the erection of up to three dwellings.
RefusalReasons: The proposed development of three dwellings, sited on land outside of the defined village boundary of Wheal Rose within the countryside, fails to provide any element of affordable housing or conserve or enhance the landscape and scenic beauty of the rural landscape in conflict with the aims and intensions of paragraphs 8, 80, 110, 112, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 2, 3, 7, 9, 12, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and Policies 1, 2, 5 and 10 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The proposal has not demonstrated through the provision of adequate site investigation information that the site is suitable for its proposed residential use taking account of ground conditions and any risks arising from contamination for the safety of future occupiers and is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8, 174 and 183 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Rocklands Marine Drive Widemouth Bay Bude Cornwall EX23 0LZ
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for a Proposed Placement of Caravan/Log Cabin within the residential curtilage of the property for ancillary purposes
RefusalReasons: 1 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposed caravan would be used and occupied for purposes incidential to the enjoyment of the dwelling house. In the absence of such information, it is contended that the submitted floor plans, which indicate the caravan would be capable of providing fully self contained two bedroomed accomodation, would result in the creation of a separate planning unit on the site, involving the material change of use of the land for the siting of a caravan to provide a separate, independant dwelling for which planning permission would be required.

Address: Land Between Burra Wallah And Sancreed Village Hall, Sancreed, Cornwall TR20 8QT
Description: Application for outline planning permission with access for the construction of a detached open market dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside the physical boundaries of any established settlement and is therefore situated within the open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. The proposal does not represent an acceptable form of rounding off or infill as defined under Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 nor is the site considered to represent previously developed land. The proposed development would introduce a new dwelling into the open countryside for which there are no special circumstances for justification. The proposed development and associated domestic paraphernalia would neither conserve nor enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and Heritage Coast nor would it preserve the setting of the Sancreed Churchtown Conservation Area. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Bungalow King Harry Road Feock Cornwall TR3 6QJ
Description: Resubmission of PA21/04238 - Demolition of Dormer Bungalow and Construction of single replacement dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The development would result in a dwelling of significantly greater bulk and massing than that existing on site, covering a notable greater proportion of the site area, as well as proposing additional hardstanding for parking provision. The resultant impact from the greater form and scale of development would be an increased presence of development on site, creating a prominent and dominant form in the setting, negatively impacting upon the open pattern and nature of existing development apparent when travelling along the adjacent highway, while additionally competing visually and impinging upon the setting of an adjacent grade II listed heritage asset. With this in mind, the development would fundamentally alter the perception of the residential plot, harming the characteristics of the area and negatively affecting the natural qualities of the site, which lies within a designated Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The development is therefore contrary to policies 1, 2, 7, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies BIO1, HE1, LS1, LS2 and D1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017 - 2030 and paragraphs 130, 174, 176, 197 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of adequate information to inform the application in relation to the presence of bats on site, the application fails to demonstrate that the proposal would conserve and enhance biodiversity and avoid impact to protected species. As such, this proposal is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the aims and intentions of paragraphs and 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 12 Back Lane Angarrack Cornwall TR27 5JE
Description: Retrospective planning permission for the removal of existing outbuilding and shed, and replacement outbuilding and parking space.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by virtue of the size, height, bulk, and massing result in a cramped form of development on the site which is out of context. Additionally, the flat roof proposed in order to accommodate the parking space is considered to be an incongruous addition that would appear out of keeping with the surrounding area which is predominantly comprised of pitched tiled roofs. The development is therefore considered to be contrary to the aims and intensions of Policies SD5 of the Hayle Neighbourhood Development Plan, Policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, the Cornwall Design Guide 2021 and paragraphs 130 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposals result in an overbearing and intrusive form of development having an adverse effect by overshadowing and loss of outlook on neighbouring properties and resulting in poor standards of residential amenity.The height and form of proposed outbuilding, together with its massing and position directly adjacent to 10 Back Lane's northwestern boundary, is considered to create a strong sense of enclosure experienced by the occupants of 10 Back Lane. It is considered that the outbuilding would significantly reduce the levels of residential amenity enjoyed by the occupants of 10 Back Lane, with the outlook from both the garden and northeast facing ground floor habitable rooms severely impacted and resulting in unacceptable overbearing impacts. The scheme conflicts with Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 which seek, amongst other matters, to ensure new development does not adversely affect the amenity of neighbouring properties. 3 In the absence of relevant assessments or detailed drawings, it is considered that none of the submitted written material is sufficient to demonstrate that the necessary site works would not cause an unacceptable risk to the retaining wall supporting the public highway. The National Planning Policy Framework in paragraph 174 makes it clear that new development will be expected, as a matter of national planning policy, not to put existing development at unacceptable risk from, nor adversely to affect it by, land instability. There is also insufficient evidence to demonstrate that the proposed outbuilding would be adequately supported to allow vehicles to park on the roof. In these circumstances the conclusion is that the proposal as submitted would be likely to result in material harm to the stability of land both on and in the immediate vicinity of the site, and in particular in relation to the retaining wall supporting the public highway. The development is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Paragraph 174 and 183 of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Ganges Freathy Cliff Military Road Torpoint PL10 1JT
Description: To build a small porch constructed of the same material as the existing chalet i.e. block and then timber walls, tiled roof and external composite cladding to match the current chalet
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development consisting of an extension to the existing chalet will have a resultant floor area exceeding that stipulated in Saved Whitsand Bay Chalet Policy W1 of the Caradon Local Plan first alteration 2007. The proposal would, by reason of its size, siting and design be harmful to the character of the locality being an Area of Great Landscape Value and is therefore contrary to the Councils Approved Guidelines for Development Control of the Whitsand Bay Chalets 2001, Saved Policies W1 and CL9 of the Caradon Local Plan 2007 and Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Land West Of Old Blacksmiths Yard Higher Condurrow Condurrow Cornwall TR14 9AL
Description: Outline planning permission for residential development of up to four dwellings with all matters reserved, except access and layout
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is not considered to represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The scheme represents an undesirable encroachment, and intrusion of the built form into the open, historic countryside setting to the detriment of the character and appearance of the countryside and setting of the World Heritage Site. The proposal would therefore fail to preserve the character and special interest of the World Heritage Site, leading to harm which would not be outweighed by significant public benefit. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal represents unjustified development and would be contrary to policies 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 120, 130, 134, 194, 195, 197 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Land West Of Greenbank House Feock Cornwall
Description: Proposed New Dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the definable limits of the settlement of Feock and does not represent an acceptable form of infill or rounding off, as defined in Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Policy H1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030. Neither is it considered that the proposal represents development of previously developed land. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic extension of the built form into the adjoining countryside, which would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the visual qualities, scenic beauty and landscape character of this section of the South Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and the sensitive settlement edge to the village of Feock. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies H1 and LS2 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030, Policies PD-P1, PD-P2 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2022-2077 together with paragraphs 8, 80, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure the provision of a financial contribution towards mitigating recreational impacts upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, the proposal is contrary to Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraphs 55, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South West Of Castle View Cleers Roche Cornwall PL26 8ND
Description: Construction of a new detached dwelling and garage on infill site with associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site sits outside of the settlement of Cleers and would not represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The proposal would physically extend the built envelope of the nearby settlement into the adjoining countryside to the detriment of the landscape character, representing an intrusion into the undeveloped countryside.  In the absence of any functional need and evidence that the new dwelling is justified to be on the land, or any other special circumstances to justify the development as a whole in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and would be contrary to the guidance contained in Paragraphs 8, 11, 78 and 79 and Sections 5, 12 and 15 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 3 (3), 7 (4 and 5), 21(a,b,c,) and 23(2,) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and guidance contained within the Cornwall Design Guide 2021.

Address: 22 Northfield Drive Truro TR1 2BS
Description: Conversion of garage, first floor extension, single-storey front extension and alterations to the existing property at 22 Northfield Drive.
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its siting, scale, height, strident material, design and discordant architectural form the proposed extensions and alterations are incongruous in relation to the host property and causes unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the street scene. The development fails to represent good design and conflicts with policies 1, 2, and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policy E1 and E4 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 97 Market Jew Street Penzance Cornwall TR18 2LE
Description: Proposed new shop front to allow for a fire escape
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building is identified within the Penzance Conservation Area Appraisal as an unlisted building of historic interest within the historic town centre and the existing shopfront reflects the buildings older heritage. Given the historic significance of the building, the alterations to the shopfront cannot be said to preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Penzance Conservation Area nor preserve the setting of the nearby listed buildings. The proposed development would harm the character of the existing building and the character of the surrounding area, and the benefits of the proposal are not considered to outweigh the identified harm with particular regard to paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to comply with the aims and intentions set out within Sections 66 (1) and 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Nankilly Farm Probus Truro Cornwall TR2 4JG
Description: Proposed change of use of land to a mixed use of tourism (glamping) and installation of two 5m x 4.4m canvas Touareg Glamping Tents with adjoining private bathroom (WC/Shower) and basic outdoor kitchenette (sink, camping stove) facilities.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development is in a countryside location away from the nearest settlements of Tresillian and Probus which offer a range of services and facilities. The site is not considered to be in a sustainable location in respect of accessibility and represents an undesirable and sporadic form of development which would promote a reliance on private vehicles. The beneficial aspects to the tourist economy do not outweigh the identified harm due to the unsustainable location in terms of accessibility and environmental harm due to the increased use of the domestic vehicle, and as such the proposal is considered contrary to Policies 1 and 5 of the Cornwall Local Plan and paragraphs 84 and 85 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: 14 Bartlett Avenue Bude Cornwall EX23 8DT
Description: Application for a certificate of lawfulness for a proposed loft conversion.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed works will not be lawful development under this certificate and will require the benefit of planning permission. This is due to a planning restriction on the original application E1/2004/01804 which removed permitted development rights. The condition stated:'Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development Order, 1995 (or any Order revoking and re-enacting that Order) no development within Classes A-H of Part 1 and Class A of Part 2 of Schedule 2 of that Order shall be carried out without the express consent of the Local Planning Authority.

Address: Land South Of Hilton Farmhouse Marhamchurch Bude Cornwall EX23 0HE
Description: Demolition of an agricultural building, erection of a dwelling and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling, by reason of its scale and domestic appearance in an exposed countryside location, will create visually harmful built form, eroding the character and appearance of this part of the countryside. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the countryside and is contrary to Policies 1,2,3, 7, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016).

Address: Levalsa Meor Farm Levalsa Meor St Austell Cornwall PL26 6DN
Description: Three one bedroom glamping units with decking, bike storage, parking/turning area, recycling/waste area, electric vehicle charging point, associated footpaths, landscaping and underground water treatment plant.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed holiday let would not enhance the immediate setting; would not be accessible by a range of transport modes and would lead to an intensification of a residential use in the countryside where no special circumstances have been demonstrated. Consequently, the proposal is in conflict with Policies 2, 3, 5 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016. 2 The proposed development as a result of its siting, scale, materials and design will result in an incongruous addition that will harm the local undeveloped landscape. The social and economic benefits of the development do not outweigh the landscape harm. The proposed development is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North East Of Lurley Penhallick Carn Brea Redruth Cornwall TR15 3YR
Description: Application for Permission in Principle for the Construction of up to six dwellings
RefusalReasons: By reason of the location of the site, physically and visually outside of the limits of a settlement and not substantially enclosed by its urban form, the proposed development would introduce a sporadic and unsustainable form of new residential development into the open countryside. The appearance of any new development on the site would be seen as a harmful encroachment into the surrounding countryside, to which it has a greater affinity than the adjoining urban form, and would result in a loss of its distinctive rural landscape character, which is subject to special protection through its designation within Camborne and Redruth Mining District World Heritage Site (WHS). Unjustified by any overriding public benefits, this sporadic form of new residential development would result in the loss of part of the relic landscape, which contributes positively to the Outstanding Universal Value and the significance of the WHS. Further environmental harm would result through the lack of suitable pedestrian infrastructure between the site and the nearest settlement, thereby giving rise to a likely increase in the reliance on the private motor vehicle, and hence unsustainable transport movements. Ultimately, the proposed use is not suitable for its location and represents an unsustainable form of residential development, in conflict with policy 1 of Cornwall Site Allocations Development Plan Document 2019, policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 13, 21, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 119, 124, 130, 174, 189, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development would introduce residential development, a new vulnerable use, on land that is within a Critical Drainage Area and in a location designated as an Area Susceptible to Surface Water Flooding where parts of the site and immediate access is identified by Cornwall Council's Strategic Flood Risk Assessment mapping to be at risk of 1 in 30 year and 1 in 100 year surface water flood events. In the absence of sufficient technical information, the application fails to demonstrate that development would not be at risk from flooding nor that it would not result in increased risks elsewhere, and it has not been demonstrated that there are no other available sites at a lower risk of flooding in the nearby settlement. In view of this matter being fundamental to the proposed use and location of the site, the proposal is in conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1 and 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 152, 154, 159, 162, 163, 164, 165 and 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Rich Marie Wheal Vor Breage Helston Cornwall TR13 9NW
Description: Conversion and extension of existing redundant barn to single-storey dwelling with associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed works, by reason of the significant extension and alterations to the building are considered to be substantial in scale; harms the intrinsic small scale and character of the host unit and is considered to represent development far beyond a conversion. The resultant residential use would fail to conserve the character and appearance of the existing building which is of simple form and style whilst leading to a proliferation of paraphernalia and domestication that would erode the rural character and would not conserve or enhance the area which is located in open countryside outside of any settlement such that it represents an unsustainable form of development. The proposal is therefore contrary to paragraphs 8, 80 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies 1, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Land And Buildings Adj To Porthpradnack Ghost Hill Predannack Mullion St Ives Cornwall TR12 7EX
Description: Construction of a detached dwelling within the domestic grounds of Porthpradnack
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its scale, height, bulk and proximity to the shared boundary with the neighbouring property to the south west, the proposed development would have an unacceptably harmful impact on the living conditions currently enjoyed by the occupants of the property known as Westward.  The considerable mass and scale of the building in such close proximity to the shared boundary would be an oppressive form of development resulting in a harmful loss of outlook, overshadowing and overbearing influences impacting both the outside and indoor areas associated with the neighbouring property.  The development is thereby contrary to policy 12 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 ¿ 2030 and paragraph 130 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site lies within an area of potentially contaminated land due to the historic quarrying of stone in proximity to the application site. A site investigation undertaken by a competent person has not been submitted with the application to ascertain whether the site is suitable for a proposed residential end use when taking into consideration the risks associated with the identified potential contamination.  In the absence of the required assessment, the Council is unable to assess the likely effects of any potential pollution on health, living conditions and the natural environment and the proposal is therefore contrary to policies 13 and 16 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 183 and 185 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land At Eastcliff Eastcliff Porthtowan Truro Cornwall TR4 8AN
Description: Proposed construction of two detached dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the definable limits of the settlement of Porthtowan and does not represent an acceptable form of infill or rounding off, as defined in Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Policies 1 and 7 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030. Neither is it considered that the proposal represents development of previously developed land. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic extension of the built form into the adjoining countryside, which would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the landscape character of this section of the Heritage Coast and the sensitive and visually prominent settlement edge to the village of Porthtowan. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies 1, 6 and 10 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030, together with paragraphs 8, 80, 130, 174 and 178 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 Due to the topography of the land combined with the form, massing and location of the two dwellings in proximity to the neighbouring dwellings to the south, the proposed development would be overly dominant creating an oppressive sense of enclosure which would also result in unacceptable levels of overlooking from the fenestration and projecting first floor balcony/terraces in relation to the frontage windows and the external amenity areas of the existing neighbouring dwellings to the south known as 'Towan', 'Casita' and 'Pensilva'. The proposed development, by reason of the location, proximity and height of each dwelling, would appear as a discordant feature within the undeveloped rural fringe of the settlement and would cause significant and demonstrable harm to the living conditions of the occupiers of the identified neighbouring dwellings thereby failing to demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location and gives rise to overlooking and overbearing impacts upon the residential amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure the provision of a financial contribution towards mitigating recreational impacts upon the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation, the proposal is contrary to Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraphs 55, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Penmaykin Liskey Hill Crescent Perranporth Cornwall TR6 0HP
Description: Design amendments to approval PA20/08697 (for a loft conversion and rebuilding of garage) to enable the Juliette balcony to be replaced with a cantilevered balcony.
RefusalReasons: 1 The development, if approved, would give rise to a detrimental impact on the neighbouring properties to the east and west of the application site namely Chalcots and The Bungalow, by way of increase in levels of overlooking of their existing private amenity areas and the transfer of noise and disturbance from the balcony.
