The design, siting and size of the proposal leads to an incongruous feature in the roofscape and one that is considered to significantly affect the residential enjoyment of those properties, contrary to Policy 12 (1 and 2) Cornwall Local Plan 2016 and the guidance within the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 with particular regard to Section 12.

Address: Glanvilles Barn Coxpark Cornwall PL18 9AZ
Description: Erection of replacement dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would result in a new dwelling in the open countryside without special justification, with a notably more-harmful impact upon its setting than the fallback position of the extant permission for the conversion of the adjacent existing barn.Specifically, through its wider span, generous glazing, complex double-winged and multiply-dormered form, revised location set on higher ground and increased massing, the proposed dwelling would appear as a conspicuous, incongruent suburban feature in the still largely rural landscape, and it would fail to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the immediately adjacent Tamar Valley Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty in the setting of which the proposal site lies. As such the development conflicts with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016; Policies HP1 and LA1 of the Calstock Neighbourhood Development Plan; Policies 3.5.1 and 3.5.6 of the Tamar Valley AONB Management Plan 2019-2024; and the advice within paragraphs 80, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure a contribution towards the mitigation of harmful impacts resulting from the proposal, it has not been possible for the Council as Competent Authority to be able to conclude that there would be no impact on the integrity of the Tamar Estuary Special Area of Conservation and Plymouth Sound Special Protection Area (the 'European Sites') as a result of the proposed development. As such the proposal conflicts with the Habitats Directive and Policies 22 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.

Address: Land South Of Carnmeor Farm Carn Stithians Cornwall TR3 7AW
Description: Conversion, extension and associated works of hay barns to form a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of the location of the site in the open countryside, would represent new residential development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. It has not been demonstrated that the buildings are suitable for the conversion and extension as shown on the proposed plans and the buildings are not a redundant or disused building which would be considered appropriate to retain, with the conversion to residential use not conserving or leading to a site enhancement. Instead, the scheme will alter the utilitarian and functional appearance of the existing buildings which, at present, clearly relate to an open and rural landscape. The proposed extensions, addition of new openings and introduction of a new access, central building and proposed garden land with associated domestic paraphernalia will fundamentally alter the perception of the buildings in the setting, such that it will be recognised as an incongruous residential form which will harm the rural characteristics of this landscape. Given the inappropriate and unsustainable form of new housing development in the countryside, the proposed development fails to conserve or enhance the landscape character in this location. As such, it conflicts with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 80, 105, 126, 130 and 174 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Old Barn Access To Perranwell Farm Perranwell Cornwall TR4 9PB
Description: New dwelling with attached double garage
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the definable limits of the settlement of Perranwell and does not represent an acceptable form of infill or rounding off, as defined in policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. Neither is it considered that the proposal represents development of previously developed land. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic extension of the built form into the adjoining countryside, which would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Riverside Cottage Tomperrow Truro Cornwall TR3 6BE
Description: Application for Outline Planning Permission with some matters reserved for the construction of a dwelling and garage namely 'access only'.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, outside of any defined settlement. The proposed dwelling therefore represents unjustified and sporadic development within the open countryside with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and unsustainable traffic movements.  The proposed new dwelling, in combination with the erosion of the site enclosure and landscape structure through formation of the new vehicular access, in this context of the rural setting, would result in harm to the distinctive landscape character of the area and would appear incongruous within the countryside. The public benefits of the scheme are limited in providing one new dwelling to the local housing stock but this does not outweigh the identified harm. The application is not sustainable development and is considered to be contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies E1, E4, E6 and H1 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan 2015 - 2030 and paragraphs 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal, through the introduction of residential development and associated changes in the context of the existing surviving elements of the former miner's smallholding, would give rise to less than substantial harm to the significance of the World Heritage Site (WHS). The public benefits of the scheme are limited in providing one new dwelling to the local housing stock but this does not outweigh the identified harm. As such it would be contrary to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 which indicates that development within the WHS should accord with the Management Plan and that proposals that would result in harm to the authenticity and integrity of the Outstanding Universal Value should be wholly exceptional. It would also be contrary to paragraphs 202, 206 and 207 of the Framework where account should be taken to enhance or better reveal the significance of heritage assets. 3 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Penhale Dunes SAC and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 The proposed new vehicular access to serve the development would be unacceptable by reason of the constrained visibility to the north along the highway when emerging from the site, which would be exacerbated by the immediate context of the acute bend in the highway to the north further reducing the ability of approaching drivers to observe an emerging vehicle. As such the proposal would leave passing vehicles vulnerable to collision. The proposal would therefore fail to demonstrate safe and suitable access to the site, contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 97 North Roskear Road Tuckingmill Camborne Cornwall TR14 8PX
Description: Construction of self-contained annexe (retrospective)
RefusalReasons: 1 Given its scale and degree of self-containment, the proposed development is not considered to have a functional link with, nor be of a subservient scale to the principal dwelling, therefore failing to represent ancillary accommodation. The proposed development, by reason of its size and design, fails to respond positively to the local character and represents an incongruous feature within the area. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of Pax Huic Domui Kehelland Camborne Cornwall TR14 0BS
Description: Conversion of Existing Barn to Form Dwelling House and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of the location in the open countryside, would represent new residential development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. It has not been precisely demonstrated that the building is suitable for conversion and the building is not a redundant or disused building which would be considered appropriate to retain, and its conversion to residential use would not lead to a site enhancement. Instead, it will alter the functional rural character of the existing building and associated land which, at present, clearly relates both physically and visually to this open rural landscape. The residential use, introduction of domestic paraphernalia and creation of an approximately 65 metres access through an agricultural land parcel will fundamentally alter the perception of the building in the setting, such that it will be recognised as an incongruous residential form which will harm the rural characteristics of this landscape. Given the inappropriate and unsustainable form of new housing development in the countryside, the proposed development fails to enhance the landscape character in this location. As such, it conflicts with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 80, 105, 126, 130 and 174 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Higher Manhay Farm, Higher Manhay Barn Wendron Helston Cornwall TR13 0NS
Description: Extension to existing dwelling and conversion of garage to dwelling with improved accessibility.
RefusalReasons: 1 It is considered that the proposed link extension and converted garage development would increase the size of the former barn, change its proportions, increasing its width, creating a development of scale that would rival the original, in addition to giving it a domestic appearance. As a result, the property would bear little resemblance to the former agricultural building. It would not lead to an enhancement of its immediate setting. Even constructed with traditional materials it would significantly change the character of the original building as such the development is not supported. The proposal, therefore, is contrary to policies 2, 12, 13 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); and paragraphs  8, 126, 130, 134 and 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Good Life Farm Road From Zion To Junction South East Of Tremount Trevellas St Agnes Cornwall TR5 0XR
Description: Change of use of land for use for a small scale campsite (up to 6 pitches) between Easter to the end of September each calendar year and the temporary siting of moveable toilet and shower blocks
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development of the site for 6 camping pitches with associated toilet and shower blocks, by reason of its scale and location in the open countryside, divorced from nearby services, facilities and amenities, would represent unsustainable new tourism development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable, undesirable and sporadic form of development that would be harmful to the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside. The development is therefore contrary to Policies 1, 2, 5, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policies 6, 10, 13, and 19 of the St Agnes Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030, and paragraph 174(b) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Penhale Dunes SAC and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of each SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030

Address: Land North East Of Foxfields Silverwell Blackwater Cornwall TR4 8JF
Description: Proposed Conversion of Outbuilding to Dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building to which this application relates is not considered to be suitably constructed or appropriate to retain, where it has not been demonstrated the building is capable of conversion without the need for significant rebuilding and extension. Furthermore, the proposed design and introduction of a residential use on the site would not lead to an enhancement of the immediate setting, where the proposed increase in the height and massing of the building would introduce an incongruous and visually intrusive structure and where the increased domestication of the wider site would detract from the rural character of the area. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and harmful form of new residential development in the countryside and without any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 7, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016) and Paragraphs 8, 80, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Penhale Dunes SAC and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Primrose Villa Chenhale Carharrack Redruth Cornwall TR16 5RB
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for the existing use of a chalet positioned within the confines of an equestrian centre for residential use.
RefusalReasons: 1 Based upon the lack of sufficiently precise and unambiguous evidence submitted in support of the application, it is not considered that the applicant has successfully discharge their onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the residential use of the chalet is lawful by virtue of the passage time, in accordance with Section 171B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). Therefore, the Certificate of Lawfulness for Existing Use cannot be granted.

Address: Land Adj To 33 Watersmead Parc Budock Water Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5EL
Description: Single new two storey, 3 bedroom, detached dwelling in garden to side of existing house.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its form, siting and scale, would result in a discordant and dominant form of development, which fails to respond positively to the existing streetscape or add to the overall quality and visual amenities of the area. The development therefore fails to accord with policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and policy H3 of the Budock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019 - 2030. 2 The proposed development fails to provide any dedicated off-road parking spaces to serve future occupiers. Given the pressure on the availability of existing on-street parking in the vicinity, and noting the likelihood of future occupiers (given the nature and scale of the dwelling proposed) owning a private vehicle, the resultant increase in the pressure for vehicular parking in the area is considered to cause unreasonable additional disturbance to the highway network and the amenities of occupiers of existing properties in the area. The development therefore conflicts with policy 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policy H3A of the Budock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019 - 2030 and paragraphs 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework. 3 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Treworlas Farm Road From Junction South Of Lower Penhallow Farm To A3078 At Treworlas Ruan High Lanes Cornwall TR2 5LN
Description: Proposed erection of a replacement dwellinghouse and the installation of a sewage treatment plant
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed new dwelling would be located within the open countryside, clearly divorced from any defined settlement with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and so be deemed unsustainable development. The proposal would also harm the distinctive character and beauty of an area that is a designated Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. In the absence of any affordable housing provision or any other special circumstances to justify the dwelling in this context, the application is not considered to represent sustainable development and is contrary to the guidance contained in paragraphs 8, 130,174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 1, 2, 7 , 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Policies LA1, LA2, H03, H04, GP2 and GP3 of the Roseland Neighbourhood Development Plan May 2015 -2030 and the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Brickworks Trelonk Farm Ruan High Lanes Truro Cornwall TR2 5PA
Description: Alterations and extensions to existing two storey property 'Brickworks'
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would, given the substantial extensions and associated excavation into rising ground and loss and modification of the quarry wall, result in the host property which is of modest scale and vernacular design qualities, being swamped by the proposed additions and the loss of its distinctive local character through the unsympathetic bulk, scale and materials proposed. This harm would impact upon the landscape qualities and scenic beauty of the immediate area as well as the setting and appreciation of this non-designated heritage asset both individually and as part of the former quarry and its associated features. The proposal would be contrary to the aims of Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies LA1, LA2, GP2 and HO9 of the Roseland Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030 and paragraphs 8, 11, 126, 130, 174, 176, 197 and 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of any assessment information to demonstrate otherwise and when undertaking a precautionary approach, the Local Planning Authority cannot be satisfied that this scheme will not impact upon the Fal & Helford Special Area of Conservation and Upper Fal Estuary and Woods SSSI, and hence the development is inconsistent with the aims of Policy LA5 of the Roseland Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030, Policies 1 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Calamankey Farm Campsite Longdowns Penryn Cornwall TR10 9DL
Description: Application for a certificate of lawfulness for existing use: Under Section 191 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to confirm that condition 2 of planning permission W2/PA08/01056/F has been breached for a period exceeding 10 years
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the evidence submitted by the applicant and having regard to contradictory information available to the Local Planning Authority, it is not considered that the documentation provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the applicant's onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the use of Calamankey Farm Campsite Longdowns Penryn Cornwall TR10 9DL has been in breach of condition 2 imposed on decision ref. PA08/01056/F dated 13th August 2008 for a continuous period of no less than ten years beginning with the date of the alleged breach. On the basis of the contradictory evidence available to the Local Planning Authority, which make the applicant's version of events less probable in the balancing act, the Certificate of Lawfulness for Existing Use cannot be granted.

Address: Land Adj To Porthcothan Traboe St Martin Helston Cornwall TR12 6EA
Description: New dwelling in the garden of Porthcothan, Traboe.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development represents housing development outside of a main town and would not constitute the rounding off or infill of a settlement, as defined by Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 given the modest size of the hamlet and its irregular scattered pattern of dwellings such that it is within a low density straggle of dwellings. The proposal would erode the setting of the hamlet and rural characteristics through the development of built form in this location which would increase building density out of character with the prevailing settlement pattern. The development would harm the landscape and scenic beauty of the AONB and would not conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty. The proposal would conflict with the aims of Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 11, 80, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy Pd-P11  of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027.

Address: Site Adjacent To 11 Penhale View Cubert Newquay Cornwall TR8 5FW
Description: Erection of detached dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is considered an important gap in the landscape and a buffer with the countryside that allows a slow transition between the existing development and the countryside. The introduction of a dwelling on this location would diminish this important gap and bring the built form further into the countryside, to the detriment of the landscape and visual amenities of the area and contrary to Policy 1 and 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan (Strategic Policies). 2 The site now proposed for an open market dwelling formed a part of a previous development approved as a rural exception scheme, where the land take for open market housing was already above 50% of the total site area. The application site must be considered in conjunction with the adjacent site to the southeast, given that, where the splitting of a site results in two sites which are physically adjoined and access shared, the capacity and suitability of the entire developable area will be considered for the purposes of determining whether it falls above or below affordable housing thresholds. In this case, in combination with the adjoining site to the southeast, the scheme further increases the land take for open market housing and exceeds the threshold for affordable housing contributions, based on floorspace, as indicated within policy 8 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure the provision of the appropriate financial off-site contribution (in lieu of on-site provision) for affordable housing, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 6 and 8 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. 3 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 16 Chili Road Illogan Highway Cornwall TR15 3JU
Description: Construction of two new semi-detached dwellings on redundant land to the rear of 16-18 Chilli Road Illogan (amended design PA21/10970)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of it's form, siting and the relative location and shape of the plot, does not respect the established pattern, form and layout of development in the locality, and does not promote continuity with the existing built form. The development will result in a discordant, incongruous and cramped form of residential accommodation, which fails to respond positively to local character or add to the overall quality of the area. The development therefore fails to accord with policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 127 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Known As Kingfisher Meadows Tresowes Ashton TR13 9SY
Description: Outline application with all matters reserved for demolition of existing stable block to be replaced by single bungalow
RefusalReasons: 1 Due to the site's position in the countryside, beyond the established settlement limits of Tresowes, it is not well related to its physical form and its development for housing would not constitute suitable 'infill' or 'rounding off' of the settlement in this location. The site forms part of a larger parcel of land that has an agricultural use such that the site would not meet the definition of previously developed land. The development of this site would result in a harmful urban intrusion into the countryside to the detriment of the strong rural character of the location. The development therefore fails to suitably integrate with the natural environment and will result in material harm to the landscape setting of the small settlement of Tresowes. The proposal is thereby contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policy 1 in the Cornwall Site Allocations Development Plan Document 2019 and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Opposte Meadowside Farm Goonhavern Cornwall TR4 9FD
Description: Erection of two holiday letting units and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is in a countryside location outside of the settlement of Goonhavern and without a safe and convenient pedestrian access, thus, is considered to be in an unsustainable location with future occupants likely to be reliant on the private car for access to services/facilities. The benefits to the tourist economy from the modest scheme do not outweigh the harm due to the unsustainability of the location in terms of access, combined with the additional harm to the rural character of the setting through the cumulative impacts resulting from the proliferation of built development and associated domestic paraphernalia in the open countryside. The proposal is therefore contrary to Policies 5, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan and paragraphs 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Fal and Helford SAC and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of each SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: First View Lamorna Penzance TR19 6XQ
Description: Demolition of a pair of existing single-storey garage buildings and creation of a holiday letting unit in their footprint.
RefusalReasons: 1 Whilst the proposal is for a holiday dwelling which could reasonably be restricted as such by condition, it nonetheless contains all of the facilities required for day-to-day private domestic existence and as such should also be considered under relevant housing policies. Owing to the site's countryside location which is clearly divorced from the nearest 'settlement', for the purposes of Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (CLP); its poor accessibility other than by private modes of transport; and the proposal not meeting any of the exceptions for new residential development in the countryside, set out in Policy 7 of the CLP, it is considered to represent unsuitable and unsustainable residential development. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 3, 5 and 7 of the CLP; and paragraphs 8 and 84 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 Whilst the site presently contains a pair of utilitarian garage buildings which do little for the character and appearance of the area, it is considered that replacing them with a more substantial and permanent holiday dwelling with large amounts of glazing which would be a conspicuous feature when viewed from the public domain (particularly outside of daylight hours) would fail to at least conserve the landscape and scenic beauty of the surrounding Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, the protection of which should be given great weight. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraphs 8, 84, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Treswithian Farm Camborne TR14 7NN
Description: Outline Planning Permission with some matters reserved (appearance, landscaping and scale) for the construction of dwellings.
RefusalReasons: 1 The access proposed by this application is constrained by the poor visibility for users of the junction onto the adjoining road and therefore unable to demonstrate otherwise, safe and suitable access to the development for all people.REASON: In the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy 27 of the adopted Local Cornwall Plan and in accordance with paragraphs 110 and 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Rose Cottage Penpont St Mawgan Cornwall TR8 4ET
Description: Listed building consent for the proposed replacement of existing asbestos/cement fibre slate with natural slate and install appropriate flashings and terracotta ridge tiles, install breathable roofing felt and appropriate insulation. Provide dry edge slate fascias, steel/aluminium gutters and down pipes to be installed where necessary
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed removal of the existing inappropriate slate roof and its replacement with an inauthentic slate will neither preserve nor enhance the special interest of the building or the Conservation Area nor does it sustain the local distinctiveness of Cornwall. The proposed works fail to preserve the special interest, authenticity or heritage values of the Grade II Listed Building. It has not been demonstrated that there is any public benefit and as such the social and economic benefits of the proposal are not considered sufficient to outweigh the adverse environmental impact for which great weight must be given; the proposal therefore represents an unacceptable form of development.  The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030; and paragraphs 130, 134, 189, 194, 197, 199, 200, 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The works fail to accord with the Council's statutory duties under sections 16(2) and 72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 in that the Listed Building would not be preserved and there would be an adverse impact upon the character of the Conservation Area.

Address: The Stables North Hill Launceston Cornwall PL15 7PQ
Description: Proposed conversion of redundant stables for use as a one bedroom residential dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building is not considered to be suitably constructed for conversion, proven as 10 years old or greater, redundant or appropriate to retain and in the absence of suitable evidence to the contrary, is considered incapable of conversion without substantial demolition/reinforcement/rebuilding operations. The proposed development is therefore considered tantamount to the construction of a new dwelling in open countryside for which no special justification has been provided in planning terms. As such, the proposal represents sporadic, unsustainable development which would fail to enhance the immediate setting and does not accord with the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 1, 2, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, with particular reference to paragraph 80.

Address: Ferndown Praze An Beeble Camborne Cornwall TR14 0LH
Description: Erection of garage/storage building for steam engine and other collectables
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its siting, massing, bulk and scale would result in an overly dominant development within the open countryside that is harmful to the character of the area contrary to policy HT4 of the Crowan Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030, policy 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North Of Tremenhere Cottage Long Lanes St Hilary Penzance Cornwall TR20 9EF
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved for a new single storey dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is located outside of the physical boundaries of any established settlement and is therefore situated within the open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. The proposed development would introduce a new unrestricted residential dwelling into the open countryside for which there are no special circumstances or justification. The dwelling would not be in a sustainable location, having particular regard to the lack of accessibility to services and facilities available locally and would give rise to dependence of future occupants on the private motor vehicle in terms of accessing such services and facilities. The narrow linear form of the site does not demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location. The provision of a dwelling with associated access, parking, garden with associated paraphernalia would, even if extensively landscaped and with a modest dwelling of an appropriate design, change the character of the site to a more domestic appearance and suburban appearance. As a consequence, the undeveloped verdant appearance, would be unduly eroded. Furthermore, the proposal would result in the subdivision of the long narrow plot that represents a historic example of the morphology of a mining settlement that is a key attribute that expressed the Outstanding Universal Value (OUV) of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site. The proposal would sever the plot from the host dwelling resulting in backland development which would be out of keeping with the character of the area which is characterised by long rear gardens containing subservient and subordinate outbuildings which serve the associated host dwellings. The harm caused by the proposal would not be outweighed by any substantial public benefits and as such the proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 13, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, policies P3, C2 and C9 of The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020-2025 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 189 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 31 Dartmoor View Saltash PL12 6WF
Description: Two storey extension to rear elevation to form enlarged lounge, kitchen and dining room on ground floor and extended bedrooms on first floor.
RefusalReasons: 1 This application for the construction of a two-storey rear extension to 31 Dartmoor View, Saltash, by reason of the decrease in separation distances between habitable rooms of no.31 and no.49 would result in an unreasonable loss of privacy and unacceptable impact on residential amenity of the occupants of 49 Dartmoor View. The development is therefore contrary to policies 1 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 adopted November 2016, paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, policies H5, ENV2 and ENV3 of the Saltash Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030 and paragraph 9.3.6 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021.

Address: Belle Vista Hillhead Road Kergilliack Cornwall TR11 5PA
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters (appearance, landscaping, layout and scale) reserved for the demolition of an existing dwelling and construction of up to 4 replacement dwellings and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would result in the development of new unfettered open market dwellings in the open countryside, contrary to the development plan's strategy for the location of new residential development and the protection of the open countryside. The site is in an elevated and visually prominent location that is visible in multiple public views and the proposed development would result in harm to the character of the area by reason of the introduction of increased built development on the site that would result in adverse visual and landscape impacts. The site has poor pedestrian connectivity and this would increase the likelihood of occupiers of the proposed dwellings relying on the private car for accessing essential day-to-day services. The proposed development would be contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policy 1 of the Cornwall Site Allocations Development Plan Document, Policies H2 and H3 of the Budock Neighbourhood Development Plan, and paragraphs 8, 110, 112, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure the provision of a financial contribution towards mitigating recreational impacts upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, the proposal is contrary to Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraphs 55, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of an adequate Phase 2 intrusive/ground investigation report the application has failed to demonstrate that land contamination would not pose a risk to the health of the future occupiers of the development. The proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraphs 174, 183 and 184 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 The application site falls within the Falmouth and Penryn - The Praze Critical Drainage Area, which is an area that has critical drainage problems and where surface water should be restricted to reduce the risk of flooding. In the absence of an adequate Flood Risk Assessment the application has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would not result in increased surface water run-off from the site that would lead to increased flood risk to third parties and the proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraph 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 5 In the absence of an adequate ecological survey including a bat emergence survey, the application fails to demonstrate that the proposal would conserve and enhance biodiversity and avoid impact to protected species. As such, the proposal is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and the aims and intentions of paragraphs and 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: The Old Workshop Mount Hawke Skate Park Mount Hawke Cornwall TR4 8BQ
Description: Retrospective permission for the erection of a live/work unit
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed, live/work unit, is sited within the open countryside and fails to conserve or enhance the rural landscape, representing an unsustainably located residential unit for which no special justification has been provided (given the lack of any clear information to demonstrate the requirement for a live/work unit in the location), with future occupiers reliant upon the private motor vehicle, given the limited links to public transport and every-day services and facilities. The development therefore conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies 1, 10 and 15 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019 and paragraphs 8, 84 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of both the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the two SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and the ethos of European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document 2021.

Address: Land North East Of Bramwell Barn Mount Hawke Cornwall TR4 8BQ
Description: Proposed self build Live/work unit (retrospective)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed isolated live work dwelling sited within the countryside fails to conserve or enhance the landscape and scenic beauty of the rural landscape and represents and unsustainably located live work dwelling without special justification whos future occupiers would have a high reliance on the private motor vehicle as the site is not well related to public transport links, everyday shops, services and facilities in conflict with the aims and intensions of paragraphs 8, 80, 110, 112, 130, 174 and 183 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, Policies 2, 3, 5, 7, 12, 16, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan - Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and Policies 1, 10 and 15 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of both the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the two SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land West Of Rickdale Cottages Trematon Cornwall PL12 4RT
Description: Proposed change of land usage, from Agricultural to occasional leisure use for the purpose of combat gaming activities (Laser Tag and Airsoft gaming)
RefusalReasons: 1 The use of the land for commercial combat gaming activities would result in an increased intensity of use of the site and would introduce a further source of noise above and beyond that currently experienced within the peaceful countryside setting. The combination of these factors is not considered to reflect the tranquil nature of the mainly pastoral landscape and associated rural activities that are expected in this location. The proposal therefore does not conserve or improve noise levels and would result in harm to the tranquillity of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. Furthermore, insufficient information has been submitted to establish the level of harm upon the occupiers of neighbouring properties in terms of unreasonable noise and disturbance. As such the development is contrary to policies 12, 13, 16 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 130.a, 130.f and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development would not provide adequate vehicular access into the site or ample parking facilities to cater for the expected volume of visitors to the site. A passing bay has not been incorporated nor has it been demonstrated that the inter-visibility between two vehicles (entering/exiting) is sufficient to enable a vehicle to pass another internal to the site without a reversing manoeuvre onto the highway. This proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (adopted 22nd November 2016) and paragraph 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North West Of Helnoweth Farm Gulval Cornwall TR20 8YP
Description: Proposed conversion of redundant stables to residential dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is located outside the boundaries of a defined settlement and is within the open countryside. Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 sets out the special circumstances in which residential development within the open countryside will be considered acceptable. It has not been demonstrated that the building is suitably constructed for its intended residential use, nor is the building redundant, disused or a historic building that is considered appropriate to retain and would lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting. Furthermore, there is insufficient information to determine that the existing building and the proposed works would meet the requirement that the building is capable of being converted to a dwelling without substantial rebuilding operations. The application building is prominent when viewed from the road. The building reads as a simple and functional stable building that relates to the adjacent field and surrounding rural character of the area, the type of building which Is expected in a rural setting and as such does not appear out of place. The proposal works would give the building a new domestic character which would significantly alter the appearance of the building and its associated curtilage. The proposed development is not considered to lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting, which is open and rural, which would be eroded by the conversion works, associated domestic paraphernalia and subdivision of the open field to the north and east of the application building and as such would have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area. It is therefore concluded that the proposal would not accord with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Treswallock Farm St Breward Bodmin Cornwall PL30 4PL
Description: Conversion of Barn A to a two bedroom dwelling at Treswallock Farm, St Breward with associated access, parking and external works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed design of the conversion of the stone-built barn to a dwelling by virtue of the form, scale and design of the proposed extension fails to preserve the character and appearance of the existing building and would detract from the original proportions of the building. The extensive glazing proposed is alien in character to the existing cluster of traditional characterful buildings and will form a conspicuously uncharacterful element, which is highly domestic in character. The proposal does not lead to an enhancement of the immediate setting and is not considered to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty within the AONB, nor is it considered to sustain the setting of designated heritage assets and would not minimise light pollution in the Core Area of the Bodmin Moor International Dark Sky Landscape not maintain the dark sky and tranquility, therefore in conflict with Policies, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030) and policies PD-P1, PD-P11 and HC-P2 of The Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027. 2 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that this proposal would not result in an increase in phosphate levels which would further adversely affect the current unfavourable status of the River Camel Special Area of Conservation. In adopting a precautionary approach, the Local Planning Authority is not satisfied that the proposal will not adversely affect the integrity of this Special Area of Conservation and the application is contrary to Regulation 63 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017; Policies 1, 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030; and paragraphs 8, 11, 174, 180 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of an ecological assessment, which should include information on the existing wildlife interest of the site and adjacent land plus the possible impacts on them, the application fails to demonstrate that the proposal would conserve and enhance habitat and biodiversity. As such, this proposal is contrary to the aims and intentions of Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the aims and intentions of Section 15 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Treswallock Farm St Breward Bodmin Cornwall PL30 4PL
Description: Listed Building Consent for conversion of Barn A to a two bedroom dwelling at Treswallock Farm, St Breward with associated access, parking and external works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed design of the conversion of the stone-built barn to a dwelling by virtue of the form, scale and design of the proposed extension fails to preserve the character and appearance of the existing building and would detract from the original proportions of the building. The extensive glazing proposed is alien in character to the existing cluster of traditional characterful buildings and will form a conspicuously uncharacterful element, which is highly domestic in character. The proposal does not lead to an enhancement of the immediate setting, nor is it considered to sustain the setting of designated heritage assets, therefore in conflict with Policies, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030) and policies PD-P1, PD-P11 and HC-P2 of The Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027.

Address: Land S Of 1 Battery Terrace Mevagissey Cornwall
Description: Retrospective consent for existing raised decking area and solar panels
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing solar panels and raised concrete and gravel area, within the garden is prominent and has a detrimental negative impact upon the character and appearance of the AONB and will not preserve and enhance the character and visual aspect of the Conservation Area, the solar array introduces a significant built form onto the plot which forms a green buffer, to the detriment of the distinctive natural beauty and character of the area.  The application is, therefore, contrary to the aims of Policies 1, 2, 3, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 130 and 170 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policies D1, D6 and HC1 of the Mevagissey Neighbourhood Plan.

Address: Bosvean School Hill Shortlanesend Cornwall TR4 9DU
Description: Part retrospective: Proposed new annex building, parking space, vehicular access, gating, fencing and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its siting and design, including materials, would appear incongruous and unrelated to the host dwelling and harmful to the street scene.  The proposal therefore fails to accord with Policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies E4, E6 and E7 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan 2015 - 2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed parking area/vehicular access has constrained emerging visibility due to the new annexe building to the west and the main dwelling to the east, both buildings are built up close to the edge of the carriageway resulting in a driver exiting the parking space having to emerge the depth of the bonnet before being able to observe approaching vehicles.  Due to the emerging visbility leaving passing vehicles vulnerable to collision, the proposal fails to demonstrate safe and suitable access to the site contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Lower Barn Guesthouse Road From Trelean Vean To Rescorla St Ewe St Austell Cornwall PL26 6ET
Description: Proposed demolition of existing reception, facilities and function building and the erection of replacement reception room, and plant room, provision of additional holiday letting/owners accommodation over.
RefusalReasons: 1 The building proposed by this application, by reason of its elevated bulk, is not of appropriate scale for its location and would appear jarring in its setting to the detriment of the character of the area. The application is, therefore, contrary to policies 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 124, 126 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework.The building proposed by this application, by reason of its larger scale than the building it would replace, would provide an opportunity for weddings of larger scale on the application site than present which would result in further adverse disturbance and noise impacts to any occupiers on the surrounding neighbouring properties, including at Western Barn, the vineyard to the immediate south, Bosue Farmhouse and Hope Barn.  The application is therefore contrary to Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Land West Of West Frogwell Farm Frogwell Road Callington Cornwall PL17 7HN
Description: Temporary 3 year consent for two static caravans in connection with agricultural business
RefusalReasons: 1 In the absence of the necessary robust special justification with regards to the essential functional need for a presence on the site and the lack of compelling evidence in respect of the viability of the agricultural enterprise that such dwelling would serve, the proposal, in seeking the creation of a new dwelling (albeit temporary) in an isolated rural location outside of any clearly defined settlement would fail to accord with the Council's spatial strategy for the delivery of housing. As such it would be an unsustainable form of development which would erode the intrinsic undeveloped nature of the countryside and Area of Great Landscape Value designation, in conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and saved policy CL9 of the Caradon Local Plan first Alteration 2007.

Address: Glamping Site Ludgvan Penzance Cornwall TR20 8HQ
Description: Proposed siting of one glamping unit for short stay holiday accommodation purposes
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by virtue of its vehicular access track and extensive curtilage is considered to detract from the rural character and appearance of the existing agricultural land and surrounding landscape. The proposed development cannot be considered to represent a form of sustainable development given the identified harm to the natural environment. The proposed development fails to sustain local character and protect the natural environment in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policy LUD1 of the Ludgvan Parish Neighbourhood Plan, Policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of Cedar Grange St Marys Road St Stephens Launceston Cornwall
Description: Reserved matters submission for 30 dwellings and associated infrastructure and open space pursuant to decision APP/D0840/W/18/3199163
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed reserved matters by reason of the inclusion of two storey houses, and the majority of the proposed dwellings having three and four-bedrooms fails to be within the scope of the Outline planning permission and its associated age restriction. The scale of the dwellings fails to reflect the identified local need for 1, 1.5 and 2-bedroom residential accommodation. As such the proposed reserved matters are contrary to policies 1, 2, 2a, 6, 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and guidance contained within paragraphs 65, 66, 138, 139 and 140 of the Cornwall Housing Supplementary Planning Document February 2020. 2 The proposed reserved matters are considered to provide insufficient and poor quality public open space by reason of the proposed siting; limited useability due to topography and the proposed inclusion of SUDS feature; lack of natural surveillance; and limited accessibility given the omission of details of a safe and suitable pedestrian connection to existing development to the West of the site as secured via planning condition on the outline consent. As such the proposed Reserved Matters are considered to be contrary to policies 2.b, 12, 13 and 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and guidance contained within paragraphs 92, 93, 98 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021; paragraphs 74, 76, 77 and 140 of the Cornwall Open Space Strategy for larger Towns in Cornwall 2014; paragraphs 9.2, 9.3, 9.3.1 and 9.3.4 of Secured By Design Homes 2019; paragraph 11.2.2 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021 and paragraphs 100, 104, 105, 106 and 107 of the National Design Guide 2021.

Address: Land South Of Llanover Pink Moors St Day TR16 5NL
Description: Application for Outline Planning Permission with all matters reserved for the construction of one self build dwelling and two affordable dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is not considered to represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The site is not considered to be well related to the physical form of the settlement nor appropriate in character in accordance with Policy 9 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The site is considered to be physically and visually more connected with the countryside and therefore represent an undesirable encroachment, and intrusion of the built form into the open countryside setting to the detriment of the character and appearance of the area. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal represents unjustified development and would be contrary to policies 2, 3, 9, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 120, 130, 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 2 A Section 106 planning obligation has not been entered into to secure the necessary affordable housing. The proposal would therefore be contrary to Policies 3 and 9 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (adopted 2016) and paragraph 55 and 57 within the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan and Paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: 2 Tara Vale Crantock TR8 5SR
Description: Proposed detached annex, workspace and car port.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its siting, massing, scale and design would result in development that is harmful to the character of the area and the streetscene and would appear cramped and contrived. The development fails to represent good design and conflicts with policies 1, 2, and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development, would have an unacceptable adverse impact on the residential amenities of the occupants of neighbouring dwellings to the north in terms of overbearing, overshadowing and creating an adverse sense of enclosure and those to the south in terms of overlooking. The proposal is thus contrary Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and the aims at paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Adjacent To 75 Trelawney Avenue St Ives TR26 1BS
Description: Erection of new dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development fails to provide continuity with the existing built form by being on higher ground and offset to the rear of the existing dwellings on Trelawney Avenue. Due to the topography of the land, the proposed development is overly dominant creating a sense of enclosure which further enhances the levels of overlooking of rear elevation windows and rear garden areas of the existing dwellings on Trelawney Avenue. The proposed development, by reason of its location and height, appears as a discordant feature within the street scene thereby failing to demonstrate a cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location and gives rise to overlooking and overbearing impacts upon the residential amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policy GD1 of the St Ives Area Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030, Policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Rosecliston Tourist Park A3075 Between Junction At High Lanes To Trevemper Bridge Trevemper Newquay TR8 5JT
Description: Change of use from existing touring caravan park and agricultural field to caravan site comprising the installation of 13 timber lodges, 75 static caravans, ancillary development infrastructure and landscaping. Demolition of existing toilet blocks and associated works. Retention of existing clubhouse, swimming pool, reception building, maintenance workshop, staff accommodation, filter beds, access, landscaping features and other existing ancillary development without complying with condition 4 of decision PA18/06164 dated 10/05/2019
RefusalReasons: 1 The original planning permission reference PA18/06164 expired prior to commencement of development, thus resulting in an unimplementable Section 73 application. This application is thereby refused in accordance with Part 4 of Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, which states: This section does not apply if the previous planning permission was granted subject to a condition as to the time within which the development to which it related was to be begun and that time has expired without the development having been begun
Dev_Type: All other small scale major developments

Address: Oaklea Nanterrow Lower Tregongeeves Polgooth Cornwall PL26 7AX
Description: Retrospective alterations to single storey garage and barn into a 2 bedroom accommodation.
RefusalReasons: 1 In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it the proposal represents a sporadic form of development outside of the defined settlement boundary and therefore considered to fall within the countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 3, 7, 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Policies 1 and 2 of the St Mewan Neighbourhood Development Plan 2016-2030. 2 The proposal if granted would result in a coalescence of both sites to form one mass or whole. Whilst the site is not designated as an area of special character i.e. AONB or AGLV the development would result in a discernible change in character to the remaining undeveloped valley floor that currently exists between 'Nanterrow' and the housing development to the north. In this regard the proposal would fail to maintain the rural characteristics of the immediate area and as such would conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030.

Address: Land North East Of Wide Horizons Tresowes Hill Ashton Cornwall TR13 9SZ
Description: Construction of Dwelling House and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its layout and design which would fail to respond positively to the local character and distinctiveness in this location, coupled with its close relationship in relation to neighbouring residential development, the proposal is considered to constitute a poor quality form of development which would fail to take the opportunity for improving the character and quality of the surrounding area and the way it functions and would not conserve or enhance the Conservation Area or World Heritage Site. The public benefits of a single dwelling would not be outweighed by the harm that would be caused which is considered to be less than substantial but the benefits of the scheme do not outweigh the harm that would be caused. The proposal would therefore conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 130 and 134, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. In addition the proposal if permitted, would be contrary to the general duty of the local planning authority to consider the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character or appearance of the Conservation Area under Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Area) Act 1990. 2 By reason of its proposed siting and bulk being located in close proximity to the dwellings of Wide Horizons and Greenbank Bungalow, the proposed development is considered to unacceptably harm the outlook from, these neighbouring dwellings and lead to a sense of overlooking and overbearing. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Kerthen Gar Townshend TR27 6AQ
Description: Workshop, polytunnel and ablutions block and change of use of land to glamping facility
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would result in the creation of new tourist accommodation in the countryside due to its location beyond the defined settlement of Townshend. The site is not considered to be accessible by a range of transport modes.  The proposal would introduce various structures, i.e. shepherds huts, new workshop and toilet block, scattered throughout the site and thereby result in a proliferation of built-form in the countryside. This would result in the loss and intrinsic harm to the character and natural part of the countryside which forms part of the relic undeveloped landscape of the Tregonning and Gwinear Mining Districts of the World Heritage Site. The harm that would arise would be localised, and therefore the impact on the WHS, as a whole, would be less than substantial within the meaning of Paragraph 202 of the Framework 2021. However, less than substantial harm does not mean less than substantial weight should be afforded to this harm. Rather, as the Framework sets out, great weight should be given to the conservation of designated heritage assets. The Framework advises that less than substantial harm should be considered in a balanced manner, against any public benefits associated with the development. The public benefits of providing additional employment and tourism facilities would not outweigh the harm identified. The proposal conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 5, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 -2030, policies HLE2, HT1, EP2 and EP3 of the Crowan NDP, Policies C2 and C9 of the Cornwall and West Devon World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020 - 2025, and paragraphs 8, 84, 130 and 197 of the NPPF (2021).

Address: Little Stitch Trew Breage Helston Cornwall TR13 9NE
Description: Retention of temporary rural workers dwelling and associated agricultural development including shepherds hut, barn/shed, compost toilet, polytunnel and hardstanding together with proposed polytunnel, packing/storage shed and workshop office
RefusalReasons: 1 The application fails to demonstrate a functional requirement for an agricultural worker to live on site, nor has it been demonstrated that the rural business is financially viable to an extent that would support the justification of a new dwelling in this open countryside location. In the absence of any identified need, the development if approved would constitute a new dwelling in the countryside to the detriment of the rural and undeveloped nature of the site, contrary to the principles of sustainability embodied in policies 1, 2, 3 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Polices 2010-2030 (adopted November 2016) and Paragraph 80 (a) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application involves the construction of a new temporary workers dwelling in the countryside along with multiple buildings and structures spread across the site. The site is located within a World Heritage Site and it is considered that the proposal would result in landscape and visual harm to the area through the proliferation of the range of structures across the site. Notwithstanding the modest associated economic benefits of this proposal, they do not outweigh the unsustainable location and less than substantial harm to the natural qualities of the setting. The proposal is considered contrary to Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Polices 2010-2030 and paragraphs 130, 174, 197,199, and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 (NPPF) and The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020-2025. 3 The application has failed to provide a desktop mining search and stability assessment in respect of historic mining activity in the immediate vicinity of the site to facilitate an appropriate assessment of whether or not ground instability poses a threat to the health and safety of those working or subsequently living on the site, to establish whether or not the site is safe for human habitation. As such, it fails to accord with the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 1 and 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, with particular reference to paragraphs 8, 174, 183, 184 and 185.

Address: Land South Of Former Mill Garage Trewardreva Constantine Cornwall
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters (appearance, landscaping, layout and scale) reserved for the construction of a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of and does not relate to any established or clearly definable settlement, and therefore cannot be considered against the provisions of Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable intrusion of sporadic housing development into the open countryside, in a location which will not encourage sustainable modes of travel, with future occupiers likely to be highly dependent on a private motor vehicle. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal therefore raises direct conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8 and 80 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to adequately secure the provision of a financial contribution towards mitigating recreational impacts upon the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 55, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North Of West Langarth Farmhouse West Langarth Cornwall TR4 9AN
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved: Erection of 4 detached two storey dwellings with double garage
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would, due to being served by an unmade access track of limited width which would not promote movements either on foot or by cycle together with the associated increase in vehicular movements, result in conflict between users of the track particularly on-coming traffic whereby no or limited passing spaces would be provided. Further, the proposed development would result in residential development and associated domestic paraphernalia encroaching upon the valley bottom which is identified as a key landscape characteristic by both permitted and emerging development proposals within the wider area and which facilitates green and blue infrastructure provision to support development within the area. These aspects are both key to achieving good design and sustainable development which creates better places in which to live and work and helps make development acceptable to communities. The proposal would conflict with the aims of Policies E1, E4, E5, H1 and T3 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23, 25 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 73, 104, 110, 112, 126, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of survey(s) to demonstrate otherwise and when undertaking a precautionary approach, the Local Planning Authority cannot be satisfied that this scheme will not harm protected species, including but not limited to bats, and hence the development is inconsistent with the aims of Policies E1 and E5 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030, Policies 1 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of affordable housing, transport infrastructure, air quality impacts, education infrastructure, public open space, flood defence infrastructure, primary healthcare, police infrastructure and contributions towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Fal and Helford and Penhale Dunes SAC for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies E1, LC1, LC4 and T1 of the Truro and Kenwyn Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030, Policies 1, 2, 8, 13, 16, 22 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and guidance contained within paragraphs 55, 57, 63, 73, 92, 93, 95, 97, 98, 104, 110, 167, 174 and 186 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North Of Trewhella Villa Long Lanes St Hilary TR20 9EQ
Description: Construction of open market housing
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would have inadequate emerging visibility to the west. The land required to improve the visibility to the west of the site entrance lies outside of the application site and is not within the applicant's ownership or control. As such the applicant has failed to demonstrate a safe and suitable access for the proposed development. The proposal conflicts with the aims and intentions of Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021). 2 The application site is located within Area 3 of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site (WHS) being the Tregonning and Gwinear Mining Districts (A3i) with Trewavas (A3ii). The application is not supported by a heritage assessment with respect to the impacts of the proposal upon the WHS as a designated heritage asset of the highest significance. There is insufficient assessment of the impacts of the proposal upon the WHS as a designated heritage asset and the submitted information is not detailed enough to provide the local planning authority with a basis for assessment that would be in accordance with paragraphs 194 and 195 of the NPPF (2021) or Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Land Adj To Marazion Bypass Marazion Cornwall
Description: Construction of live/work unit on commercial land
RefusalReasons: 1 It is considered that the site is not immediately adjoining any settlement and therefore does not accord with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.
