In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development and in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policy 2 of the St Mewan Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2016 - 2030 and Policies 1, 3, 7, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: 57 St Johns Walk St Ives Cornwall TR26 2JJ
Description: Construction of ground and first floor extensions to existing dwelling to create a new dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The introduction of a new residential unit within the curtilage of the dwelling known as 57 St Johns Walk would result in a cramped and contrived form of development that would appear out of character with the existing development in the surrounding area. The proposed dwelling, by reason of its height, narrow form and pattern of fenestration is considered to be an incongruous feature that would be detrimental to the street scene. The proposed development is therefore considered to be contrary to policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, policies GD1, BE10 and BE17 of the St Ives Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The refusal of planning permission complies with paragraph 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 that development that is not well designed should be refused. 2 The proposed balcony, by reason of its position and scale, would harm the residential amenities of the neighbouring occupiers of 57 and 59 St Johns Walk with particular regard to overlooking and noise/disturbance. It would therefore conflict with policy GD1 of the St Ives Neighbourhood Plan 2015 - 2030, policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, which together seek to achieve a good standard of residential amenity by, amongst other things, ensuring that development proposals protect individuals and property from overlooking and unreasonable loss of privacy.

Address: Land Adjacent 1 Woodland Court Truro Cornwall
Description: Application for construction of an infill dwelling on vacant plot in residential location.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling would, by virtue of its scale and close proximity to the footway at Tremorvah Wood Lane, have an overbearing impact on part of Tremorvah Wood Lane and an adverse dominant presence within the streetscene to the detriment of the character of both Tremorvah Wood Lane and Woodland Court. The proposed windows at the north-west elevation will by virtue of their proximity to residential gardens at Monterey Gardens have detrimental impact on residential amenity through overlooking. The proposal conflicts with Cornwall Local Plan Policy 12 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Croeso Goonbell St Agnes Cornwall
Description: Erection of two detached dwellings (in lieu of extant approval PA18/11335 for a semi detached pair)
RefusalReasons: 1 The alternative layout for development of this site would result in the introduction of built form on Plot 2 which is located within the countryside, outside of the defined settlement boundary for St Agnes. The proposed dwelling therefore represents unjustified development that encroaches into the open countryside that is important to the landscape setting of the village of St Agnes.  The proposed new dwelling on Plot 2 in particular would appear incongruous in this context of the rural peripheral setting, resulting in harm to the distinctive landscape character of the area and the traditional morphology of the existing linear form to this section of the village. The public benefits of the scheme are limited in providing two new dwellings to the local housing stock but this does not outweigh the identified harm. The application is not sustainable development and is considered to be contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies 1, 6, 7 and 10 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030 and paragraphs 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal, through the introduction of the reconfigured residential development and associated incongruous layout changes, in the context of the existing, traditional linear grain and form of development along Goonbell within the St Agnes Mining District, would give rise to less than substantial harm to the significance of the World Heritage Site (WHS). The public benefits of the scheme are limited in providing two new dwellings to the local housing stock but this does not outweigh the identified harm. As such it would be contrary to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policy 11 of the St Agnes Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030 which indicate that development within the WHS should accord with the Management Plan and that proposals that would result in harm to the authenticity and integrity of the Outstanding Universal Value should be wholly exceptional. It would also be contrary to paragraphs 202, 206 and 207 of the National Planning Policy Framework where account should be taken to enhance or better reveal the significance of heritage assets. 3 The application site falls within the Zones of Influence of both the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Penhale Dunes SAC and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Off Carn Ros Carn Ros Lower Boscaswell Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7UF
Description: Construction of 2No. energy efficient family homes
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by virtue of its design, notably its scale and appearance, fails to reference or reinforce local distinctiveness in an area designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Heritage Coast, the Boscaswell Conservation Area and St Just Mining District World Heritage Site where new development should sustain local distinctiveness, preserve the character and appearance of the area and protect the significance of the designated assets and their setting. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the area and detract from the historic significance and whilst the harm is considered to be less than substantial, the public benefits of the proposal are not considered benefits that outweigh the identified harm with particular regard to the Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB, maintain the character and distinctive landscape qualities of the Heritage Coast, preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Boscaswell Conservation Area and protect and conserve the significance of the St Just Mining District World Heritage Site in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies AD2, AD4 and BD1 of the St Just-in-Penwith Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030, Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176, 189, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies PD-P1 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027. 2 The proposed development fails to comply with the parking requirements for dwellings with three or more bedrooms as set out within Policy BD5 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2010-2030.

Address: Police Station Dove Street St Ives Cornwall TR26 2LZ
Description: Conversion and extension of Old Police Station to form six studio apartments and three maisonettes
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed self-contained units on the ground and first floor would have not have any windows in the bedrooms or shower room. The only windows would be in the kitchen/living room on the north elevation facing onto the parking area/rear wall of the cinema. As north facing they would not receive direct sunlight, and the ground floor windows would be partially shaded by the proposed first floor balcony. The proposed design and layout of the units on the ground and first floor would result in a gloomy and oppressive living environment, thereby resulting in inadequate living conditions for future occupants. The units on the ground and first floor would not accord with the nationally described space standards the minimum gross internal floor areas. In addition, the proposed extension to the rear of the existing building, adjacent to the Trenwith Place, would be overbearing for the occupiers of Royal Cottages. The proposed development conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 12 and 13 of the CLP, paragraph 130 of the NPPF (2021) and paragraphs 9.3.2 and 9.4.2 of the Cornwall Design Guide (2021) which all seek to ensure that developments have a high standard of amenity for existing and future users.   2 The intention of the proposal seeks to retain the Art Deco building but the defining features of the buildings of this era would be lost with the introduction of a pitched roof and dormers. The introduction of the pitched roof and dormers would not respect the character and appearance of the host building. In addition, the introduction of balconies on the front faÃ§ade would add visual clutter to the principal elevation. The proposed extension on the south elevation would introduce a built-form beyond the existing and strong building line established by Nos. 2 and 32 Trenwith Place. The combination of the proposed extensions and alterations would alter the overall form, scale and appearance of the building. The sum of the alterations would result in a contrived design which would fail to add to the overall quality of the area. The proposal conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies GD1 and BE2 of the St Ives Area Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015 - 2030 and paragraph 130 of the NPPF (2021).

Address: Land West Of Pengerise Germoe TR20 9AA
Description: Construction of dwelling house and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 Due to the site's position in the countryside, beyond the established settlement limits of Germoe Crossroads, it is not well related to its physical form and its development for housing would not constitute suitable 'infill' or 'rounding off' of the settlement in this location. The development of this site would result in a harmful urban intrusion into the countryside to the detriment of the strong rural character of the location which is designated an Area of Outstanding Natural beauty. The development therefore fails to suitably integrate with the natural environment and will result in material harm to the landscape setting of the small settlement of Germoe Crossroads.  The proposal is thereby contrary to policies S1 and S3 of the Breage Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030, policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 176 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies PD-P1, PD-P2, PD-P7 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2022-2027. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land At Tencreek Farm Plymouth Road Liskeard Cornwall PL14 3PS
Description: Advertisement consent for the installation of 2no. illuminated freestanding totem signs
RefusalReasons: The proposed signs, in the absence of any approved development or use on the site, would be a proliferation of unwarranted signage on an undeveloped site, causing harm to public amenity contrary to policies 1, 2, 12 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan, paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies 4, 10 and 13 of the Menheniot Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030.

Address: Land At Tencreek Farm Plymouth Road Liskeard Cornwall PL14 3PS
Description: Advertisement consent for installation of 6no. illuminated fascia signs, 3no. illuminated booth lettering signs and 1no. illuminated digital booth screen
RefusalReasons: The proposed signs and booth screen, in the absence of any approved development or use on the site, would be a proliferation of unwarranted signage on an undeveloped site, causing harm to public amenity contrary to policies 1, 2, 12 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan, paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies 4, 10 and 13 of the Menheniot Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030.

Address: Land At Tencreek Farm Plymouth Road Liskeard Cornwall PL14 3PS
Description: Advertisement consent for 4no. illuminated freestanding signs, 2no. banner units, 1no. illuminated play land sign and 20no. dot signs
RefusalReasons: The proposed signs, in the absence of any approved development or use on the site, would be a proliferation of unwarranted signage on an undeveloped site, causing harm to public amenity contrary to policies 1, 2, 12 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan, paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies 4, 10 and 13 of the Menheniot Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030.

Address: Land Adjacent Mount Hope Old Carnon Hill Carnon Downs Cornwall
Description: Outline planning permission for residential development of up to 3 dwellings with all matters reserved, except access
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed residential development does not represent an acceptable form of rounding off or infill as defined in Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policy H1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030 because it would extend development into the countryside beyond the current built-form of Carnon Downs and by reason of its urbanising impact and extension of built development into the countryside, with visual coalescence with the adjoining North Grange Industrial Estate to the south west, which would be detrimental to the rural character and appearance of the area. The proposal has not been submitted as a rural exception scheme or a development that would comply with Policy 7 of the CLP. Therefore the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 12, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Policy H1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030 together with paragraphs 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The submitted scheme does not demonstrate safe access/egress for the proposed development with the use of the existing byways 305/1/4 and 305/1/3 which are considered unsuitable to cater for the inevitable increase in vehicle movements generated by the development by reason of the surface condition and width, and would in the opinion of the Local Planning Authority give rise to conflict with other users of the public right of way. The proposed location of this development would encourage vehicle movements in conflict with pedestrians giving rise to increased danger for all users and creating an unacceptable highway safety impact. As such the development is assessed as being in conflict with Policies 16 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policy H1 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030 and the paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan and Paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Land South East Of Harberton Rock Road St Minver Wadebridge Cornwall
Description: Provision of a tennis court and enclosure fencing to be used in conjunction with Harberton, Rock Road, St Minver
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal is sited on land which is outside of the development boundaries within the St Minver Parishes Neighbourhood Plan 2017-2030. The proposal would introduce development into the countryside eroding the site's intrinsic verdant qualities and the positive contribution it makes to landscape character and setting of the settlement. The proposal would not be considered an exceptional circumstance so would therefore conflict with Policy STMNDP 2.6 of the Neighbourhood Plan, would conflict with policies 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 12, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Pentrelew, Penarrow Road, Mylor Churchtown Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5UD
Description: Outline planning permission with some matters reserved (appearance and landscaping) for construction of single storey eco self build dwelling and garage
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of and does not relate to any established or clearly definable settlement, and therefore cannot be considered against the provisions of Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 or Policies H1 and H2 of the Mylor Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030. The proposal represents an unsustainable intrusion of sporadic housing development into the open countryside, in a location which will not encourage sustainable modes of travel, with future occupiers likely to be highly dependent on a private motor vehicle, and which would also lead to visual harm through the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment, which is designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, and is therefore a highly sensitive location. The proposed development would fail to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and therefore raises direct conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies H1, H2, L1 and L2 of the Mylor Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030, and paragraphs 8, 80, 130, 174, and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application has not demonstrated that a satisfactory visibility splay to the west for emerging drivers can be achieved and therefore the development fails to provide a safe and suitable access to the site for all people. The proposed development is considered to be contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and advice in paragraphs 8, 110 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of a financial contribution towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies 22, 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, the European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document (July 2021), and advice in paragraphs 8, 55, 57, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Redundant Barn North Of Higher Numphra Numphra St Just Penzance Cornwall TR19 7RP
Description: Conversion of barn to single dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside the physical boundaries of any established settlement and is therefore situated within the open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 sets out the special circumstances in which residential development within the open countryside will be considered acceptable. The building is not considered to be appropriate to retain and its conversion would not lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting. The application building is prominent when viewed from the public right of way that runs past the building, only 14m away and both the building and the proposed access track would be readily visible from the road. The building reads as a simple and functional block building that relates to the adjacent field and surrounding rural character of the area, the type of building which Is expected in a rural setting and as such does not appear out of place. The proposed works would give the building a new domestic character which would significantly alter the appearance of the building and its associated curtilage. The proposed development is not considered to lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting, which is open and rural, which would be eroded by the conversion works, associated domestic paraphernalia and subdivision of the field and as such would have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area. It is therefore concluded that the proposal would not accord with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies PD-P1, PD-P2, PD-P11 and PD-P18 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027, Policies AD5, AD8 and BD8 of the St Just-in-Penwith Parish Neighbourhood Plan 2021-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South West Of West Wing Cadson Manor Farm St Ive Cornwall PL17 7HW
Description: Proposed single holiday accommodation unit and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The site, in a countryside location away from any established settlement and without a safe and convenient pedestrian access to any services, facilities or public transport connections, is considered to be in an unsustainable location where tourists will wholly rely on the private vehicles for access to services. In any event, the proposed accommodation unit is tantamount to a new dwelling in the open countryside and does not accord with the housing spatial strategy of the Development Plan; not being related to any settlement, nor meeting any of the special circumstances set out within Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan. The limited benefits to the tourist economy do not outweigh the environmental harm due to the unsustainable location in terms of access, or the adverse visual impact to the rural and landscape character of the Lynher Valley Area of Great Landscape Value through the introduction of unsympathetically designed built development, erosion of the rural context and domestication of the land. The proposal is therefore contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and Saved Policy CL9 of the Caradon Local Plan First Alteration 2007. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure a contribution towards the mitigation of harmful impacts resulting from the proposal, it has not been possible for the Council, as Competent Authority, to be able to conclude that there would be no impact on the integrity of the Tamar Estuary Special Area of Conservation and Plymouth Sound Special Protection Area (the 'European Sites') as a result of the proposed development. As such the proposal conflicts with the Habitats Directive and Policies 22 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Land Rear Of Glenview Chapel Hill Bolingey Perranporth Cornwall TR6 0DQ
Description: New 2 storey, 3 bedroom detached house
RefusalReasons: 1 The introduction of a new residential unit at land to the rear of Glenview, Bolingey would result in a cramped and contrived form of development that would appear out of character with the existing development in the rural village location by virtue of its design, height, pattern of fenestration, materials and appearance. The proposed development is therefore considered to be contrary to policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The refusal of planning permission complies with paragraph 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 that development that is not well designed should be refused. 2 The tandem development would result in an undesirable relationship with the host dwelling and the neighbouring dwelling to the west, by creating a narrow, unsuitable access that leads through to the rear of the site, resulting in an increase in noise and disturbance by way of increased car journeys, affecting the residential enjoyment of these properties. This is considered contrary to Policies 1, 12 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan (Strategic Policies) and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The application site falls within the Zones of Influence of both the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and the Penhale Dunes SAC and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SACs without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 14 High Street Chacewater Truro Cornwall TR4 8LW
Description: Listed Building Consent for the replacement of four existing box-frame sash windows facing High Street
RefusalReasons: 1 The replacement of the original sliding sash, Georgian style windows with timber framed Victorian style double glazed windows would fail to enhance or preserve the features and fabric and appearance and historic character of this Grade II listed house, its historic setting or the wider Conservation Area, and the less than substantial harm caused by the proposed development would not be outweighed by any public benefits. As such the proposal conflict with Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016), Policies HE1, HE2 and HE3 of Chacewater Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030 and paragraph 202 of the 2021 National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Polgoon Farm, Manufacturing Unit Access To Polgoon Rosehill Cornwall TR20 8TE
Description: 3no. proposed live-work units comprising ground floor workspace (uses falling under classes E such as office, workshop, studio, wellbeing surgery and research) with conjoined residential accommodation
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside the physical boundaries of any established settlement and is therefore situated within the open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. The proposed development would introduce new housing development into the open countryside for which there are no special circumstances for its justification. The proposed development would also introduce new business space into the open countryside where the scale of the development is not considered appropriate and an overriding locational and business need has not been demonstrated. The proposed development fails to protect the open countryside from inappropriate development in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 84 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The outdoor amenity space which comprises a small communal garden and first-floor balcony areas is inadequate to serve the units which are capable of accommodating up to 6 occupants each. In addition, the space provided for the storage of waste, recycling and compostables is inadequate. A good residential environment is a basic requirement and given the fact that the occupants of the units are likely to spend their working time and non-working time in the same space, a good standard of amenity space is all the more important. The proposed development fails to provide a sufficient level of amenity space in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 12 and 13 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and paragraph 9.5.7 of Section 9.5 and paragraph 2.1.2 of Section 2.1 of Appendix 2 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021.

Address: Trevithal Farm Trevithal Paul Penzance Cornwall TR19 6UQ
Description: Application for Permission in Principle for the Construction of up to two dwellings
RefusalReasons: Trevithal is not a settlement and consequently the application site is in the open countryside. The proposed development would result in unjustified residential development in the open countryside. There are no shops or services within Trevithal and is not served by public transport. The nearest facilities at Paul and Mousehole are not within a particularly convenient walking distance of the application site, and although lit in places it is not consistent on the section of highway between Trevithal and Paul and there is no dedicated pedestrian footway. The development would not represent a particularly safe or attractive option for pedestrians or cyclists during hours of darkness. As such occupiers of the development would be reliant on private vehicles. The site is not previously developed land and not sustainably located. The proposal would not accord with requirements of Policies 1,2, 3, 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. The proposal would introduce residential built-form and associated domestic infrastructure and paraphernalia onto the site thereby encroaching into the countryside. This intrusion would significantly alter the character and appearance of the site. The change in character would fail to respect the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside, protect and conserve natural landscape of the county, and sustain local distinctiveness and character. The proposed development would conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan, saved policy CC5 of the Penwith Local Plan 2004, Policy PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022 - 2027 and paragraphs 174 and 177 of the NPPF (2021).

Address: Small Barn Boscaswell Road Lower Boscaswell Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7ER
Description: Extension of incidental building
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed extension brings about conspicuous change to the characteristic form of the existing field shelter thereby altering its intimate relationship with the field enclosure and surrounding landscape. The increase in scale and loss of the original faÃ§ade fundamentally alters the original form of the locally distinctive building which comprises a critical part of the character of the area thereby detracting from its historic significance and whilst the harm is considered to be less than substantial, the public benefits of the proposal are not considered benefits that outweigh the identified harm with particular regard to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB, maintain the character and distinctive landscape qualities of the Heritage Coast, preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Boscaswell Conservation Area and protect and conserve the significance of the St Just Mining District World Heritage Site in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies AD2, AD4, AD8 and BD1 of the St Just-in-Penwith Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030, Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176, 189, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policies PD-P1 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027.

Address: Cuddra Aquatics Access From Holmbush Road To Cuddra Aquatics Cuddra St Austell Cornwall PL25 3RQ
Description: Erection of 8no. residential park homes, including external terraces and internal access track
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its location outside of the clearly defined settlement does not represent infill, rounding-off or fall within the definition of previously developed land and would visually extend the built form into the open countryside eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development and in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 2, 3, 7,21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to deliver on-site open space or an off-site financial contribution to be used for the creation or improvement of open space within accessibility limits of the development as required by the Cornwall Council adopted the Open Space Strategy for Larger Towns in Cornwall 2014, and in the absence of a mechanism to collect financial contribution towards Education Infrastructure for which there is an identified need, the proposal is therefore in conflict with Policy 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030.

Address: Land East Of Suncrest Helstone Camelford Cornwall
Description: Construction of affordable-led housing development.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would constitute housing development in a rural location outside of the development boundary of the town of Camelford. The site is neither connected to nor is it proposed to provide footpaths and cycle paths into the town and as such a dependence would exist upon the private vehicle for the majority of essential journeys to access everyday services and facilities. As such the proposed development is contrary to policies 1A and 1B of the Camelford Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030. 2 The proposed development is within a rural location and would extend the built form of the settlement further out into the countryside. The proposal is not considered to be affordable housing led, as: the proposed size of the units and tenure fail to reflect the identified affordable housing need for the parish and insufficient financial viability information has been provided to demonstrate that the level of proposed open market dwellings is the minimum required to deliver the affordable housing on site. The proposal is therefore not considered to constitute Sustainable Development and would conflict with policy 1B of the Camelford Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030; Policies 1, 2, 3 and 9 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and guidance contained within paragraphs 100 - 104 of the Cornwall Housing Supplementary Planning Document 2020 and paragraphs 8 and 63 of the National Planning Policy Framework, 2021. 3 The application site is within the hydrological catchment of the River Camel which is designated as a Special Area of Conservation under the Habitat Regulations 2017. The designated site is considered to be in unfavourable condition due to high levels of phosphates. Without mitigation it has been demonstrated that the proposed development would result in additional phosphate loading. Due to the absence of any proposed detailed mitigation scheme or any mechanism to secure any such mitigation the precautionary principle must prevail in favour of nature conservation. The Local Planning Authority is not satisfied that the proposal will not adversely affect the integrity of this Special Area of Conservation and as such the development is contrary to Regulation 63 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017; Policies 1, 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030; and paragraphs 8, 180 and 185 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of on-site affordable housing for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies 1, 3 and 9 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 63 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Adjoining Riverside Close Ludgvan Penzance TR20 8EF
Description: Construction of Single Storey Holiday Accomodation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal by reason of its scale, form, design and due to the confined nature of the site fails to respond positively to the character and appearance of surrounding area and would result in a poor residential environment for future occupants. The proposal would provide a poor standard of living and amenity space both internally and externally within the constricted site and would not reflect the pattern or density of development within the surrounding area resulting in visual harm. As a result, the proposal is considered to constitute a poor-quality form of development which would have an adverse visual impact and would result in a poor residential environment for future occupants contrary to the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8 and 130 of the NPPF 2021 and Policies LUD5 and LUD7 of the Ludgvan Neighbourhood Development Plan. 2 The proposal by reason of the lack of allocated, off-road parking provisions requiring future occupants to park on the surrounding road network would cause additional congestion and highway safety issues. The application site is located on Church Hill, towards Lower Quarter where the Ludgvan Neighbourhood Plan specifically identifies the area as having an issue with lack of parking provisions. The proposed development is considered to further exacerbate this issue and as a result would conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policies LUD5 and LUD16 of the Ludgvan Neighbourhood Development Plan.

Address: Land South Of Menegwidden Cottage Tresavean Lanner Redruth Cornwall TR16 6JN
Description: PROPOSED DEMOLITION OF AGRICULTURAL BARN AND ERECTION OF DWELLINGHOUSE (FOLLOWING PREVIOUS APPROVAL UNDER CLASS Q REF: PA21/09737 8th DECEMBER 2021) NEW DRIVEWAY AND PARKING AREA.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of the location in the open countryside, would represent new residential development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. The fallback position at the site has been acknowledged along with the degree of harm which would be caused however the proposed scheme, which includes a modern dwelling, incorporation of land for garden and creation of an approximately 40 metres driveway through an agricultural land parcel along with the associated parking and turning area will fundamentally alter the perception of the building in the setting and introduce a greater level of urbanisation and domestic paraphernalia, such that it will be recognised as an incongruous residential form which will harm the rural characteristics of this landscape. Given the inappropriate and unsustainable form of new housing development in the countryside, the proposed development fails to maintain and enhance the landscape character in this location. As such, it conflicts with policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies 1, 6, 7, 18 of the Lanner Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030 and paragraphs 8, 11, 80, 105, 126, 130 and 174 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Higher Boswarthen Access Track To Mount Whistle Newbridge Cornwall TR20 8NZ
Description: Proposed extensions (reduced and revised application following withdrawn application PA21/04671).
RefusalReasons: 1 The extensions by reason of their scale and design would significantly detract from the architectural merits of the original building. The scale and contrast in appearance of the extensions impairs the attractiveness of the existing building diminishing its historic interest by drawing attention away from the original building. In addition, the level of glazing would result in substantial expanses of light spill within the West Penwith International Dark Sky Park. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the existing dwelling and surrounding area and the small economic gain through the construction of the extensions is not considered a public benefit that outweighs the identified harm with particular regard to Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the host dwelling as well as its significance as a non-designated heritage asset and would result in additional light spill in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and 203 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies PD-P1, PD-P2 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027. 2 In the absence of an ecological survey to identify the presence and impact on protected species, the Local Planning Authority are unable to assess whether the development would adversely impact on biodiversity and the ecological value of the site, with specific regard to protected species. The proposed development therefore fails to comply with the aims and intentions set out within Policies 1 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended).

Address: Land And Building At Roskorwell Roskorwell St Keverne Helston Cornwall TR12 6PR
Description: Change of use of recreational building into a holiday-let
RefusalReasons: 1 The use of the permitted recreation building as a holiday dwelling would represent unsustainable new development within the open countryside for which no special need or justification has been adequately demonstrated. The site is therefore not deemed to be an appropriate location for the expansion and upgrading of existing tourism accommodation at the site and moreover, the proposal represents a form of housing in the open countryside for which no special circumstances have been identified to justify it. Such unsustainable development in the countryside is inaccessible by a range of transport modes other than the private motor car and therefore raises direct conflict with policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and 27 in the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 80, 84, 85, 103 and 112 in the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the River Fal and Helford River Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 1 Bal-Maidens Rest Wheal Widden Bissoe Truro Cornwall TR4 8SS
Description: Construction of 4 new dwellings.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site of the proposed dwellings is outside the settlement of Bissoe and does not meet the criteria for rounding off, infill or previously developed land and is not put forward as a rural exceptions site for affordable housing thus does not accord with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan. Nor does the proposed development accord with the exceptions criteria for dwellings in the countryside set out at Policies 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030. 2 The proposed vehicle access from the C0005 has an inadequate visibility splay for emerging vehicles resulting in an access which is neither safe nor suitable. There is no convenient pedestrian footway with lighting to the bus stops and access to bus stops is along a busy road thus the proposal does not provide a safe or suitable access for all users. The proposal conflicts with Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 Policy 27 and paragraph 110(b) of the National Planning Policy Framework. 3 No assessment of the impact on ecology has been undertaken by the applicant thus the local planning authority has been unable to assess whether the proposals would have a significant impact on protected species, including European protected species, or biodiversity generally or to assess whether, if impacts exist, that they can be satisfactorily mitigated. The proposal therefore conflicts with Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraphs 174 (d) and 180 (a) of the National Planning Policy Framework. 4 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Fal and Helford Estuaries Special Area of Conservation and the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of these Special Areas of Conservation without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation Development Plan Document 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 5 The proposed development of four dwellings would, by virtue of their scale, prominent siting and design result in a suburban form out of character with the edge of settlement location and represent an unsympathetic intrusion into the countryside that harms the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside as well as failing to protect or conserve the historic landscape of the World Heritage Site. The proposal therefore conflicts with Policy 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraphs 130 (a, c), 174 (b) and 197 of the National Planning Policy Framework and conflicts with Policies P3 and C3 of the World Heritage Site Management Plan. The proposal would also result in a harmful level of overlooking of the private garden of The Cottage contrary to Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 (f) of the National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: St Cadocs Access To Treyarnon Treyarnon Padstow Cornwall PL28 8JR
Description: Part demolition and extension of existing semi-detached property incorporating new balconies and construction of garage
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of its excessive scale, discordant architectural form the proposal leads to an overdevelopment of the site and is incongruous in relation to the host property and causes unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the host property and fails to conserve or enhance the character and appearance of the surrounding Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The development fails to represent good design and conflicts with policies 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Polies and paragraphs 8, 130, 134 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and the guidance within the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027 with regard to Policy PD-P3. 2 The proposed extension, due to the large balcony on the first storey west elevation, results in an unacceptable increase in the intensity and immediacy of both the perceived and actual overlooking of the neighbouring dwelling South Tamarisk. The proposed garage, by reason of its siting, scale, height and massing results in an unacceptable overbearing impact that would be oppressive to the amenity of the neighbouring property South Tamarisk. The development fails to protect the amenities of neighbouring properties through overlooking and overbearing, and conflicts with policies 1, 2, and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Redundant Barn North Of Kenegie Home Farm Gulval Penzance Cornwall TR20 8YN
Description: Conversion of existing barn to residential dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside the physical boundaries of any established settlement and is therefore situated within the open countryside as defined under paragraph 2.33 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 sets out the special circumstances in which residential development within the open countryside will be considered acceptable. The building is not considered to be appropriate to retain and its conversion would not lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting. The building reads as a simple and functional timber outbuilding that relates to the adjacent agricultural building and surrounding rural character of the area, the type of building which Is expected in a rural setting and as such does not appear out of place. The proposed works would give the building a new domestic character which would significantly alter the appearance of the building and its associated curtilage. The proposed development is not considered to lead to an enhancement to the immediate setting, which is open and rural, which would be eroded by the conversion works, associated domestic paraphernalia and additional domestic light spill through the intensification of the use of the building and as such would have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area. It is therefore concluded that the proposal would not accord with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies PD-P1, PD-P2, PD-P11 and PD-P18 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022-2027 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of 17 Crossways Falmouth Cornwall TR11 4HQ
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved for new detached dwelling with parking
RefusalReasons: 1 The outline proposal for the erection of a dwelling would constitute an overdevelopment of this restricted site with the loss of a significant proportion of the rear garden area to the existing dwelling, which makes a significant contribution to the established character of this residential area within the town of Falmouth. The erection of a new dwelling in this location would be harmful to the character of the locality and would provide a cramped form of development with insufficient amenity space for both the proposed dwelling and the existing dwelling. Consequently, the proposal is contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policies DG 2 and DG 4 of the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2012-2030, as well as advice contained in the Sections 4.2.5 and 9.5.7 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021, and advice in paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The outline proposal for the erection of a dwelling on this restricted site would be harmful to the residential amenities of adjoining occupiers with the inevitable scale and mass of the building, together with its proximity to the party boundary with the immediate neighbours at No. 19 Crossways, having a dominating and overbearing impact on neighbouring dwellings and private amenity spaces. The residential amenities of future occupiers of the development would also be severely compromised by the proximity, elevated and overbearing nature of the existing host dwelling set immediately to the north of the site. Such an arrangement of buildings would be contrary with the aims and intentions of Policy 12 (2) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, as well as advice contained in the Section 9.5.7 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2021, and advice in paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of a financial contribution towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies 22, 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, the European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document (July 2021), and advice in paragraphs 8, 55, 57, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Adjacent To Lilac Cottage Pennys Lane Par Cornwall PL24 2SH
Description: Application for Outline Planning Permission with all matters reserved for the construction of a new dwelling house and improvements to access, landscaping and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its location outside of the clearly defined settlement does not represent infill, rounding-off or fall within the definition of previously developed land and would visually extend the built form into the open countryside, eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 3, 7 , 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The location of the site is not acceptable in terms of the risk of flooding, with particular regard to the sequential test. It therefore conflicts with Cornwall Local Plan Policies 2, 16 and 26 which collectively seek to protect people from unsafe environments and potential hazards, ensure that buildings can adapt and be resilient to climate change and require development to be sited in a manner that increases flood resilience of the area, taking account of the need to avoid areas of flood risk. For similar reasons, the proposal would also be inconsistent with the provisions in the Framework and PPG in relation to planning and flood risk.

Address: Land Adjacent To Fairfield Telegraph Hill St Day TR16 5AH
Description: Outline application for proposed construction of single dwelling with all matters reserved, except access
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is considered to be located in the countryside and not considered to represent infill or rounding off in accordance with Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The scheme represents an undesirable encroachment and intrusion of the built form into the open, historic countryside setting to the detriment of the character and appearance of the countryside and setting of the World Heritage Site. The proposal would therefore fail to preserve the character and special interest of the World Heritage Site, leading to harm which would not be outweighed by significant public benefit. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal represents unjustified development and would be contrary to policies 2, 3, 7, 12, 21, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, section 7.1 of the The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020-2025 and paragraphs 120, 130, 134, 194, 195, 197 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 2 The access proposed by this application is constrained by sub-standard visibility in both directions onto the B3298. In the absence of information to demonstrate otherwise, safe and suitable access to the development for all people is therefore not provided and the application is contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 110 and 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation and the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan and Paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Jazzrio Cabin 16 Phillack Hill Phillack Hayle Cornwall TR27 5AD
Description: Certificate of Lawfulness for the existing development and use of Jazzrio Cabin as a residential dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The documentation provided in support of the application is not sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the applicants` onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the building on the land known as Jazzrio Cabin, 16 Phillack Hill, Phillack, Hayle TR27 5AD has been used as a single dwellinghouse for a period of 10 years or more prior to the date of this application; or that the residential use of the building for a period of 10 years or more has been achieved in the past and has not subsequently been abandoned or replaced by another use; and that the building itself was capable of being used as a single dwelling house with regard to its ability to afford to those who used it the facilities ordinarily required for day-to-day private domestic existence for a continuous period of 10 years. The Council, therefore, does not consider that the residential use of the building is lawful by virtue of immunity from enforcement action under Sections 171B (3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), and refuses to grant this Certificate of Lawful Use (existing use) being applied for.

Address: Horizon Farm Bungalow Bakers Hill Tremar Cornwall PL14 6EA
Description: Hybrid planning application - Conversion of existing building into shop, meeting rooms, offices, hair and beauty salon and associated works (in full) and outline permission with all matters except access reserved for residential development and extra care facility
RefusalReasons: 1 Notwithstanding the allocation of the site within the development plan, the proposal, set in a location divorced from its nearest settlements has failed to demonstrate that it would provide safe access to and from the site for all modes of transport, particularly pedestrians and cyclists.  Furthermore, it has not been demonstrated that the additional vehicular traffic it would generate would avoid a harmfully unsafe degradation of safety levels of the road network within the parish. As such, the proposal would conflict with Policies 1, 2 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016; Policies 14, 20, 21 and 23 of Connecting Cornwall 2030, Cornwall's Local Transport Plan; Policies 21 and 24 of the St Cleer Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021; and the guidance contained within paragraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure their delivery, the proposal fails to provide: financial contributions to deliver improvements to offset increased pressure on primary health care provision; financial contributions to offset impact upon the provision of public open space; financial contributions to offset impact upon the provision of educational facilities; and contributions to mitigate against the impact of occupants upon the nearby Special Area of Conservation/ Special Protection Area. As such the proposal is contrary to Policies 22, 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.
Dev_Type: All other small scale major developments

Address: 61 Number 3 Field, Sunnyside B3247 Between Military Road And Withnoe Lane Freathy Cornwall PL10 1JP
Description: Extension to living room
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development consisting of an extension to the existing chalet will have a resultant floor area exceeding that stipulated in the saved Whitsand Bay Chalet Policy W1 of the Caradon Local Plan first alteration 2007. The proposal would, by reason of its size, siting and design be harmful to the character of the locality being an Area of Great Landscape Value and is therefore contrary to the Councils Approved Guidelines for Development Control of the Whitsand Bay Chalets 2001, saved policies CL8, CL9 and W1 of the Caradon Local Plan First Alteration 2007 and Policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: Castlematters Ltd Tinners Walk Port Pendennis Falmouth Cornwall TR11 3XZ
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing use of 2x 20ft. storage containers placed on car park
RefusalReasons: 1 The breach of condition cannot have been in place for ten years given that the relevant planning permission was issued in 2020 and there is contradictory evidence in respect of the length of time that the containers have been on site. Therefore, on the balance of probabilities, the evidence is not clear, precise and is ambiguous and the application for a Lawful Development Certificate is refused on that basis.

Address: Land North Of The Nook Morwenna Road Shop Morwenstow Cornwall
Description: Full application for the construction of five detached dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the existing built form of the settlement of Shop and represents neither infill nor rounding off of the settlement contrary to Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 to 2030. The development represents an undesirable extension and intrusion of the settlement into the adjoining countryside to the detriment of the character and appearance of the countryside.  In the absence of any affordable housing provision or any other special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and would be contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, saved policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local Plan 1999, paragragh 45 of the Cornwall Housing Supplementary Planning Document 2020 and guidance contained within paragraphs 8, 78, 130, 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development would provide in excess of 1000 sqm of floorspace, as such in the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of an affordable housing contribution for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policy 8 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 64 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Carrick Court Road From Marble Head Cottage To The Old Barn Restronguet Point Feock Cornwall TR3 6RB
Description: Demolition of existing garage and alterations and extensions to dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site is within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty which is a designated landscape afforded the highest level of protection and should be protected from harm. The proposed extension and alterations to the existing dwelling, by reason of their scale, massing,design and amount of glazing are considered to harmfully add further to the cumulative erosion of the tranquillity of the shore line and street scene, especially from light spill in the nocturnal landscape.  As such the impact on the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty would be harmful and there would be a failure to conserve the landscape and scenic beauty of the designated landscape as required by Policies 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, together with Policies D1, LS1 and LS2 of the Feock Neighbourhood Development Plan, and paragraphs 130, 134 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework and Policy SCC09.1 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan.

Address: Well Parc Hotel Dobbin Road Trevone Padstow PL28 8QN
Description: The construction of 10 new 2 storey, 3 and 4 bed holiday homes of between 90 -130 square metres including parking for 10 cars, access road, communal recycling, refuse and cycle stores and associated landscaping.
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within an undeveloped parcel of land which is outside the urban form of the settlement of Trevone. The proposed development of 10 new two storey holiday dwellings, by reason of their scale, massing and location would result in harm to the intrinsic character of the surrounding rural setting and the natural qualities of the Carnewas to Stepper Point Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. Given the lack of any overriding material considerations, the application is not sustainable development and is contrary to Policy CSP-P2, CSP-P3 and CSP-P4 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2022-2027, Policy PAD7, PAD8 and PAD19 of the Padstow Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030, Policies 1, 2, 5, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 7, 8, 80, 82, 130 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal has not sufficiently demonstrated that surface water can be appropriately managed on site and has not submitted the required level of detail. For this reason, the proposal fails to accord with Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and Paragraph 167 and 169 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land West Of The Croft Trevaunance Road St Agnes Cornwall TR5 0NB
Description: Erection of a purpose built building to accommodate a solar array of 100 panels and use of the building as a holiday letting unit
RefusalReasons: 1 The siting of the proposal to the west of existing residential curtilage and on land that is higher than the surrounding land, results in an extensive mass and form of development that would be visible from public vantage points. The benefits of the solar panels are recognised and although the holiday let would provide some limited economic benefits, the harm to the World Heritage Site and Heritage Coast is not outweighed by significant public benefits as required by Cornwall Local Plan Policy 24. The proposal is thus unacceptable and leads to a detrimental impact on the character of the countryside and the World Heritage Site without any substantial public benefit, contrary to Policies 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan (Stategic Policies). 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and it is considered that the proposal would when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affects the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, ethos of European Sites Mitigation DPD 2021 and paragraphs 8 and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: W T Warren And Son Boswedden Road St Just Cornwall TR19 7JP
Description: Partial demolition and construction of 20 dwelling houses and new estate road
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development fails to deliver the 30% target level of affordable housing as required by Policy 8 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. The submitted Viability Appraisal and Costs Appraisal is not in accordance with Government Guidance contained in the Planning Practice Guidance and paragraph 58 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021). As such the application contains insufficient evidence and justification for the scheme to deliver no affordable housing. 2 The proposed development would involve the partial retention and conversion of the existing relatively modern utilitarian buildings which do not make a positive contribution to the character and appearance of the area. There is no overriding reason to retain any of the buildings within the application site. The retention and conversion of an existing building on the site would result in a contrived design giving rise to a poor standard of amenity for future occupiers and a poor site layout. In particular, units 14 - 20, due to the orientation, single aspect and lack of direct natural ventilation into living spaces would have inadequate living conditions for future occupants. The proposed parking layout, in respect of units 1 - 5 would give rise to pedestrian and vehicle conflict thereby failing to provide a safe and suitable access to the site for all people. Although each unit would have a small provision of private amenity space the areas between the dwellings would be laid to hardstanding used for car parking. This is not considered to be an enhancement on the current appearance of the site. The proposal has failed to improve the appearance of the site by including a site specific landscaping scheme. For the reasons outlined the proposal has failed to seize the opportunity to enhance or better reveal the significance of the designated heritage assets and their setting which is impacted upon by the proposed development. The proposal in its current form would however fail to enhance this part of the AONB.The proposal conflicts with the aims and intentions of policies 2, 12, 13, 23, 24 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies BD1, BD4, BD5, AD2 and AD3 of the St Just Neighbourhood Plan, policies PD-P1, PD-P2 and PD-P11 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2022 - 2027, paragraphs 9.3.2 and 9.4.2 of the Cornwall Design Guide (2021), and paragraphs 110, 112, 130, 176, 194 and 197 of the of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The applicant has failed to submit sufficient ecology information, i.e. An Extended Phase 1 Habitat Survey and Biodiversity Gain Plan, for the local planning authority to assess the ecological impacts and enhancements associated with the development. The application fails to demonstrate that the development would not result in an adverse impact on existing features as a first principle and enable net gains. The application fails to accord with the aims and intentions of Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policy AD10 of the St Just Neighbourhood Plan and paragraphs 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021). 4 In the absence of a completed legal agreement to secure contributions relating to public open space, primary healthcare provision and education infrastructure as part of the development in line with the Council's adopted policies, it renders the development in conflict with policy 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 58 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021).

Address: Land Adj To Bosveal Durgan Mawnan Smith Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5JR
Description: Application for Outline Planning Permission with all matters reserved for demolition of existing building and proposed new residential dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of and does not relate to any established or clearly definable settlement, and therefore cannot be considered against the provisions of Policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 or Policy 1 of the Mawnan Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030 (Referendum Version January 2022). The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable intrusion of sporadic housing development into the open countryside, in a location which will not encourage sustainable modes of travel, with future occupiers likely to be highly dependent on a private motor vehicle, and which would also lead to visual harm through the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment, which is designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, and is therefore a highly sensitive location. The proposed development would fail to conserve and enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and therefore raises direct conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, Policies 1, 4 and 5 of the Mawnan Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030 (Referendum Version January 2022), and paragraphs 8, 80, 130, 174, and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of a financial contribution towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation, for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to Policies 22, 23 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, the European Sites Mitigation Supplementary Planning Document (July 2021), and advice in paragraphs 8, 55, 57, 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: South West Water Treatment Works Trewithick Lane Egloskerry Launceston Cornwall
Description: Conversion of existing water reservoir to a single dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building to which this application relates is not considered to be suitably constructed or appropriate to retain, where it has not been demonstrated the building is capable of conversion without the need for significant rebuilding or alteration. Furthermore, the proposed design and introduction of a residential use on the site would not lead to an enhancement of the immediate setting, where the development would create visually harmful built form, eroding the character and appearance of this part of the countryside which is designated as an Area of Great Landscape Value. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and harmful form of new residential development in the countryside and in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016), Saved Policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local Plan 1999 and Policies 2, 6 and 8 of the adopted St Stephens by Launceston Neighbourhood Development Plan.

Address: Tennis Courts Adj To Badham Farm Stables Trewidland St Keyne Liskeard Cornwall PL14 4RW
Description: Outline application with all matters reserved for construction of 2 no. dwellings and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed site is found in the open countryside in an unsustainable location divorced from any established settlement. The scheme does not meet any of the special circumstances listed within Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan and occupants would be predominantly reliant on private motor vehicles to access local services and facilities. The development would visually extend the built form into the open countryside, harming the character and landscape qualities of the Area of Great Landscape Value. The proposal conflicts with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12, 21 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016), Saved Policy CL9 of the Caradon Local Plan (first alteration 2007) and paragraphs 80 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure a contribution towards the mitigation of harmful impacts resulting from the proposal, it has not been possible for the Council as Competent Authority to be able to conclude that there would be no impact on the integrity of the Tamar Estuary Special Area of Conservation and Plymouth Sound Special Protection Area (the 'European Sites') as a result of the proposed development. As such the proposal conflicts with The Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017and Policies 22 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.

Address: Sunny Corner Bakers Lane Albaston PL18 9GJ
Description: Temporary siting of a residential chalet with agricultural worker tie for 3 year trial period
RefusalReasons: 1 In the absence of the necessary robust special justification with regards to the essential functional need for a presence on the site and the lack of compelling evidence in respect of the viability of the agricultural enterprise that such dwelling would serve, the proposal, in seeking the creation of a new dwelling (albeit temporary) in an isolated rural location outside of any clearly defined settlement would fail to accord with the Council's spatial strategy for the delivery of housing. As such it would be an unsustainable form of development which would fail to conserve or enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty designation, in conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and policies HP7 and LA1 of the Calstock Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030.

Address: Willow Green Cottage Threemilestone Truro Cornwall TR4 9AL
Description: Outline Planning Application with all matters reserved for up to 5 dwellings and associated access road and services within the curtilage of Willow Green Cottage.
