Description: Change of use of land for up to 6 glamping units
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would not enhance the immediate setting; would not be accessible by a range of transport modes and would lead to an intensification of a residential use in the countryside where no special circumstances have been demonstrated. Consequently, the proposal is in conflict with Policies 2, 3, 5 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016. 2 The proposed development as a result of its siting, scale, materials and design will result in a prominent and incongruous addition that will harm the landscape. The social and economic benefits of the development do not outweigh the landscape harm. The proposed development is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. policy LLNE1 of the Luxulyan Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018-2030 and paragraph 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Bridge Works Bodriggy Street Hayle Cornwall
Description: Prior Approval under Part 18 Class A Schedule 2: Removal of existing steel deck and installation of new precast concrete cill beams. Addition of a cess walkway to form a 900mm footway to be used by NR staff for maintenance.
RefusalReasons: Part 18 Class A of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 2015. Part 18 permits development that is in relation to local or private acts of parliament subject to the following conditions: (a) the development (other than the provision of or works carried out to a dam) ought to be and could reasonably be carried out elsewhere on the land; or (b) the design or external appearance of any building, bridge, aqueduct, pier or dam would injure the amenity of the neighbourhood and is reasonably capable of modification to avoid such injury. It is not considered in respect of this prior approval application that it has been adequately demonstrated that the design or external appearance of the bridge will not injure the amenities of the neighbourhood in which it is to be sited and as such planning permission for the development will be required.

Address: Jennys Rest Trewellard Hill Trewellard Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7TE
Description: Proposed Conversion of Garage and roof terrace to form self contained Annexe Accomodation
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its form and use of materials appears out of keeping with the character of the existing dwelling known as Jennys Rest and the surrounding area which is designated as a Conservation Area. The proposed development cannot be said to preserve and enhance the character and appearance of the Trewellard Conservation Area due to the lack of cultural, physical and aesthetic understanding of its location. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the surrounding area and the small economic gain through the construction of the annexe is not considered a benefit that outweighs the identified harm with particular regard to paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. In addition, the proposed development would result in an overbearing structure which would create a sense of enclosure for the occupiers of the neighbouring property known as Mandaly thereby harming the enjoyment of the existing roof terrace associated with the said property. The proposed development would give rise to harm in terms of both visual and residential amenity in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Axe Head Farm Underlane Wendron TR13 0EJ
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for existing use of a mobile home structure as a dwelling house for in excess of 4 years
RefusalReasons: 1 The evidence submitted in support of this application and the evidence in the possession of the Local Planning Authority fails to demonstrate, on the balance of probability, that the mobile home as identified on Location Plan (ref. AHF21-SLP), received on the 13th July 2021 has been sited and used as permanent residential accommodation for in excess of 10 years.

Address: Land At Brynn Mill Road From Demelza To Brynn Mill Roche St Austell Cornwall PL26 8NL
Description: Change of use of land for the siting of one caravan (shepherd hut) for use as holiday accommodation and associated works.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed holiday let would not enhance the immediate setting; would not be accessible by a range of transport modes and would lead to an intensification of a residential use in the countryside where no special circumstances have been demonstrated. Consequently, the proposal is in conflict with Policies 2, 3, 5 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016. 2 The proposed development as a result of its siting, scale, materials and design will result in a prominent and incongruous addition that will harm the local undeveloped landscape.  The social and economic benefits of the development do not outweigh the landscape harm. The proposed development is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policy G1 of the Roche Neighbourhood Development Plan 2016-2030 and paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that this proposal would not result in an increase in phosphate levels which would further adversely affect the current unfavourable status of the River Camel Special Area of Conservation. In adopting a precautionary approach, the Local Planning Authority is not satisfied that the proposal will not adversely affect the integrity of this Special Area of Conservation and the application is contrary to Regulation 63 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017; Policies 1, 2 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030; Policy G2 of the Roche Neighbourhood Development Plan 2016-2030 and paragraphs 174, 180 and 181 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South West Of Chyponds Trenear Wendron Cornwall TR13 0ER
Description: Proposed dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The site lies within Flood Zone 2 and Flood Zone 3 with the proposal relating to a more vulnerable use. The application fails to demonstrate there are no other available sites at a lower risk of flooding than the proposed site. It has not, therefore, been clearly demonstrated that the requirements of the Sequential Test have been met. Furthermore, the submitted flood risk assessment does not adequately demonstrate that the site is wholly safe from all flood sources over its lifetime, meaning the Exception Test would also not be passed in any case. The proposed development therefore conflicts with the aims and intentions of Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 162, 164 and 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposed development, as a result of the proposed form and finish, would be incompatible with the character of the immediate setting, failing to demonstrate an understanding or response to surroundings or promote local distinctiveness. Conversely, the development will result in a discordant feature causing detrimental harm to the setting, which is of historic value noting the location within a World Heritage Site. There are no public benefits sufficient to outweigh this harm. The development therefore fails to comply with policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 197 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of an adequate ecological survey, the application fails to demonstrate that the proposal would conserve and enhance biodiversity and avoid impact to protected species. As such, this proposal is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the aims and intentions of paragraphs and 174 and 180 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of 16 Castle View St Stephens Cornwall PL12 4RD
Description: Erection of Dwelling (Revision to planning approval PA18/09876 to allow for integral garage and fourth bedroom on slightly larger site.)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, by reason of its long ridge line and gabled eastern elevation, would create a new dwelling of excessive massing, resulting in a harmfully conspicuous appearance within its setting. In addition, the resulting private garden area left to the host dwelling No.16 would be of awkward shape, with impaired levels of light receivable and of limited amenity value to occupants. As such, the proposal conflicts with Policies 2,12 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Section 5.5 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2013, and paragraph 124 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Pentreath Penmarth Carnmenellis Redruth Cornwall TR16 6PJ
Description: Outline planning permission with all matters reserved: Construction of Up to Two Dwellings and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the established settlement of Penmarth and does not represent infill or rounding off as defined in policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic extension of the built form into the countryside which will lead to the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal would not provide a suitable site for housing because of the conflict with the policies of the development plan and the harm to the character and appearance of the area. In particular the proposal would conflict with Policies 1,2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 -2030 and paragraphs 11, 127, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 which seek in this respect, amongst other things, to ensure that proposals maintain and respect the special character of areas, recognising that all urban and rural landscapes, designated or undesignated, are important.

Address: Land North Of Tregulland House Tregulland Road St Clether Launceston Cornwall PL15 8QW
Description: Change of land use, for construction of a four bedroom dwelling house, with attached garage. Existing vehicular access track to carriage way.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling, by reason of the location in the open countryside and no relation to any established settlement, does not represent infill, rounding-off or make use of previously developed land within or immediately adjoining a settlement, and would visually extend the built form into the countryside, eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 3, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016). 2 In the absence of adequate information regarding the potentially contaminated land, it is not possible to assess the impact and effects on the proposed residential development in respect of the safe occupation of the building and site. Consequently the proposal is contrary to paragraphs 183 and 184 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016.

Address: Camping Site And Premises Sandway Beach Earls Drive Kingsand Torpoint Cornwall PL10 1NG
Description: Continuation of land as a private campsite for 20 tents to be sited between 1 April and 30 September each year
RefusalReasons: 1 The application has failed to demonstrate that the site is not at risk from flooding and wave action, which will be exacerbated as the effects of climate change on sea level rise and increased storminess occur. This therefore represents a significant safety risk for occupants which cannot be satisfactorily overcome through mitigation. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (adopted November 2016) and paragraphs 154, 159 and 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land East Of Edmore Park Caravan Site Edgar Road Wainhouse Corner Bude Cornwall EX23 0BJ
Description: New dwelling to replace agricultural building.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling to replace the agricultural barn is in a rural location not within or adjacent to the definable urban form of the Wainhouse Corner settlement. It does not infill, round off or use previously developed land immediately adjacent to a settlement and visually extends the built form into the open countryside further eroding the intrinsic character of the wider landscape. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposed dwelling represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the open countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 21, 23 (1) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016) and paragraphs 79 and 174(b) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Dragon's Corner Adjacent To The Entrance To Colliford Lake Park St Neot Cornwall
Description: Change of use of land for the stationing of 2 caravans for the purpose of human habitation and associated works including car parking, foul drainage, boundary treatment and retention of existing shed and poly tunnels.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would result in the stationing of two caravans for residential use in a location isolated from existing settlements, divorced from services and facilities and poorly served by public transport, which furthermore would degrade the natural beauty of the landscape of the Bodmin Moor section of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and conflict with the Council's spatial strategy for development. As such the development conflicts with Policies 2, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016 and the advice within paragraphs 80, 93(e) and 104(d) of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Old Farmhouse Lawrence Road St Agnes TR5 0XQ
Description: Application for a lawful development certificate for a proposed ground floor side extension.
RefusalReasons: 1 On the basis of the submitted documentation provided and the Local Planning Authority's own investigations, the Local Planning Authority considers that the proposed ground floor side extension at "Old Farmhouse, Lawrence Road" requires express planning consent. The site is on article 2(3) land, being within a World Heritage Site, where a side extension does not comprise permitted development due to criteria A.2(b) of Class A, Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended). Furthermore, submitted plans indicate that the side extension would, at its highest point, exceed 4 metres in height, thereby failing to accord with criteria A.1(j)(i) of the same order.

Address: Former WT Warren Bakery Premises Truthwall St Just Cornwall
Description: Demolition of commercial buildings and construction of five dwellings with associated amenity space
RefusalReasons: 1 Whilst it has been suggested that the site would be unsuitable to continue as business use due to environmental considerations, limited evidence has been submitted to adequately demonstrate this, and it is considered that a sustainably located site of this nature could quite easily accommodate a business use which is not detrimental to the amenities of the neighbouring residential properties. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with Policy 5(2) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and Policy CD3 of the emerging St Just in Penwith Neighbourhood Development Plan. 2 The proposed development by reason of the increased height of the proposed dwellings above the existing landscape structures will form prominent new additions to the settlement which is at odds with the character of the traditional built form. This introduction of unsympathetic residential development will harm the setting of Truthwall and will result in a conspicuous uncharacteristic extension to the built form which is designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The proposed development would neither conserve or enhance this designated landscape contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, policies AD1, AD2 and BD1 of the emerging St Just in Penwith Neighbourhood Development Plan and paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 57 Trefusis Road Flushing Falmouth TR11 5TZ
Description: Proposed construction of balcony to front of property.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed installation of a first floor, front balcony, by reason of its modern, unsympathetic design and materials and projecting nature fails to take account of the historic context of the application site and surrounding traditional vernacular, whilst the principle of the scheme would fail to preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Flushing Conservation Area. The development is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policy HE2 of the Flushing NDP and paragraphs 194, 199 and 200 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Grove Hotel 1 Grove Place Falmouth Cornwall TR11 4AU
Description: Listed building consent for demolition of a section of the existing low stone wall to create an opening for a new driveway and single parking space, installation of 2no low stone pillars and of a free standing electric vehicle charging point
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, involving the removal of a section of walling at Grove Hotel to access a newly formed driveway and car parking space would lead to less than substantial harm to the significance of this Grade II listed building and its historic setting within the Falmouth Conservation Area, and the harm caused by the proposed development would not be outweighed by any public benefits. As such the proposal conflicts with the aims and intentions of Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016), paragraph 202 of the 2021 National Planning Policy Framework and Policy DG 6 of the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030.

Address: Land North Of Thorn Farm Kings Hill Bude Cornwall EX23 0LU
Description: Permission in Principle for up to four new dwellings together with the provision of a pedestrian cycle link to King's Hill, Bude (resubmission of withdrawn application no. PA20/05520)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development by reason of its location is not considered within or adjacent to the settlement of Bude by reason of the intervening agricultural field and well-established hedgerow boundary and given the character of the surrounding area, the site is not considered appropriate to increase building density for residential development. The proposed development is not considered to be previously developed land due to absence of any permanent structure and part use of the site for agricultural storage. No special circumstances have been put forward in accordance with Policy 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan. Therefore the proposal is in conflict with Policies 3 and 5 of the Bude-Stratton Neighbourhood Development Plan 2016 - 2030 and Policies 3, 7 and 21 of The Cornwall Local Plan (2010-2030).

Address: Bosvathick Lodge Bosvathick Drive Constantine Falmouth Cornwall TR11 5RZ
Description: To provide an extension to allow provision of modern kitchen and bathroom to a small and listed dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed extension by reason of its substantial size, combined with its non-simplistic design and use of inappropriate external materials would lead to less than substantial harm to the significance of this Grade II listed building and its historic setting, and the harm caused by the proposed development would not be outweighed by any public benefits. As such the proposal conflicts with Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) and paragraph 202 of the 2021 National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Former Heather Vale Gilberts Coombe New Portreath Road Redruth Cornwall TR16 4HG
Description: Outline application with all reserved matters for a proposed residential development
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located at an unsustainable location outside and detached from any established settlements thereby precluding it from representing infill or rounding off as defined in policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic built form into the countryside which will lead to the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural and rural character. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal would not provide a suitable site for housing because of the conflict with the policies of the development plan and the harm to the character and appearance of the area. In particular the proposal would conflict with Policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 -2030 and paragraphs 11, 80, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 which seek in this respect, amongst other things, to ensure that proposals maintain and respect the special character of areas, recognising that all urban and rural landscapes, designated or undesignated, are important. 2 The access proposed by this application is constrained by the poor visibility and results in a sub-standard visibility to all the road users. In the absence of information to demonstrate otherwise, safe and suitable access to the development for all people is therefore not provided and the application is contrary to Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 110 and 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 1A Trevose Avenue Newquay TR7 1NJ
Description: Convert the front yard/garden into a parking space for 1 car.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development comprises the conversion of the front yard/garden into an off-road parking space for one car. Due to the lack of adequate space and restricted dimensions, accessing the space would be problematic, requiring several manoeuvres and having the potential for a parked vehicle to obstruct the adjacent pavement, the side access lane and the main access to the property. The proposal has not demonstrated safe and suitable access and conflicts with Policy H4 of the Newquay Neighourhood Development Plan 2019, Policy 2 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal would represent a poor design that would negatively affect the character and appearance of the area through the removal of the frontage wall and introduction of vehicles parked on the front yard/garden that would be incongruous to the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal is contrary to Policy D1 and H2 of the Newquay Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019, Policy 2 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North Of Higher Treglyn St Minver Wadebridge PL27 6RG
Description: Outline application with all matters reserved for proposed live/work unit
RefusalReasons: 1The site lies in open countryside for the purposes of planning and outside of a defined settlement. No overriding need has been demonstrated for a rural location. The site has no safe pedestrian route to services and facilities and would be reliant on private vehicle for some day to day needs. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this rural location, including compelling evidence of an essential need for the proposed type of accommodation in this specific location, the proposal is not sustainable development and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 80, 92, 104, 112, and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The site lies within Special Development Area E of the St Minver Neighbourhood Development Plan 2017-2030 that is allocated for business/industrial use under Policy STMNDP2.3. This development if permitted would introduce a residential use into this allocated site that would conflict with the aims and intentions of the policy to encourage economic growth in this area and potentially undermine the viability of this allocation by introducing a residential element that could result in an amenity conflict with some industrial activities and therefore prevent future development from locating on this site.

Address: Bealswood Cemetery Road Albaston PL18 9AJ
Description: Construction of five dwellings and extension to existing dwelling. (Resubmission of planning application PA20/03516)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by the reduction of the widthof the carriageway of Cemetery Road for a length of approx. 68m that would becaused by its entrance build-out, would impede two-way traffic and cause localtraffic congestion leading to a degradation of levels of highways safety.Furthermore, through its reduction of on-street parking opportunities, theproposal would cause a significantly adverse impact upon the local roadnetwork, and in turn harmful disruption to the operation of: funerals at theadjacent cemetery; the Parish archive housed in the cemetery chapel; the Parish Council's meetings in the nearby Tamar Valley AONB Centre; the operation ofthat centre itself, and the nearby Fernleigh House Children's Centre. As suchthe proposal fails to accord with Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016 andparagraphs 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal, by introducing built form into this site which lies outside their defined development boundaries, would fail to preserve the essential character of the settlement of Albaston; and fail to maintain the valued green space, openness and landscape character of the gap between Albaston and Drakewalls. As such it would conflict with the spatial strategy of the development plan and Policies HP1 and HP2 of the Calstock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan (NDP) 2020 -2030 Post-examination Submission Draft June 2021.

Address: Land North West Of Lamara Lancamshire Lane Rosudgeon Cornwall TR20 9PL
Description: Permission in Principle for proposed infill development of up to 2 dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal is considered to result in the extension of the settlement into the open countryside as opposed to infilling within its built form. Furthermore, none of the exceptions for new residential development in the countryside would be met. In addition any new vehicular access would have a detrimental impact on the existing landscape. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 3, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Concrete Batching Plant Road From Bownder An Sycamor To Creegbrawse Creegbrawse St Day TR16 5QF
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for existing use of land for the mixed use of a concrete batching plant and for the siting of a residential caravan
RefusalReasons: 1 The Council does not consider that the documentation provided in support of the application is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to successfully discharge the applicant's onus of proof to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, the entirety of the identified land in question has been used for a continuous period, in excess of 10 years, for the stationing of a caravan for residential use. Indeed, the caravan currently on site is not occupied for residential purposes at present. Similarly, it is not demonstrated that the entirety of the land is currently, or has been, in use for concrete batching. As such the application for a Lawful Development Certificate for an Existing Use is refused.

Address: Corner Barn Lower Boscaswell Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7ER
Description: Installation of Juliet Balconies & Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed enlarged openings/Juliet balconies appear incongruous and inappropriate in the context of the character and form of the existing converted barn, and the proposed works materially reduce the visual quality of the streetscape. The proposed works fail to preserve the character and appearance of the Boscaswell Conservation Area, which is located within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty The National Planning Policy Framework requires harm to be weighed against the public benefit of the proposals. In this case the harm of the proposed Juliet balconies and associated works has been set out above. Although the private benefits and minor economic benefits of the insertion of Juliet balconies are appreciated, the proposed works would result in less than substantial harm in relation to the Conservation Area and its setting that are not balanced by these factors or other factors acting in the public interest.The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 2 (paragraphs 1a to 1d), 12 (paragraphs 1a and 1b), 23 (paragraphs 2 , 2a and 2b) and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); Sections 1, 2.6, 2.9, 2.10 and 7.8 of the Cornwall Design Guide 2013; and paragraphs 126, 130, 134, 194, 197(c), 199, 202, 176, 178 and 189 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development does not accord with the local planning authority's statutory duty under section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 because it would not preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Conservation Area. 2 The proposed Juliet balconies, due to their design and location, would result in an unacceptable increase in overlooking and disturbance in relation to the immediately adjacent garden area of 17 Boscaswell Village. The extremely close proximity of the proposed Juliet balconies allows for a significant increase in levels of overlooking and disturbance to the users of 17 Boscaswell Village that is considered intrusive, unreasonable and of harm beyond that of the reasonable levels of privacy currently enjoyed at this property. The proposed Juliet balconies would raise concerns relating to the impact upon the occupiers of neighbouring property that are not balanced by other factors acting in the public interest.The proposal is therefore contrary to Policy 12 paragraphs 2a and 2c of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016); Section 2.6 (bullet point 1); Section 4.1 (bullet point 1) and Section 4.11 (bullet point 1) of the Cornwall Design Guide 2013; and paragraphs 126, 130, 132 and 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: Land South East Of Thimble Hall Chilsworthy Cornwall PL18 9PB
Description: Outline application for single storey timber built log cabin for use as holiday accommodation with appearance and landscaping reserved.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would be tantamount to a new dwelling in the open countryside, with its related domestication impacts, in a relatively isolated and unsustainable location, for which no special circumstances or justification have been established, and would lead to significant detrimental environmental impact by failing to respect the historic interest in the area nor protect and enhance the historic environment forming part of the World Heritage Site, nor would it protect and enhance the visual quality of the site and its surroundings, nor conserve or enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the AONB, instead contributing to a gradual erosion of the special qualities and features for which the landscape is designated. As such, it fails to accord with the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 7, 5, 3, 23, 24 and 1 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, policies LET2, HE1 and LA1 of the Calstock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2020-2030, and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, with particular reference to parts 2, 15 and 16. 2 The application has failed to provide a desktop mining search and stability assessment, nor a Phase 1 ground contamination investigation report in respect of historic mining activity in the immediate vicinity of the site to facilitate an appropriate assessment of whether or not ground instability or contamination poses a threat to the health and safety of those working or subsequently living on the site, to establish whether or not the site is safe for human habitation. As such, it fails to accord with the provisions, aims and intentions of Policies 16 and 1 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and the National Planning Policy Framework 2021, with particular reference to parts 15 and 2 and paragraphs 183, 184, 185, 186 and 8.

Address: 3 The Mews Road From Perran Lane To Church Farm Perranuthnoe TR20 9NB
Description: Amendments to Existing Roof Structure and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The addition of a pitched roof dormer to the roof would be wholly at odds with and would be seen in stark contrast to the single storey roof of the existing dwelling. The pitched roof dormer would project above the existing roof line and would be seen as an awkward and incongruous addition that would neither reflect nor respect the form of the existing dwelling. The proposal would cause less than substantial harm to the special interest and significance of Conservation Area. In these circumstances, paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021(NPPF) states that the harm should be weighed against the public benefits of the proposal. The benefit of the dormer addition would not sufficiently offset the adverse impacts upon the character of the Conservation Area. The proposal would therefore fail to preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Conservation Area. The proposed development is in conflict with Policies 2, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 126, 130, 174-178 and 194-208 of the National Planning policy Framework 2021 and contrary to the duty of the local planning authority stipulated by Section 72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990.The proposed development would also be detrimental to the character of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and therefore is in conflict with Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policy MD9 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021. 2 The addtion of a pitched roof dormer by reason of its design and relationship to the neighbouring properties would give rise to an overbearing impact to the occupiers of the properties either side of the proposed development resulting in a significantly diminished unsatisfactory outlook. The proposal represents poor design in terms of resultant roof shape and the poor relationship between neighbouring properties gives rise to a poor level of amenity and substandard living environment for all occupiers. The proposal therefore fails to accord with policy 12 of Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Known As Leans Field North Of Trevarian Hill Trevarrian Newquay Cornwall TR8 4AD
Description: Temporary change of use of land for Drive-in Cinema
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal would not be of appropriate scale to its location and would not be accessible by a range of transport modes. The development would be sited in a prominent location on the undeveloped coastline. Whilst the harm would be temporary and reversible, the proposal would still be in situ for a significant period of the year and would result in considerable harm to the character and appearance of the area, which is designated as Area of Great Landscape Value. Whilst the development would bring forward significant economic benefits, it is concluded that the proposal would not provide a well-balanced mix of economic, social and environmental benefits. It is therefore considered that the proposal would not amount to sustainable tourism and would conflict with Policies 2, 5, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016 and saved Policy 14 of the Restormel Local Plan 2001. 2 The proposal is for a main town centre use as defined by annex 2 of the National Planning Policy Framework. The proposal would be located within the open countryside and would not be accessible or well connected to a town or centre. The application would fail to satisfy the sequential test and would conflict with Policy 4 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, and paragraphs 87, 88 and 91 of the National Planning Policy Framework. 3 The application fails the statutory derogation tests as it would introduce a disturbance to foraging and commuting bats and there is no imperative reason of overriding public interest for the development. The application is therefore contrary to Policy 23(3.d) of the Cornwall Local Plan and the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 (as amended) and amendments; Schedule 5 of the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981; paragraphs 98 and 99 of Circular 6/2005 and government guidance (updated 7 January 2021) Protected Species and development: advice for local planning authorities.

Address: Land East Of Meadowcroft Bray Shop Callington Cornwall PL17 8NX
Description: Construction of two four bedroom bungalows
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development, by reason of its location outside of any defined settlement, does not represent infill or rounding-off, nor does it make use of previously developed land within or immediately adjoining the settlement, and would visually extend residential built form into the countryside, eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting, which is within an Area of Great Landscape Value.  In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable form of development in the countryside leading to harmful incremental growth and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016) and Saved Policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local Plan.

Address: 1 Duke Street St Stephens Launceston Cornwall PL15 8HE
Description: Listed Building Consent for replacement windows
RefusalReasons: 1 The introduction of double glazed uPVC windows would fail to enhance or restore/preserve the features and fabric and appearance and historic character of this Grade II listed house, its historic setting or the wider Conservation Area, and the less than substantial harm caused by the proposed development would not be outweighed by any public benefits. As such the proposal conflict with Policy 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (Adopted 22nd November 2016) and paragraph 202 of the 2021 National Planning Policy Framework.

Address: Land East Of Trewellard Farmhouse Trewellard Hill Trewellard Pendeen Penzance Cornwall TR19 7TE
Description: Demolition and removal of various outbuildings, replacement of Storage Barn for agricultural use and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would introduce a building which is not typically agricultural in character in a prominent location within the open countryside for which there has been no justification demonstrated. The application site falls within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Heritage Coast, Conservation Area and World Heritage site and the proposed development is not considered to conserve or enhance the landscape character and natural beauty of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and Heritage Coast, preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Trewellard Conservation Area or protect, conserve and where appropriate enhance the significance of designated and non-designated assets and their setting in regard to the World Heritage Site in conflict with Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021, Policies 1, 2, 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990.

Address: Land South Of Pico Ville The Mount Par Cornwall PL24 2BX
Description: Outline Application all matters reserved for the erection of a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The scheme to introduce a dwelling onto this site would result in a development that would appear cramped and at odds with the character of the established pattern of development and street-scene. The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims of Policies 2, 12 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030. 2 The scheme would result in a cramped form of development for the occupiers of the proposed dwelling with limited usable or private amenity space to the detrimental of the health and wellbeing of occupiers. The proposal is therefore contrary to the aims of Policies 12, 13 and 16(3) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Cornwall Council's Chief Planning Officer's Advice Note: Good Design in Cornwall. 3 The site is not conducive for a housing development without having a detrimental impact upon the living conditions of the occupier of The Annexe (rear of No.3 Nevada Villas) through noise and disturbance as well as to the occupants of No.3 Nevada Villas through overlooking and loss of privacy. The proposal is in conflict with Policy 12 (2a, b and c ) of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 which requires development to demonstrate a design process that has clearly considered the existing context, noting development proposals should protect individuals and property from, overlooking and unreasonable loss of privacy; and overshadowing and overbearing impacts and unreasonable noise and disturbance.

Address: North Coast Holiday Cottages New Portreath Road Redruth TR16 4QL
Description: Change of use of two holiday dwellings to C3 residential
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development is located in an open countryside location where there is poor accessibility to services, facilities, amenities, and employment. With no special justification the scheme introduces open market dwellings at an open countryside location which would not be appropriate to the prevailing character which comprises holiday units and generate domestic paraphernalia which would not respond to its landscape setting. The proposal would therefore be contrary to Section 12, paragraph 127 and Section 15, paragraph 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and Policy 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, the guidance within the Cornwall Design Guide and Part 2 (Context and Identity) of the National Design Guide (Planning practice guidance for beautiful, enduring and successful places, January 2021)

Address: Land North East Of Moss Side Farm Tavistock Road Callington Cornwall
Description: Variation of condition 1 of decision PA20/02110 dated 11/02/2021 Reserved matters application for the construction of 46 dwellings and associated infrastructure. (Details following outline application no. PA16/04340 approved on appeal 06/04/17.)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, in seeking to replace 22 of the dwellings of a permission (for 46 dwellings of wholly 2-storey built form) with single storey bungalows, would alter the nature and extent of the development permitted and - through the introduction of overlooking opportunities leading to degraded levels of privacy, extensive design and layout challenges, together with an introduced lack of tenure neutrality - result in the fundamental alteration of the development as permitted.Given that the local planning authority shall consider only the question of the conditions subject to which planning permission should be granted, the proposed change in plans is considered to fall outside of the remit of Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and to conflict with the contents of Paragraph: 031 Reference ID: 21a-031-20180615 of the National Planning Practice Guidance (Revision date: 15 06 2018).

Address: Bealbury Orchard St Mellion Saltash Cornwall PL12 6RX
Description: Outline application for the construction of two dwelling houses with all matters except access reserved
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwellings, by reason of the location in the open countryside and no relation to any established settlement, does not represent infill, rounding-off or make use of previously developed land within or immediately adjoining a settlement, and would visually extend the built form into the countryside, eroding the character and appearance of the rural setting. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify it, the proposal represents an unsustainable and sporadic form of development in the countryside and, in the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh such harm, the proposal is contrary to Policies 1, 3, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 (November 2016).

Address: Land Adj To Laflouder Farm House Laflouder Lane Mullion TR12 7HT
Description: Reserved Matters application for access, appearance, landscaping, layout and scale following outline approval PA18/09039 dated 04.12.18
RefusalReasons: 1 By reason of occupying a prominent position in the local landscape which by reason of the proposed massing, height and design of the proposed contemporary dwelling it is considered to neither conserve nor enhance the landscape and scenic beauty of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, nor take into account the sensitivity and capacity of the landscape asset. The proposal is therefore considered harmful to the appearance and character of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and it does not promote or reinforce local distinctiveness. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030; paragraphs 8, 130, 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021; and Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016 - 2021.

Address: Land North East Of 6 Carnyorth Terrace Carnyorth St Just Cornwall TR19 7QE
Description: Construction of single dwelling and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would infill an existing gap within the settlement which is considered to positively contribute to the character and appearance of the Carnyorth Conservation Area and St Just Mining District World Heritage Site. The proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the surrounding area and the modest contribution to the housing stock and small economic gain through the construction of the dwelling are not considered benefits that outweigh this identified harm with particular regard to paragraph 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. The proposed development fails to preserve and enhance the character and appearance of the Carnyorth Conservation Area and St Just Mining District World Heritage Site in conflict with the aims and intentions set out within Policies C2 and C7 of the Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2013-2018, Section 72 (1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Policies 1, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 130 and Section 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land SW Of Treamble Chapel Amble Wadebridge Cornwall PL27 6EW
Description: Proposed Live/Work unit
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located within the countryside, clearly divorced from any settlement. A new live/work unit in this location would introduce accommodation with poor accessibility to necessary daily services and facilities which would perpetuate over reliance on the private vehicle and associated unsustainable traffic movements. It would also harm the distinctive character of the surrounding area by introducing built form and domestic chattels onto an overgrown parcel of land within the countryside. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this rural location, including compelling evidence of an essential need for the proposed type of accommodation on this specific location, the proposal is not sustainable development and is contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and 21 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 80, 92, 104, 112, and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land North East Of Woodbine Cottage Kestle Mill Newquay Cornwall TR8 4PU
Description: Permission in Principle for conversion of a double garage into a single one bedroom dwelling (resubmission of previous refusal no. PA20/07580)
RefusalReasons: 1 The existing building lies within the open countryside, is not appropriate to retain and its conversion to residential use would not lead to an enhancement to its immediate setting. The application does not represent a sustainable form of development and is contrary to the aims and intentions of Policies 1, 2, 7, 21, 23 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and paragraphs 8, 9, 79, 80, 130, and 182 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The application site falls within the Zone of Influence of the Penhale Dunes Special Area of Conservation (SAC), and it is considered that the proposal would, when considered in combination with other plans and projects, adversely affect the integrity of the SAC without the ability to mitigate. Consequently, the proposal would represent Habitats Development for which permission in principle cannot be granted. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of Policy 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030.

Address: The Old Barn Access To Perranwell Farm Perranwell TR4 9PB
Description: The construction of a single dwelling on previously developed equestrian land within or adjacent to the settlement of Perranwell
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is located outside of the definable limits of the settlement of Perranwell and does not represent an acceptable form of infill or rounding off, as defined in policy 3 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030. Neither it is considered that the proposal represents development of previously developed land. The development therefore represents an undesirable and sporadic extension of the built form into the adjoining countryside, which would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment. In the absence of any special circumstances to justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, and paragraphs 8, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a suitable Phase 1 Land Contamination Report which properly determines and evaluates the existence or otherwise of contamination, its nature and extent, and the risks it may pose to receptors, it has not been possible to conclude that the proposal would not result in harm to future occupants or the natural environment. As such it cannot be confirmed the proposal could be made safe and the proposal conflicts with policy 16 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 183 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 The development relates to a site partially within an area identified as susceptible to surface water flooding; the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 indicates that a site-specific flood risk assessment is required for developments in such areas where a more vulnerable use is proposed. In this case, an appropriate flood risk assessment has not been provided. As such, it has not been demonstrated that the development, which will introduce a more vulnerable use, is suitably safe from flood risk; neither has it been demonstrated the development would not impact upon flood risk elsewhere. The proposal is therefore considered contrary to policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 159 and 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land West Of Kimlers Way Kimlers Way St Martin Looe Cornwall PL13 1PS
Description: Construction of 33 dwellings to include public open space, landscape planting, pedestrian and vehicular links.
RefusalReasons: 1 The development of this site for dwellings, and not for employment units in the face of a strong record of delivery of the former and a shortage locally of the latter, would fail to represent balanced, sustainable development to serve the community of Looe.  As such the proposal conflicts with Policies 2, 2a and 5.2 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Policy E3 of the emergent Looe Neighbourhood Development Plan Submission Draft Jan 2021 and the advice within paragraph 8a of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The development would fail to provide for active travel routes along obvious desire lines, clear visibility at access points, unimpeded access for service vehicles and adequate levels of parking provision. As such the proposal conflicts with Policies 12, 16 and 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Policy T4 of the emergent Looe Neighbourhood Development Plan Submission Draft Jan 2021 and the advice within paragraph 104 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 It has not been demonstrated that the development would not result in harmful heightened rates of surface water run off, and that, in turn, flood risk would not be increased elsewhere. As such the proposal conflicts with Policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Policies CCLS6 and CCLS7 of the emergent Looe Neighbourhood Development Plan Submission Draft Jan 2021 and the advice within paragraph 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 4 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of affordable housing, off-site financial contributions towards mitigation with regard to impact upon the provision of public open space, and also the impact of occupants upon the Plymouth Sound & Estuaries Special Area of Conservation and Tamar Estuaries Complex Special Protection Area, the proposal is contrary to Policies 8, 22, 23, 25 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016.

Address: Land And Caravans Nancemellin Camborne Cornwall TR14 0DW
Description: Certificate of existing Lawfulness for the stationing of a residential caravan with associated shed and surrounding raised decked area, with the development as a whole resulting in operational development upon agricultural land to provide residential accommodation, with a continuous residential use for over ten years.
RefusalReasons: 1 Based on the documentation and evidence provided in support of the application and having regard to representations and contradictory evidence received against the application and other information available to the Authority, it is considered that the applicant has not discharged their onus of proof, to demonstrate that, on the balance of probability, a residential caravan with associated shed and surrounding raised decked area, with the development as a whole resulting in operational development upon agricultural land to provide residential accommodation, with a continuous residential use for over ten years has occurred on the land known as Ro Dama, Nancemellin, Camborne, TR14 0DW. As such, the material change of use of land is not considered to be lawful by virtue of immunity from enforcement action in accordance with Section 171B(3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) because the use has not occurred for a period of ten years from the date of the breach, nor has immunity been gained under Section 171B(2) of the 1990 Act because the development is not considered to consist of the change of use of any building to use as a single dwellinghouse. For these reasons, the Certificate of Lawfulness application is refused.

Address: Leti Coth Farmhouse Gorran St Austell Cornwall PL26 6EW
Description: Change of use of land for the siting of 1no. holiday caravan, associated hard standing, septic tank, parking and decking. Retrospective.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed holiday let would not enhance the immediate setting; would not be accessible by a range of transport modes and would lead to an intensification of a residential use in the countryside where no special circumstances have been demonstrated. Consequently, the proposal is in conflict with Policies 2, 3, 5 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, adopted November 2016. 2 The proposed development as a result of its siting, scale, materials and design will result in a prominent and incongruous addition that will harm the landscape and distinctive scenic beauty of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The social and economic benefits of the development do not outweigh the landscape harm. The proposed development is contrary to Policy 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, Policy MD9 of the Cornwall AONB Management Plan 2016-2021 and paragraph 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 3 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions to mitigate the recreation impact on the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan.

Address: Primrose Farm Access To Primrose Farm Lower Sticker St Austell PL26 7JL
Description: Siting of three glamping units and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development of the site for three holiday letting units by reason of the location of the site in the open countryside, divorced from nearby services, facilities and amenities would represent unsustainable new residential development for which no special justification has been adequately demonstrated. The proposal therefore represents an unsustainable, undesirable and sporadic form of development that would be harmful to the intrinsic character and beauty of the countryside. The development is therefore contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 22 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8, 79, 130, and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of financial contributions for mitigation for the Fal and Helford Special Area of Conservation for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 of the Cornwall Local Plan

Address: Portholland West Car Park West Portholland Portloe Truro Cornwall TR2 5PU
Description: Installation of payment machine, ANPR camera and associated infrastructure. Part retrospective.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed parking meter infrastructure, in combination with the adjoining ANPR camera and support post, would represent alien and visually intrusive man-made features which would fail to conserve or enhance the landscape character and scenic beauty of the AONB in which the site lies or the setting of the adjoining listed historic lime kiln structure due to their design and scale, in conflict with policies LA1, LA2, CV2, GP1 and CD1 of the Roseland Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015-2030, Policies 12, 23 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016, Policies MD9 and SCC9.02 of the AONB Management Plan 2016-2021 and paragraphs 8, 130, 174, 176 and 197 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 1 St Crewenna Terrace Hayle Road Leedstown TR27 6DD
Description: Extension of Existing Dwelling to Form Separate Dwelling House and Associated Works
RefusalReasons: 1 Due to the constrained parameters of the plot, the proposed dwelling would be built-up immediately adjacent to the boundary shared with No. 2 Hayle Road, the neighbouring dwelling to the south-east. By reason of the constrained parameters of the plot, together with the scale, form, appearance and layout of the proposal, the proposed dwelling would loom above the boundary shared with No. 2 Hayle Road, resulting in harmful sense of enclosure and oppressiveness experienced within the rear garden of this neighbouring dwelling. The proposal would therefore fail to achieve a high standard of amenity for the occupants of the neighbouring property as a result of the harmful overbearing impacts identified. As such, the proposal would be contrary to the aims and intentions of policies HT1 and HT4 of the Crowan Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018 - 2030, policies 1 and 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 Policy FAS4 of the Crowan Neighbourhood Development Plan 2018 - 2030 states that, on any new development, sufficient on-site parking must be included to ensure that no additional on-street parking is required, with at least two spaces provided per small unit (1-2 beds) and more for larger units (3+ beds). Due to the constrained parameters of the parking area proposed to serve the existing and proposed dwellings, it would not be possible to safely park and turn four vehicles without egressing onto the adjoining carriageway in a reverse gear. When egressing onto the B3302 in a reverse gear, the visibility of oncoming traffic approaching from the south-east would be severely constrained by the presence of the neighbouring dwelling, thereby raising potential for vehicular conflict. Therefore, the development proposal fails to demonstrate that safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved by all vehicular users which results in conflict with policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 110 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. This reason for refusal is in accordance with paragraph 111 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: 39 Lower Pengegon Pengegon Camborne Cornwall TR14 7UJ
Description: Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of two flats
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development would result in the loss of a historic dwelling within the Camborne and Redruth Mining District World Heritage Site (WHS). The existing dwelling and those adjacent have evidential and historical value in that they are a tangible and legible representation of past lives and the activities within this section of the WHS, such that the existing dwelling is deemed to be a non-designated heritage asset which adds to the overall significance of the WHS being a designated heritage asset. The loss of the existing dwelling, which is an irreplaceable resource, would result in the loss of a non-designated heritage asset and less than substantial harm to the significance of the WHS. The resulting harm to the authenticity and integrity of the WHS is not wholly exceptional nor is it outweighed by any substantial public benefits. Furthermore, by reason of its form, footprint and design, the extension proposed to accommodate the new flats would fail to harmonise with the character and appearance of the existing terrace of historic cottages, thereby failing to promote local distinctiveness and respond positively to the landscape. In the absence of any other material considerations which outweigh the identified harm, the proposal is contrary to policies 1, 2, 12, 21, and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, paragraphs 8, 119, 130, 189, 197, 199 and 202 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and policies P3, C2 and C9 of The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape World Heritage Site Management Plan 2020-2025. 2 In the absence of sufficient technical information to support the application where there is considered to represent surface water flooding concerns, it has not been demonstrated that the proposal would minimise, reduce or where possible eliminate flood risk on site and in the area. The proposal is therefore considered to conflict with the aims and intentions of policy 26 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraph 167 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Off Francis Road Trebetherick Wadebridge PL27 6TR
Description: Variation of Condition 5 of Application PA18/11257 dated 30/01/2019 namely to change the wording as follows :- "The development hereby permitted shall be used as holiday accommodation only and shall not be occupied as a person's sole or main place of residence nor shall the unit be sold off separately for any purpose from the Highcliffe Holiday complex, unless the sale of a freehold interest includes covenants in perpetuity which require the house to be used for holiday purposes only and ties the future management of the property exclusively to the Highcliffe Holiday Complex as shown edged red on the plan PD343/17. The owners/occupiers shall maintain an up-to-date register of the names of all owners/occupiers of each individual unit on the site and of their main home addresses and shall make this information available at all reasonable times to the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To support the expansion of the existing Highcliffe Holiday Complex in accordance with policy 5, criterion 3, of the Cornwall Local Plan and to aid in implementation of Policy STMNDP of the St. Minver Neighbourhood Plan 2015-2030 which seeks to support the expansion of existing businesses, particularly those based on tourism and to avoid the circumvention of Policy STMNDP 3.2 of the St. Minver Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015-2030"
RefusalReasons: 1 The application if approved would undermine the planning reason for approving the development in principle which was to support the expansion of an existing tourism business and to prevent the circumvention of the principal occupancy condition required by the St Minver Neighbourhood Development Plan for all new dwellings in this location. It would therefore be contrary to adopted development plan policy 5, criterion 3, of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016-2030 and policies STMNDP 2.2 and STMNDP 3.2 of the St Minver Neighbourhood Development Plan 2015-2030

Address: Prince Of Wales Inn Newtown St Martin Helston Cornwall TR12 6DP
Description: Change of use of public house to a single dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The change of use of the Prince of Wales Inn to a sole residential use would deny the population of Newtown and nearby rural settlements, together with tourists, an important community facility which contributes to the social and economic wellbeing of the local community. It is not considered that sufficient evidence is provided to demonstrate that there is no need for the facility or that it could not be economically viable such that a commercial future should be abandoned, while there are further insufficient alternative facilities available in the vicinity. Consequently, the development fails to accord with policies 1, 4 and 5 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8, 81 and 84 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021

Address: 7 Trevarrick Road St Austell PL25 5JN
Description: Application for a Lawful Development Certificate for a proposed use: Extension of an existing two-storey gable to the rear of the property by three metres from the existing wall line with minor changes to windows in the front elevation.
RefusalReasons: 1 The development would fail to accord with Class A of part 2 of schedule 2 of the Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 for the following reasons:The proposed entrance feature is to accommodate balcony provision upon its roof, such works not falling within the scope of the above permitted developmentThe first floor of the proposed 2 storey extension incorporates a window wrapping around the corner of the building, thus failing to accord with the condition A (b) of the above legislation in that this window does not appear to be obscure glazed or non opening. For these reasons it is considered that planning permission is required for this work.

Address: Kelsey West Pentire Road Crantock TR8 5SD
Description: Demolition of existing dwelling and construction of a new dwelling.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling by virtue of its scale, mass, architectural form, design and materials results in a development that is visually prominent, incongruous and dominant in the streetscene, to the detriment of the character of West Pentire and Holywell and Perranporth AGLV. It fails to demonstrate an understanding or response to surroundings or promote local distinctiveness and conflicts with policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, PV1 of the Crantock Neighbourhood Development Plan and paragraphs 11, 130 and 174 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 The proposal, by virtue of its proximity to the boundary and the introduction of a balcony on the SE corner, will have an overbearing impact and lead to an unacceptable level of overlooking upon the neighbouring property Seascape, and due to the scale, form and massing, would be unduly harmful to the residential amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring residence. As such, the proposal is considered to be contrary to the aims and intentions of Policy 12 of the Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010-2030 - adopted November 2016 and Section 12, particularly paragraph 130, of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land Adj To Piskey Laden Gwallon Lane Marazion Cornwall TR17 0HJ
Description: Construction of a dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The cramped siting of the proposed dwelling in relation to other existing and approved development, along with the overall introduction of additional built form, associated parking, domestic paraphernalia and boundary treatments, in this semi-rural setting would fail to retain the spacious character of the surrounding built form and would compromise the semi-rural character of area, particularly when viewed from public vantage points. As a result, the proposed development would conflict with policies 1, 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030 and paragraphs 8 and 130 of the National Planning policy Framework 2021, and the recommendation for refusal would accord with paragraph 134 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South East Of Penscombe Barns Lezant Launceston Cornwall
Description: Proposed alterations and extension to previously approved barn conversion with extant permission (E1/2009/00354)
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed extensions by reason of scale would dominate the host building and would detract from the original proportions and simple form of the historic building resulting in the loss of the barns character. The proposals fail to lead to an enhancement of the site or its wider setting. The proposed development is therefore considered to be in conflict with Housing 1 Policy of the Lezant Neighbourhood Development Plan 2019-2030, Policies 2, 7, 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic policies 2010-2030 and paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of Rising Sun Nurseries Harrowbarrow Callington Cornwall PL17 8JD
Description: Construction of three-bedroom detached dwelling, provision of external garden amenity area
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposal, in seeking the erection of a dwelling in what is considered to be a rural location outside of any clearly defined settlement would fail to accord with the Council's strategy for the delivery of housing. As such it conflicts with Policies 3 and 7 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016 and Policies HP1 and HP2 of the emergent Calstock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030 Submission Draft (including Post-examination Modifications) August 2021. 2 The proposal, by reason of its large mass relative to its modest plot size, together with its conspicuous extensive glazing, would appear cramped and unsympathetically urban in appearance. As such it would fail to respect the distinctive character of its rural location or to accord with Policies 2, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan 2016 and Policy HE1 of the emergent Calstock Parish Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021 - 2030 Submission Draft (including Post-examination Modifications) August 2021.

Address: 44-46 Market Street Falmouth TR11 3AJ
Description: Mixed use development comprising retail and residential uses
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development includes 14 units of accommodation with associated car parking provision on the site which would generate an increased use of the main street for vehicular access. This goes against the strategic vision to prioritise pedestrian movements in Market Street, contrary to policies TC1, TC5, and the Town Centre Strategy as set out in the Falmouth Neighbourhood Development Plan 2021-2030 and Policy 27 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010-2030, and paragraphs 92, 104, 106, 110, 111 and 112 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021. 2 In the absence of a mechanism to secure the provision of education, open space, healthcare and highways contributions, and contributions towards the Strategic Access Management and Monitoring Measures for the Falmouth and Helford SAC, for which there is evidence of an identified need, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies 22 and 28 of the Cornwall Local Plan, the European Site Mitigation SPD (July 2021), and guidance contained within paragraphs 55,57, 95, and 98 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.
Dev_Type: All other small scale major developments

Address: Field End Farm Pencuke Lane Higher Crackington Bude Cornwall EX23 0BH
Description: 2 x Tree house holiday accommodation units and associated works
RefusalReasons: 1 The application site is not in a location where new residential units would ordinarily be supported, meaning it is only the enhanced tourist offer which could provide overriding justification. The proposed development, both in terms of the physical built form and associated human activity is considered to result in material harm to the natural character of the area, which currently exhibits undisturbed, tranquil, woodland characteristics, being within an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, Heritage Coast and a County Wildlife Site. The social and economic benefits of the proposal are not considered sufficient to outweigh the adverse environmental impact for which great weight must be given; the proposal therefore represents an unsustainable form of development, contrary to Policies 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030, saved policy ENV1 of the North Cornwall Local plan 1999, Policies CC1, MD6, MD13 of the Cornwall Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty Management Plan 2016-2021 and guidance within paragraphs 8, 11, 84, 120(b), 174 and 176 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2021.

Address: Land South Of Red Lane Red Lane Rosudgeon Cornwall TR20 9PU
Description: Planning in Principle for the construction of up to 5 dwellings
RefusalReasons: 1 The application would involve the provision of additional residential units on land outside of the definable limits of any established settlement. The site is not well related to the existing form of the settlement at Rosudgeon and cannot be considered an appropriate form of infill or rounding off due to the pattern of adjacent development and because it would extend development into the open countryside. Furthermore, the site does not constitute previously developed land. Given the above, the development represents an undesirable expansion of the built form into the adjoining countryside, which would lead to visual harm through the erosion of the character and appearance of the natural environment as well as failing to demonstrate an understanding of the setting. In the absence of any sufficient special circumstances which justify residential development in this context, the proposal does not represent sustainable development and is contrary to policies 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 12 and 23 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and paragraphs 8 and 127 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019. 2 The proposal will impact upon the character and special interest of the World Heritage Site. In the absence of any heritage impact assessment to demonstrate the extent of this harm, it cannot be determined that the public benefits of the proposal are sufficient to outweigh the level of harm incurred, furthermore it cannot be confirmed that the proposal will have special regard to the desirability of preserving the setting. The application is therefore contrary to policies 12 and 24 of the Cornwall Local Plan Strategic Policies 2010 - 2030 and with paragraphs 127, 184, 189, 192 and 196 of the National Planning Policy Framework 2019.

Address: Boscreege Caravan And Camping Park Boscrege Ashton TR13 9TG
Description: Certificate of lawfulness for proposed use of land as a static caravan site without limitation except that it shall be used for holiday accommodation only and shall not be occupied as a person's sole or main place of residence.
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed development for the use of land as a static caravan site without limitation except that it shall be used for holiday accommodation only is considered to comprise a material change of use as the increase in numbers would exceed the development granted under planning decision PA17/07794 and comprise a material change through an intensification of use through an unspecified number of units being located on the site, resulting in the loss of a landscaped area which would result in adverse harm upon the character of the area which is within a World Heritage Site. Planning permission must be sought to undertake the works.

Address: Land East Of Kernou Veor Greenbottom Truro Cornwall TR4 8QH
Description: Permission in Principle for construction of one dwelling
RefusalReasons: 1 The proposed dwelling does not safeguard an agricultural field that is located within the countryside and does not represent infill or the rounding off of a settlement and would visually extend the built form into the open countryside, eroding its intrinsic character.
